I'm not reviewing the book, neither writing a blurb for it. I'm expressing my experience of this deeply humane saga.I've read all Frederik Backman's book and was looking forward to this latest offering. As usual it was packed with emotions, strong characters and passion. This time around it was a small town with a passion for ice hockey and a community who desperately needed to win the season in the interest of the future. Beartown did not have tourism, high-tech or mine industries; it only had darkness, cold and unemployment. It was a town where wild animals barely endure but where the people were tough enough to overcome the challenges. The high school's ice hockey team was their only claim to possible fame and future fortunes. Nobody lived in that town, everybody just survived it. The rules by which the community was built determined that all inhabitants must play by the rules, work hard, take the knocks, don't complain, keep your mouth shut. And so it was for generations.It was the end of the season with the semi-finals looming. Emotions ran high, winning was everything, the social dynamics sped out of control and the ice hockey club's motto, "Culture, Values, Community", shuddered against the walls of the club offices and ice rink. The players understood their trainers. If you apply enough pressure to coal, it becomes diamonds. The club had an unpleasant culture of silence, the sort of thing you find among soldiers and criminals.... Silence always goes hand in hand with shame. But then: the unthinkable happened and the silence was broken, defied, challenged, by an event that rocked the town. A whole community had to test and re-evaluate their own mores and values as well as the noble intentions they had for their children. Nobody could escape the test of loyalty... Some quotes from the book:Water expands when it freezes; you need to know that if you build a house in Beartown. In the summer the rain seeps into the cracks in the bricks, then when the temperature slips below zero the moisture freezes to ice, and the bricks break. She will remember that that‚Äôs how it felt to grow up as the little sister of a dead big brother. A childhood that was one long, desperate attempt not to be liquid, not to seek out the cracks in your parents.Water: If you let it make its way too far in, it can freeze into ice and break your heart.There are few words that are harder to explain than ‚Äúloyalty.‚Äù It‚Äôs always regarded as a positive characteristic, because a lot of people would say that many of the best things people do for each other occur precisely because of loyalty. The only problem is that many of the very worst things we do to each other occur because of the same thing.‚ÄúNever trust people who don‚Äôt have something in their lives that they love beyond all reason.‚Äù Her mom loves a man who loves a place that loves a game. This is a hockey town, and there are plenty of things you can say about those, but at least they‚Äôre predictable. You know what to expect if you live here. Day after day after day.Beartown by Backman differs hugely from his previous books in that it moved away from the Swedish idiom and adapted a North American 'feel'. The Swedish authenticity is absent. I can only assume that the prose was adapted, stream-lined, for a much bigger American audience, with a touch of popular drama, action and excitement brought in to cater for this particular audience. The editors changed.However, Beartown is an excellent story written by a skillful author. The town is still Swedish. The setting still the dark wonderland of the Swedish winter. A really thought-provoking, heart-stopping tale. A Man Called Ove was, and still is, by far my favorite Backman book. In fact, it is still one of my all-time favorite reads. It was written for a different audience with different characters to serve the tale and presented an honesty which made it a superb and highly popular read. The 'earthliness' and charm in A Man Called Ove, and My Grandmother Asked Me to Tell You She's Sorry and Britt-Marie Was Here have gone. The dry and subtle humor left with it. In its place a political correctness moved in with a politeness that will be more acceptable and soothing to a different audience. The previous books were character driven. This book is action-driven. The Beartown characters were interesting, strong, passionate about life, family, community and self interests. They were honest, dishonest and multi-faceted. Some were heartwarming and other heartbreaking. It ripped my heart out.Be that as it may, I loved Beartown too. Not in love with it. Just loved it. However, it still gets another well-deserved five-star rating. Thankfully Frederik Backman was still present. A fantastic read. RECOMMENDED for sure!

A morality tale that exposes the dark side of school team sport programs, with hockey as exemplar. Backman works his usual magic of pulling the reader‚Äôs heartstrings while delivering wisdom on meeting life‚Äôs challenges from seemingly unlikely sources. This is certainly a moving and dramatic story, and one that finds heroism and humanity even in characters you would most like to hate. However, I personally got worn down by the relentless repetition of its simple theme, namely that the cult-like drive toward team winning inspires individual achievement and community cohesion but at the cost of the souls of the players and the town itself. As the book cover indicates, there is a violent event in this tale that splits Beartown apart. Not wanting to spoil that core plot element makes it hard to go into details of the book‚Äôs successes and weaknesses. I can say that I felt there were too many characters to focus on and that I missed the humor that palliated the tragedy in his other books.The remote father of a teenaged hockey star, Kevin, conveys an ominous life-lesson about the impending championship meet:‚Ä¶the final isn‚Äôt just about hockey. It‚Äôs about what sort of man you want to be. A man who goes out and grabs what he deserves, or one who stands in the corner waiting for someone to give it to him.The talented coach, David, wisely stresses teamwork in his training philosophy:He taught them that passes are just as important as shots. ‚Ä¶But he also taught them that they only had each other, that the only person you can trust in this world is the guy next to you on the ice.But he can‚Äôt really take credit for creating a player like Kevin:Because what makes Kevin the best is his absolute desire to win. Not that he hates losing, but that he can‚Äôt even begin to conceive of trying to accept not winning. He‚Äôs merciless. You can‚Äôt teach someone that.Some core messages:When you lose hockey it feels like having your heart scalded. When you win, you own the clouds.Difficult questions, simple answers. What is a community?It is the sum total of our choices.There are few words that are harder to explain than ‚Äúloyalty.‚Äù It‚Äôs always regarded as a positive characteristic, because a lot of people would say that many of the best things people do for each other occur precisely because of loyalty. The only problem is that many of the very worst things we can do to each other occur because of the same thing.We can‚Äôt protect our children we can‚Äôt protect our children we can‚Äôt protect our children. Personally, this was more like a 3.5 star read for me. I had already got most of the book‚Äôs messages from another book about hockey achievement as both a doorway to and displacement from life for an Ojibway youth in Ontario, Wagamese‚Äôs powerful Indian Horse.This book was provided for review by publisher through the Netgalley program.

Wow, Beartown was SO good! Backman has done it again. The setting is a small town (Beartown),located in a cold forest, competing with jobs, sports teams, greater opportunities, and the residents of other nearby, bigger and more prosperous towns. Beartown focuses on its love of hockey. Boys become men when they play on Beartown‚Äôs hockey teams. The story opens with one event then backtracks to how the town arrived at said event. Beartown is a story about friendships, family, community, the power of sports (for better or worse), right vs. wrong, and good vs. evil. The book had me hooked early on. The story built at a good pace - it wasn‚Äôt a slow build but also didn‚Äôt move at the typical quick pace of a thriller. I definitely wouldn‚Äôt classify Beartown as a thriller, but it was intense. Some plot elements were obvious and predictable but not all of them. The story kept me curious about how things would unfold. I liked the ending too. When the book came out earlier this year, I remember reading several reviews where readers mentioned they didn‚Äôt like hockey or weren‚Äôt fans and still enjoyed the book. I do like hockey and I enjoyed the many references to the intensity required for the game, the sounds on the ice during practice and in games, the dedication and commitment players must bring, etc., however, I don‚Äôt think this is all exclusive to hockey - it‚Äôs applicable to most sports, and I think these elements were well-balanced in the story. There‚Äôs so much more to the story that it was easy for me to see why non-hockey fans would still rave about this wonderful book. Beartown is easily one of my favorite reads of the year and for anyone late to the game like me, I highly recommend it!

Fredrik Backman has made quite a name for himself with a number of his novels, though I chose to watch their success from the sidelines. When this book was recommended to me, I thought I would give it a try, since my favourite sport plays a central role. Beartown defines itself by the success of the local hockey team. Buried in the forested part of Sweden, Beartown is usually the butt end of jokes around the country, though some still remember when its junior team rose to second best in a national tournament. Now, two decades on, the team finds itself in the semi-finals, hoping to beat the odds and vie for the coveted championship. While the town waits for game day, the reader learns more about the locals and how hockey influences their daily choices. From teenage girls looking to become more popular to a general manager whose past glories are all but shelved as he makes the tough calls, through to the players themselves who seek fame and fortune. That buzz all changes when one of the star players is accused of a serious criminal act. Backman explores how hockey runs so deep through the veins of some locals that choosing to knock someone down a peg is a greater crime than anything a player could have done. Faced with this division, Beartown must come to grips with all that takes place during the fallout and choose who ought to be vilified, and which lives deserve protection. An insightful book that explores how a small town deals with its one uniting force, even when it becomes tarnished. Recommended for all who love character exploration and the examination of society through small-town microcosms.While I am no hockey player, I can see how many can relate to this book. The story is one that transcends Backman‚Äôs native Sweden and could easily be supplanted here to small-town Canada. Any community that relies on a single sport to create its fabric is sure to see the parallels, as well as how its stars are more than people, perhaps even time-limited gods. Backman offers up a slew of interesting characters who bring their own perspectives to the hockey persona that pervades Beartown. It is not worth trying to list them all, but the attentive reader will see so many personalities woven into the larger fabric of the town and how each plays an important role. Backman does deify the hockey players, but there is a reason for this, as he explores the role they play with the everyday citizen. Many may shy away from the novel because of their lack of interest in hockey, but I would warn those folks not to do so. The story transcends the puck in the net mentality that seems so strong with those who love hockey like myself. Backman offers up a wonderfully powerful social commentary on sports, small towns, and the blinders people put on when things go wrong. I can see a large cross-section of the population enjoying this book because of that, even as the town‚Äôs fabric is frayed and torn apart because of a certain action. There is so much going on within the pages of this novel, though much is spoiled if I say any more. An eventful story, Backman forces the reader to think outside the rink and see just how loyal small towns can be to those who create unifying moments that create water cooler fodder. Bring on the sequel!Kudos, Mr. Backman, for an interesting exploration of society. I am eager to see if you continue in your sequel, which I have in hand and will begin now!Love/hate the review? He wrote A Man Called Ove (2012), Things My Son Needs to Know about the World (2012), My Grandmother Asked Me to Tell You She's Sorry (2013), Britt-Marie Was Here (2014), Beartown (2017), Us Against You (2018), and Anxious People (2020).The story of Beartown follows the events leading up to the rape of 15-year-old girl Maya Andersson by the star junior hockey player Kevin Erdahl, and the consequences for Maya and Kevin, the players, their families, friends, and the community which has a long-standing reputation as a hockey town.Peter Andersson, in his forties, is the general manager of the ice hockey club in Beartown, a small town located somewhere in Sweden. Peter grew up in Beartown and was a junior hockey star. He went to North America to play in the NHL, but injuries stopped his career short. He married Kira, a lawyer from a big city, and their first-born son, Isak, died when he was just a baby. Peter and Kira decided to return to Beartown, with their other children, Maya and Leo, when Peter was offered the job with the ice hockey club. Kira continued to work as a lawyer in a nearby city. Maya and her best friend, Ana, have different interests, but are devoted to each other. Because Ana lives with her father and her mother has left, Ana spends a lot of time with the Andersson family.Amat is a 15-year-old who immigrated to Sweden when he was a little boy, with his mother, Fatima. Fatima struggles on the edge of poverty and works as custodian at the arena run by the Beartown ice hockey club. She supports Amat's devotion to ice hockey, and he displays remarkable ice skating speed. He often goes to the rink with Fatima before it opens and practices his skating techniques and ability. This catches the attention of Sune, the veteran coach of the A-team, which is the highest level team operated by the Beartown club.Kevin Erdahl is the star of the Beartown junior team, which consists of players who are 17 years old. Kevin's talent is so outstanding that the entire junior team has been built around him since he was about seven years old. David is the current coach of the junior team, who has moved up to coach the players in each successive age group as Kevin and his cohort have come through. David, Sune, Peter, the president and directors and sponsors of the ice hockey club, all expect Kevin's team to succeed.The novel opens with the team and the community preparing for a key semi-final game. Recognizing that lack of speed is a weakness, Sune and David agree to add Amat to the team as an underage junior to improve their chances. 4.5****There are few words that are harder to explain than 'loyalty'. It's always regarded as a positive characteristic, because a lot of people would say that many of the best things people do for each other occur precisely because of loyalty. The only problem is that many of the worst things we do to each other occur because of the same thing.This was an intense and taut fiction book. The book is set in Beartown. A town that is shrinking with each year, with less jobs and people moving away. Its isolated and very community driven. Despite the gloominess of Beartown, a bright new future is possible with the towns intense investment into the sport of hockey and their local team. The people of Beartown are obsessed with the sport and invest all their time and sometimes their money into training their children in hockey, watching the games and supporting the team. One day, this is all put in jeopardy due to one single horrendous act. This divides the town into those who believe it should be hushed up and those who believe justice should be sought.The topic of this book, the repercussions of the horrendous act and how the people of Beartown react was heart-wrenching, gut-wrenching, infuriating and tearful. At times the people of Beartown would just victim blame and hush up the person who was courageous enough to come forward and take a stand- I would get so angry that I wanted to throw the book across the room. Some moments in the book and the attitudes of the characters made me feel physically sick. The events in this book make you feel like you've been punched in the stomach and all the air is sucked out of you. These emotions that were invoked in me are what makes a good book and makes Fredrik Backman a brilliant writer.Fredrik Backman tells this story from various points of view, all interwoven together to create an intriguing narrative. I especially loved the characters of Amat, who showed courage in a town that wanted to keep him silent; Zach, a bullied boy with his own courageous and empathetic streak; Benji, a hockey player harbouring his own secret; Ana and Maya, two friends with such a close bond that they will always be there for each other; and Kira and Fatima, two mothers who work hard, who don't fit into Beartown's norm, and encourage their children to do what is right, not what is easy. The strength that these last two characters show is truly amazing, Fredrik Backman does a brilliant job at describing a strong bond of love and support between a mother and her children.  What is clear from the narratives of the characters is that hockey is important, and this overshadows and silences any other important factors or important conversation, such as victims of horrendous acts, bullying, sexism, homophobia and racism. It shows how a town would rather silence these 'mishaps' instead of trying to change the society they live in and face the truth.There's a label she used to love but which she loathes when it's pronounced in a Beartown accent: 'career woman'... but no one calls Peter a 'career man.' It strikes a nerve because Kira recognises the insinuation: you have a 'job' so you can provide for the family, whereas a 'career' is selfish.This book delves into victim blaming. The way the town treats the victim is infuriating however it reminds readers that this happens ALL THE TIME to women, and men, everywhere.'I'm just doing my job here.' That's why no one asks what the boy did; as soon as the girl starts to talk they interrupt her with instead with questions about what she did.... If only she hadn't existed, then none of this would have happened, why didn't she think of that?It starts with 'she wanted it' and ends with 'she deserved it'.The reason why I gave this book 4.5* is that for the first 100+ pages there was a keen focus on hockey, which I understand plays a part in showing the reader how important the sport is to the town, however I was losing interest quickly and was not sure if I should continue. In addition, there is a great amount of detail in this book, some which I felt was not needed, and I did not feel that the book needed to be as long as it was.

Thank-you, Thank-you, Thank-you to NetGalley and Atria books for allowing me the opportunity to read this advanced reader's edition.First off, (as a Canadian) I love hockey. So the blurb about the book intrigued me. A small depressed town, in the forest of Sweden, ever so devoted to their Junior hockey team could so easily have been a small town anywhere in Canada. Everything was riding on the Junior team making the Championship Finals and winning. There was no other option for them. By winning the finals the town would gain notoriety around the country and it would bring a brand new ice hockey training centre and help the depressed economy and its people. Everyone lives and breaths hockey in Beartown until something goes horribly wrong. The story is so much more than just about hockey. It centres around some of the players, coaches and staff and their families.This is such an intense and heartfelt story. It's about a town and people struggling with morals and finding justice. I felt many emotions reading this book from anger to tears of sadness. I highly recommend this book!

I appreciated that this book addressed the issue of sexual assault with some sensitivity. I also liked how Fredrik Backman captured the role of place, how one‚Äôs environment ‚Äì in this place, a small town ‚Äì can influence how one wants to live their life and one‚Äôs comfort with speaking up against the norm.That said, I found the writing in Beartown pretty clunky and difficult to connect with. I will provide a few examples. First, Backman often started chapters with vague, ominous introductory statements that felt over-dramatic to me, like this one:‚ÄúA simple truth, repeated as often as it is ignored, is that if you tell a child it can do absolutely anything, or that it can‚Äôt do anything at all, you will in all likelihood be proven right.‚ÄùWhich‚Ä¶ I guess? But it just feels so nonspecific and theatrical that I couldn‚Äôt connect. Another example, this passage after two friends support one another: ‚ÄúNever again do you find friends like the ones you have when you‚Äôre fifteen years old.‚ÄùLike‚Ä¶ I also guess this may be true in some ways? I‚Äôd rather Backman solely show that instead of then telling us the point he‚Äôs trying to get across, which reduces the poignancy of the characters‚Äô interactions with one another.I also feel like the book tried to include too many perspectives. I would have preferred the novel to focus on one to three perspectives instead of including so many and in my opinion, not doing any of them justice. Though vastly different in content and themes, this book reminded me of watching the TV show Euphoria (which I could only get through half of the first season because of all the violence, then I read all the episodes‚Äô Wikipedia summaries lol) ‚Äì there‚Äôs a lot of shifting around to different points of view. Which kind of works in a television show like Euphoria where you can add elements of glitz and glam to the visuals and the narration, not so much in a novel where at least I wanted more depth from the characters. The more I think about this book, the more I dislike it. If this is Backman's usual writing style, then this may be the first and last of his books that I read. I know I'm in the minority on this one, and perhaps it is because I am too cynical - I felt increasingly manipulated as I reached the end.Beartown is the small everytown, where hockey is king. From the very start, it's laid out explicitly that the success of the junior boys' hockey team is paramount: the town's future depends on it. If the hockey team succeeds, there will be a new school coming to town, and with it new families to supplement the dwindling population. Beartown might even get a shopping mall! All of that rests on the shoulders of the teenage boys on the team, and on no one more heavily than the star, Kevin Erdahl. The story transitions between several perspectives. There's Peter Andersson, the general manager of the club, his wife Kira, and daughter Maya. There are several coaches with different styles who have molded generations of boys and men in Beartown. There are classmates, friends, and teammates of Kevin and Maya. It's a book that truly shows the town in full, and the impact of the choices that the characters make ripple through the entire population. I really liked the setting and the central story of the hockey team. Backman takes a lot of care describing local institutions and areas (the rink, the local bar, the different neighborhoods in the town), as well as the Swedish winter (the darkness, the cold, the atmosphere). I also liked reading the different perspectives, particularly Sune, the older coach in decline, and Amat, the younger player desperate to prove himself. The first half was immersive and interesting. But as I read on, the book lost me. It was partially due to writing style, and partially due to the resolution of the major themes in the story, which I found trite and unsatisfying. There's this third-person narrator who keeps showing up, to say things like this:
Hockey is never satisfied being part of your life, it wants to be all of it.
and
We devote ourselves to sports because they remind us of how small we are just as much as they make us bigger.
and
When you can accept the worst aspects of your teammates because you love the collective, that‚Äôs when you‚Äôre a team player.
and on, and on. This is the same style that wraps up the central conflict of the book, which is Kevin Erdahl, the teenage star, sexually assaulting Maya, the daughter of the hockey club's general manager. While the question is, for the town, "what's the right thing to do, in this conflict?", the question for Backman is, "what's the aphorism to apply to this contrived situation?" How can Backman get his characters to act the aphorisms out, in a somewhat cartoonish way? And how can he misrepresent the actual events happening on the page to manipulate the reader's emotions? (There are several examples of this. (1) The entire book - the ENTIRE BOOK - is based on the setup that one teenager is in the woods with a gun to another teen's head. We get back to that at the very end. Turns out, Maya didn't load the gun and never intended to. She just wanted to scare the shit out of Kevin. In what world does this happen???? (2) The writing in the scene where Zacharias enters the school to scrub the words off of Maya's locker deliberately sets you up to think he has killed himself. (3) When David realizes that Benji is gay, he's massively disappointed and upset for a few pages .... and then you learn he's upset AT HIMSELF! The way that all three of these are written is deliberately misleading to the reader and doesn't mirror the experience that the character is having (and you're reading their perspective!). It's only written that way to manipulate your emotional response.) How are we supposed to feel about the supposed moral quandary of the book, when it actually turns out to be quite easy for everyone to do the right thing? (For real - the older female bartender is able to rally the young ne'er-do-wells of the town to her side, the younger witness in love with the victim easily gives up his spot on the team to Do the Right Thing, and the perpetrator's MOTHER has an emotional breakdown out of the horror of the event.) These scenes aren't actual exploration of the ethical implications. They're just setup so that Backman can emotionally manipulate the reader through stock characters and then toss an aphorism on top.So, not a fan, and I still need someone to explain the exchange rate for kronor to me.

As I read the first third of this book, I found it interesting but, to be honest, I was missing the unusual characters of Backman's earlier novels. Then the story changed and I realized that all before had been prelude! Important prelude to all that would now happen in Beartown!Beartown exists for and with hockey. They have long had a symbiotic relationship, sometimes healthy for both parties, sometimes not for one, the other or either. Families, businesses, all that remains in the declining town are in some way linked to the ice, to hockey. In some ways, there are more elements of Backman's characters from prior books present here than I first thought. There are no stock characters; all are individuals with their own tics and warts or complexities. The quirkiness is more internalized here than in Ove or Grandmother or Britt-Marie, but it is still present. But in Beartown, Backman has delivered a novel with a more complex and a more full story...and actually more complex characters, though I continue to love so many of his earlier ones. Here the town is a living breathing entity, almost separate from all of it's human members. It's master is winning hockey games and survival of the town. Each of the individual human beings, be they the high school age players, their classmates or parents or siblings; the business men who control the local economy; the leather-jacketed toughs who seem a force unto themselves; the coaches, managers or opponents, has to struggle within this town to find their place. And the defining moment of this novel affects everyone of them.I recommend this book to all who have enjoyed Backman in the past. And to those who have not found what they were looking for in past books by Fredrick Backman, I would suggest giving Beartown a try. I suspect it will grab you as it did me and not let you go.A copy of this book was provided by the publisher through NetGalley in return for an honest review.

It took quite some time for me to get to this after ‚ÄòA Man called Ove‚Äô. Based on the reviews, I did sense I had to expect something quite different. It certainly was ‚Äì while ‚ÄòA Man called Ove‚Äô points to that beyond the literal leaving quite a bit unsaid, ‚ÄòBeartown‚Äô takes on the job of verbalizing what would be most difficult for most and does an exceptional job of it. The aftereffects of the book continue well after I finished it. Beartown is a small town, where everything centres around Ice Hockey. There is not much of industry or choices for a career and it is hockey which fires the imagination of the youth. Peter is the General Manager of the Hockey Club having had a successful career himself and moves back to Beartown from Canada. His wife Kira and children Maya & Leo are supportive of how hockey is centerstage in their lives. Kevin is the star of the junior team and will soon be actively sought outside the community. Sune is the coach of the senior team and it looks like the board will most likely let him go in favour of David who is the far more aggressive coach of the junior team. At this point in the story, Backman‚Äôs narrative meanders to the edges of ageism / devaluing of the wise & experienced but pulls back ‚Äì squarely moving into the aftermath of a sexual assault and the divisions it creates. There are so many issues the story throws open in the later stages ‚Äì power structures in society, egos, trauma, manipulation, corruption, class & gender prejudice, burden of proof, victims viewed as manipulators, unequal voices, mobocracy, self-delusion & most of all oppressive silence bordering on cowardice. After all ‚Äì there is no greater enemy to truth than violence, and there is no greater hope than when values combine with courage.The characters are many but will stay with me for a long time to come: Benji for his friendship & calling a spade a spade when it comes to it, Maya for her grace & strength, Peter & Kira for their maturity & family ties, Amat for his humility & courage, Ramona for her values & plain speak, Sune for his wisdom‚Ä¶..It is just possible that the second paragraph of my review might have portrayed an inaccurate picture of what the book is about. It is not about ‚ÄòBeartown‚Äô, a fictional town ‚Äì it is about the world we live in & us - our choices & behaviours.‚ÄòBeartown‚Äô is one book all must read.

But we know the difference between good and evil."Highly recommended!

The people of Beartown are most definitely crazy and obsessed over ice hockey and can‚Äôt get enough of it (and can‚Äôt get away from it ha ha ha). ‚ÄúHate can be a deeply stimulating emotion. For fans of Backman's earlier books, let me state right now that if you are looking for the quirky characters and gentle humor of Ove, Grandmother, and Britt-Marie, you will be disappointed. This novel is a departure for him, and I think it's my favorite one yet.Beartown is a book about a town where ice hockey rules people's lives and defines them. But at it's basic level, it is a book about sports. Football, basketball, baseball, soccer, lacrosse, tennis, gymnastics, just pick one and it works just as well as ice hockey to demonstrate what a particular sport means to it's participants. How a sport can make or break kids. How coaches sacrifice family and home life for the team. The sacrifices of time, energy and money for the parents because their kids are passionate about a sport. How being rich or poor or somebody or nobody ceases to matter when you sit in the stands for two or three hours cheering your team on. The beauty of victory and the heartbreak of loss, and how both those things have something to teach. And underneath it all, how we treat each other in the game of life.There are some big issues in this novel not related to sports, but to things that get swept under the rug, secrets that can weigh heavily on people, and everyone's need to be included and accepted. The resolutions were real, not all neat and tidy and tied up with a bow. I loved these characters and this story and this town.One more caveat if you plan to read this one. I found it slow to get started and wondered where things were going for the first 25% of the book, then wham! Could not put it down!

3.5‚òÖsThe small community of Beartown lived solely for ice hockey ‚Äì the continual, non-stop deep freeze of winter meant the teams could play almost year round. But the town was slowly dying as businesses closed and people moved away. This year though the town dared to dream - the junior league team had reached the semi-finals ‚Äì they would win; and the final would follow. The sponsors would return; the people would return. Beartown would revive‚Ä¶The teenage boys that the life of Beartown relied on were seventeen years of age. Most of them had been playing ice hockey since they were old enough to walk; their dream was close to being fulfilled. The support of the coach, the officials, the hierarchy was intense ‚Äì everything was for the team. Peter was general manager, David was the coach; their boys followed the motto of WIN, WIN, WIN. But the night the team won the semi-final, their celebrations rapidly escalated out of control and nothing would ever be the same. The traumatised victim, the police investigation ‚Äì the ripple effect was felt in every home and residence in Beartown. What would be the outcome? Would the perpetrator be punished? Would the victim survive?Beartown by Fredrik Backman is a dark look at life behind the scenes of sport. About how players think they‚Äôre untouchable; how they can do and get away with pretty much anything. Those who are the victims are made to be the one who did wrong. It happens everywhere ‚Äì and it‚Äôs horrifying. The subject matter of Beartown is harrowing; some of the characters are not nice at all. What a beautiful and well round up coming of age story. Backman is a gifted storyteller, he knows how to convey emotion perfectly. I would even say he is better with emotion than with words (his writing style isn't mindblowing), but I think that the emotion-stirring makes him a such popular writer. He is just a bit melodramatic at times, but that didn't bother me. This book deals with a lot of heavy topics, such as sexual and physical abuse, poverty, addiction, in a very realistic way, that is complex to achieve, not overbearing, and at the same time not shallow. Backman also has a gift of describing simple everydayness - hockey training, going to school, work and family life, engagingly and interestingly. Psychological characterization is done completely through scenes of day-to-day life making this book an embodiment of show, don't tell writers mantra. I was completely immersed in the story and wanted to stay as long as possible in Beartown. Backman does a fascinating job at describing suffering that is inevitable in ordinary life, no matter your age, gender, social class. Through his writing, he describes the difficulties of the bully as well as the bullied, in a well-balanced, empathy-evoking way, without justification or judgment, and you can connect to the story of every single character. That is a quality I always admire in a writer, not to make characters black and white but to take time to show the vulnerable and wounded parts of those who are considered to be villains. It is admirable what a writer approaches issues of gender or social inequality without being blind to the greater picture of all-consuming suffering that is inherent to all humans, no matter the injustice imposed by society. No privilege makes you immune to pain. Great work!

I was beginning to think that Fredrik Backman was a bit of a one-trick pony -- happily settling into the "I can write about curmudgeonly old people with good hearts hiding under the grumpy exterior" genere. This book showed he has a wider ranger than I had previously attributed to him."Bear Town" is a book that is seemingly about hockey and a small town where that sport reigns supreme. A place where most of the residents see their glory days in high school and differences are mocked, not celebrated. A dying town that pins its hopes on the thought that one day the local team might just win a major championship.The story could simply be read at the surface level, and still be a well-written and engaging tale. However, for me, the book was more a metaphor on a way of life. The danger of small-thinking and mob mentality. The shallowness of just "going with the flow." And the courage to speak truth, even knowing the unjust consequences that may follow.Thank you to NetGalley and Simon & Schuster for a galley of this book in exchange for an honest review.

Culture, Values, Community 
The OLD Beartown motto. The new one ‚Ä¶ well, the town has taken so many hits over the years, there really isn‚Äôt any except "The team comes first" and that is exactly the problem.Beartown is at the edge of nowhere, in the middle of woods and darkness and cold. Once, the town had a shot at greatness thanks to their signature sport: ice hockey. But they missed the chance and so fewer and fewer people work in the only factory in town, more and more people move away and those that stay are in a kind of downward spiral.We‚Äôre following many of the residents throughout the book, learn about their pasts to understand their future. Because what we‚Äôre told in the very first sentence of the book is Late one evening toward the end of March, a teenager picked up a double-barrelled shotgun, walked into the forest, put the gun to someone else‚Äôs forehead and pulled the trigger.Who, how exactly or why is what we find out while following the story. We see events unfold and even though I knew relatively early on what was about to happen to a certain teenager, it was gripping and heartbreaking and I couldn‚Äôt put the book down (but had to put it down because it often hurt).Ice hockey, by now, is all the town has left so to some degree I understood the desperation and people‚Äôs obsession with winning as it would have improved the town‚Äôs situation by a lot (a hockey school, a shopping mall, more investors - that sort of thing). However, what the town was willing to do for that was abominable. I get that you want to save your home but at some point you have to ask if what you‚Äôre turning it and yourself into in the process is worth saving. As Stephen King so aptly put it once: ‚ÄûSometimes, dead is better‚Äú.The kids on the team basically know no rules. They can misbehave towards teachers or other people as much as they like, even break the law, and are never punished because the team always comes first and the town needs the team to win (for which they need certain players).But when is enough enough?Nothing that is worth it ever comes easy but how much are you willing to sacrifice - how many people - to get what you want for a town?What kind of person are you; at what point can you no longer look at yourself in the mirror?These are the questions the book asks over and over again, always with different people but always coming back to the main issue. It‚Äôs really nice how the author always comes full circle, explaining people‚Äôs motivations without making excuses for them. Because of course people have reasons; maybe not good ones, but understanding how we got to a point is important nevertheless.I‚Äôm not much of a sports person. I do watch soccer during World and European Championships but never to a level shown here. No matter how good you are at anything, no matter how important the job you do possibly is, you‚Äôre not above the law. That is how I see it. People need to be held accountable for their actions. Period.And that is the next aspect of this novel. Because someone IS being held accountable. And the town doesn‚Äôt like having to look in the mirror and take responsibility for this person turning out the way he/she has, which leads to even more abominable behavior until the final confrontation. The author has an uncanny way of portraying people. The horror of the ordinary, the bleakness of Beartown but also its unrelenting hope, its will to fight, the abominable people who come from money with their sense of entitlement, helicopter parents, insufferable children/teenagers, unconditional best friends, negligent and even violent parents, drunks, racists (or at least people with an aversion towards anyone who is "different" or who they think to be "beneath them"), parents who reflect their own hopes and dreams onto their children until they crush them with their expectations, hard-working people used to making one big sacrifice after another, locker-room talk and "boys will be boys" ‚Ä¶ the best and the worst humanity has to offer and every aspect of life as found anywhere in the world.Fredrik Backman doesn‚Äôt shy away from an all too realistic portrayal of what has been and still is going on in the world. From small town life and economic crises, to victim blaming and taking justice into your own hands.I seriously loathe some people in this town. Some I never liked, but only a few have managed to make me hit my steering wheel in frustration because I wanted to see them hurt for what they said and did - and got away with. It was pointed out to me that I‚Äôm too invested, that this is "just fiction" but not only is it utterly realistic fiction dealing with real-life hardships, not every author can manage to make you care so fucking much (pardon my French).Backman‚Äôs writing style is beautiful. He‚Äôs one of the rare authors who can gut you with a sentence he casually drops in the middle of a completely harmless scene. And just when I thought the worst was over, he even did that right at the end of the book (making me dread the sequel). It really is extraordinary.Warning: This is only for people who have read this book. I mean it. All others: shoo!I‚Äôm not actually happy with the ending. I wanted Kevin to face up to the entire town. I wanted him humiliated. I wanted him to lose everything. Not just for the rape but also for how he behaved to Benji and Maya and in general despite knowing he was guilty. I know this is supposed to show us the power of mercy but certain people don‚Äôt deserve mercy.Just like all the town's people got off waaay too easily. Consider all the horrible things they said and did and most of them haven't even seen the error of their ways! I know, I know: that's realistic. But I don't care. I'm like Kira. I wanna see them hurt! God, I loved that scene when she went after those brats on their bikes. BWAHAHAHAHAHAHA!I am, however, pleased with Maya becoming a star and still playing the guitar Amat buys for her (how sweet that he did that despite needing the money so desperately himself).And Benji. How my heart broke for the poor boy. I hope he'll come out of the closet eventually.The way people kept making excuses and stayed silent almost got more to me than the ones being all-out assholes. At least "the pack" finally got the message from Ramona but I consider it too little too late.*sighs*I need a break now. The plan was to read the sequel immediately but this book has drenched me emotionally in a way only very few others have managed.

just..wow. I'll need some time to process thisalright. some time has passed, and even no review of mine could do this book justice, i'll still try. when i put this on my tbr, i had NO idea that this book would be this complex and gripping. fredrik backman's writing is truly beautiful. instead of shoving facts into your face, he tells the story by telling the stories of selected inhabitants of beartown. be it an old hockey coach, a boy that has to hide his homosexuality, or an immigrant woman that wants nothing more than to help her son in every possible way.while the major conflict only starts around 200 pages in, beartown does not get boring. in that time, the writing incites emotions beyond everything.i hardly ever use quotes in my reviews, but this one struck a chord with me:"she's fifteen, above the age of consent, and he's seventeen, but he's still 'the boy' in every concersation. she's 'the young woman'"just...wow. i have never seen storytelling or characterisation like this. backman's writing does not only suck you up, it makes you a part of the action, makes you feel as if everything happened right in front of you.this book will break your heart. the blatant injustice with which the rape is treated hurts, and it is supposed to hurt - because we all know headlines of girls who were "too drunk", who "were obviously flirting", whose clothing was "too revealing", who were "asking for it". i shed many, many tears over this book - partially because i felt for maya, and benji, and so many more, but also because i know that the case described is, sadly, anything but fictional. i almost cried while writing this review. read the book. now.

Loved it just as much the 2nd time!!!How I enjoy this author's novels! He certainly knows how to tell a story. Beartown is a story about small-town hockey and it's community. People with hopes, dreams, heartache, corruption and secrets.The town revolves around it's junior hockey team and they are about to compete in the national semi-finals. It's now up to a group of teenage boys to fulfill the hopes and dreams of Beartown. A violent act occurs against a young girl leaving the town in shock and turmoil. Accusations are made leaving no resident unaffected. The majority of Beartown residents desperately want to believe that this event didn't happen with many having a disturbing feeling that it's true. Unexpected citizens come forward to try to save the town.Backman is a gifted writer when it comes to examining humanity. He creates characters that are so real that we feel as if we know them. And we certainly won't easily forget them.I highly recommend this unique, touching and thought-provoking story!Many thanks to Net Galley and Simon & Schuster for an arc of this novel.

Wow, this is the first book I've read from Frederik Backman and it is absolutely terrible. Worst book I have finished.The short review: The writing is unrefined, simplistic, and melodramatically monotoned. The story, which drags on twice as long as necessary, forces cliche characters to face a side-choosing modern moral question (with an obvious right and wrong answer) and thinks that it explores a complex contrived situation with depth, but instead it stumbles through caricatured people having unrealistic, forced conversations all told with an excessive amount of eye-roll-inducing dramatic platitudes.The extended review:The writing style is tawdry, immature, and severely lacking. It was a struggle to keep filling my time and mind with this novel, but I finished it so I could give it an honest and properly complete review - plus it was for a book club.Perhaps the most obnoxious aspect of the format is that every chapter begins with excessive platitudes, aphorisms, and smack you in the face dramatic proses that are constantly repeated throughout each short chapter. We get a solid 50 chapters of:
Its just a game. Except it‚Äôs more. It‚Äôs life. Hockey is everything. This book is about life not hockey. Here is an aphorism or platitude that I want to apply to these characters. * * * Chapter Break * * *Here is some clunky, unnatural dialogue that demonstrates said aphorism in an obvious manner. Explain what the characters are feeling so there can be no room for inference. * * * Chapter Break * * *Repeat a variation of the aphorism or platitude, possibly with another character interaction. Also explain bluntly what these people are thinking and feeling and make clear how it contrasts with the previous example. * * * Chapter Break * * *Did you get that? Let me explain the wisdom frankly.* * * Chapter Break * * *Single line repeat the aphorism or platitude again. End Chapter. 
 The above is the tacky writing style and formula used throughout the entire book. There are too many unnecessary chapter breaks to emphasize some statement that was intended to be weighty and meaningful - the style and low quality philosophy quickly becomes tiresome and obnoxious after the first couple chapters. To make the writing more painful, the plot dragged on excessively long, yet somehow the book had no room for any visible character growth.The overall story, while it offers nothing new, could be fine and done well, but the execution resulted in over the top drama and a tone that takes the trite philosophy too seriously. Backman attempts to write from multiple character perspectives and somehow every single one resulted in a cliche. All the characters are banal melodramatic soap opera caricatures who are told to us not shown by Backman‚Äôs annoying habit of outlining what their passions and thoughts. The entire narrative is told, not shown - the role and for what storytelling purpose of each character was made for is readily apparent.Ultimately, there are nearly no redeeming qualities to this novel - it's bad characters, bad writing, bad technique, and a mediocre been done before plot. This book feels like reading the screenplay for a low budget made for TV movie that, like this review, was repetitive and dragged on too long.

Oh dear.After reading Anxious People I was really looking forward to this one. This story about the people living in Ice Hockey loving Beartown was dreadful.The characters were cliched, the story was predictable and there was way too much young bloke, ice hockey loving jock type humour. Beartown is centred around a remote hockey town and its inhabitants. While hockey is a big part of the novel it‚Äôs the community around it that is so gripping. There were a lot of characters in this book which at first I struggled with but soon became a lot more comfortable with. I first became fully immersed around 125 pages in. I loved the dialogue in this novel, it said so much about the characters and their relationships with each other.

"Late one evening toward the end of March, a teenager picked up a double-barreled shotgun, walked into the forest, put the gun to someone else's forehead, and pulled the trigger."I have to admit, I have mixed feelings about this one. When I saw that this book was about hockey, and basing my expectations on A Man Called Ove, I kind of expected a Mighty Ducks vibe. I have to say, I was very, very, very wrong. The author even prefaced my copy with a warning that this particular novel is much darker than his other books. If the author's intro didn't give away the nature of the book, the opening line--quoted above--did. Backman certainly knows how to grab a reader's attention, doesn't he?This book covers a wide range of heavy topics. It's full of violence (and not just typical on the ice incidents), bullying (lot's of it), sexism, as well as classism, with a little xenophobia and homophobia thrown in for good measure. So on one hand, it was an engaging story, but on the other hand, I spent a lot of my time reading it being ridiculously angry. As a woman, the sexism was enough to make me foam at the mouth, let alone all the other infuriating elements thrown in on top of that.I loved the setting, the atmosphere, and the writing. I liked most of the main characters, but there were some I despised. I hated the attitude of the town in general. It was almost a mob mentality because, God forbid, someone mess with their precious little hockey team. I was not particularly happy with most of what happened in the story, but the ending left me with a feeling of pride and justice, even if it wasn't the legal kind. While not every story has to give me the warm fuzzies, I need to be able to take something positive away from the experience. Otherwise, it's not worth reading, because I truly suffer through all those negative feelings and experiences. Extreme empathy isn't always a good thing, and I don't put myself through all that drama for nothing. I'm not an emotional masochist. In the end (triple entendre--add preferred sound effect here), this book delivered and gave me what I needed to move on from all of the doom and gloom held within its pages. I recommend this if you like hockey, Sweden, Scandinavian culture, small towns, cold climates, and/or darker content."They do that in hockey towns."

Going in, I thought Beartown was going to be about a down-on-its-luck hockey town trying to win a championship. But it turned out to be so much more than that. The central conflict, which I won't give away, is portrayed with so much heart, complexity, and raw emotions. It felt so real that I had to read this book slowly, taking deep breathes and frequent breaks just so that my heart didn't burst.There are so many strong and lovable characters in here, including Maya, Kira, Peter, Ana, Amat and so many more. It's great when an author can capture one real three-dimensional character in a book's pages, but to craft so many of individuals and make them all come alive is astounding. This book covers so much, about loyalty, sacrifice, love of self versus love of community, belonging, bonds of family and friends, morality, what we teach our children through our actions and our words. And Backman does it all in a cohesive tale. At times during the first half, it feels like the book could have been more concise, but Backman's beautiful writing and wise insights more than makes up for the slower initial pace.Simply put, this book blew me away!

While this is a very different book than A Man Called Ove, Backman brings the same ability to capture a character‚Äôs essence in just a sentence or two. ‚ÄúHer mom isn't the sort you argue with; her mom is a lawyer, and she never quite stops being one‚Äù. Or ‚Äúyou never want to get away from home as much as you do when you're fifteen years old‚Äù. This is a poignant novel. A whole town‚Äôs hopes are riding on the success of their junior hockey team. So much pressure on the backs of these teenagers. And these kids already have so much pressure, just from life. ‚ÄúOne day he'll stop adding and subtracting income and expenditures in his head all the time. There's an obvious difference between the children who live in homes where the money can run out and the ones who don't. How old are you when you realize that also makes a difference.‚Äù And it's not just the boys. The girls are dealing with their own issues. ‚ÄúFew disappointments can compare with the way you feel the first time your best friend dumps you for a boy.‚Äù Backman‚Äôs writing is flat out gorgeous and poetic. I wanted to highlight about every other sentence in this book. I'm a fast reader, but I found I wanted to really slow down and savor the story. It makes you want to reach out and hug every one of the main characters. Of course, as the book goes on, you want to do something other than hug some of them. ‚ÄúWe become what we are told we are‚Äù. For better or worse, this plays out. This book brought back memories for me about a lot of news stories. The UVA lacrosse player that killed his girlfriend. Football plays like Ben Roethlisberger. My only complaint is that at times, his writing comes across as didactic. You see the points he's trying to make, you don't need to be hit over the head with them. If I hadn‚Äôt loved the story so much, this might have warranted a deduction in stars. But I would have rated it higher than five if I could have, so still a five in my book. This book is amazing. To be able to elicit such a range of emotions from me in such short order. Is it a cliche to compare reading it to a roller coaster? I can see this being made into a movie. In fact, I was surprised when I googled Beartown movie rights to not find they had already been sold. I can't recommend this one highly enough. Sure to be one of my favorites of 2017.

Wow! This book was a massive departure from Fredrik Backman's usual reads. It reminded me a lot of the show 'Friday Night Lights' (if anyone wants to watch a tv show with the same fundamental elements).This is the story of Beartown, a small town that loves Hockey. They live, breath, and literally drink (in large doses of coffee) the sport. It's a coming of age story that hits all the elements of pain, love, heartache, loyalty, defiance, and suffering. The hockey team symbolizes hope for a community that has nothing more than bitter cold and forests. There is a large cast of characters, and the first half of the book spends an extensive amount of time setting up their stories, which at times felt too detailed, but in the end, it all comes together. Then...The incident that flips the town on its head. The community, the coaches, the players, the fans all weigh in. It was astounding to see what side of the conflict the townspeople land on. Beartown reminds you of the few strong ones that fight against evil and those that will join or continue to shade themselves behind a lie.   ‚ÄúIt doesn't take long to persuade each other to stop seeing a person as a person. And when enough people are quiet for long enough, a handful of voices can give the impression that everyone is screaming."  Beartown, at times is infuriating, gut wrenching, and painful. Other times, warm, inviting, and heartwarming. Backman writes in a brillian, creative way--the conversations flowing. Even though the story doesn't end in a perfect knot, there is still some redemption. I recently read another sports heavy book (Carrie Soto is Back) and I was overwhelmed and bogged down by the elements of the sport. I liked that Beartown talks about hockey, but doesn't waste time teaching us about the game like we need to pass a test after. This is more a drama, set in the confounds of a hockey town. The story remains interesting, the drama worthy of attention. Overall, a great read. 4/5 stars.

I was really late to the party for "Beartown" and "Us Against Them" by Fredrik Backman. I ended up listening to both audiobooks back to back last year and really enjoyed them. I'm not entirely sure why I didn't update or write a review for the books, but I did have a lot going on at the time. I also have a harder time writing reviews for audiobooks unless I make notes right away. I'm getting better at taking a moment or two to jot a few things down as I listen. I recently started reading Backman's upcoming "Anxious People" and wanted to add my two cents about these books too. "Beartown" did get off to a bit of a slow start for me but once I got a little farther into it, I was hooked! Once I was finished I immediately started listening to "Us Against Them". Both were excellent reads that I highly recommend!

"People say she's gone mad, because that's what people who know nothing about loneliness call it."I'm not sure where to even begin with how to talk about my love for this book. Everyone said it was amazing, yet it still took me by surprise. The depth of feeling it evoked, the love I developed for every single one of the characters -- I simultaneously didn't want it to end but couldn't wait to see what happened.In the beginning I was a little frustrated with how slow the story was to develop, but I quickly recognized -- and came to appreciate -- how necessary and intentional that was. The time Backman spent developing each character, as well as Beartown itself, made you know them intimately and care for them deeply.This was quite a first book for 2018. I'm not sure how anything else I read this year can live up to it -- it has earned a firm place in my top 10 books of all time. All I can say is READ IT.

Let me just start by saying this is not a book I wanted to read: a town obsessed w hockey, a rape - not interested. I have thoughts on organized sports that go against the mainstream. However, it was my book groups choice and frankly one of the reasons I'm in a book group is to broaden my range of books.  That said, I immediately fell in love with Bachman's writing voice. Wonder if wonders! I enjoyed A Man called Ove very much, but here the authors voice was different - more overtly philosophical. More along the lines of, "Pull up a chair friends and sit awhile. I have a story to tell and it's not just any story"  And I fell in love with his voice, his rhythm of repeating phrases, the people - oh my gosh I loved the people major, minor, good and horrid. And darn if even the horrid didn't receive some redemption by the end. I read this book on my kindle and I only mention that because I noticed that GR had tracked the fact that I had 255 places where I highlighted (used three colors) and written notes. And I fell in love with this book.  Around the middle it became difficult going for a while - I couldn't imagine where else he was going w the story and I thought it would never end. But of course I trusted the author - sighed deeply a few times - and pressed on. And I fell in love with the story and people and powerful writing all over again reading straight through to the ending and beyond.  There is enough wisdom, enough exploration of dozens of themes like friendship, parenting, leadership both of community and individuals, the life and art of coaching, career highs and lows, becoming adults, loss of many kinds, challenges of growing up, parent child relationships, how we send our youth different messages based on their gender, class differences, immigrants, the painful struggles for survival in small towns, and of course the many roles of passion for a sport can play - enough wisdom to fill several books.  My Board of Education friend said she would not want to the one to bring this book up for approval for the high school students and yet we all agreed how it is a book that would be a perfect community read because these are themes that touch all of our lives.  I'm very happy I read this extraordinarily well-written and thought provoking novel filled with people stories that matter. But it was often an uncomfortable read for me. Quotes:Why does anyone care about hockey?  Perhaps it depends on who you are and where. Because it tells stories.Never trust people who don't have something in their lives that they love beyond all reason. Team banner: Culture, Values, CommunityAll organizations like to boast that they are building a culture, but when it comes down to it everyone really only cares about one sort: the culture of winning.Culture is as much about what we encourage as what we permit.

What a beautiful book. I savored every last word of Bachman's. After reading A Man Called Ove, I really didn't think he could get much better than that, but he did. Goodness. I think I'm going to let this sink in a little bit, marinate in it, before writing a more detailed review. For now, all I can say is this book gave me all the feels. Wow! Just wow!

What an amazing book. So many character perspectives. Such a heartbreaking and touching look at a small town deeply affected by isolation and lack of opportunity, and one that doesn't want to confront its own prejudices. Hockey is everything in Beartown, sometimes the one bright spot when jobs are leaving, it's cold and dark in the winter, and all you have to look forward to is a factory job, if you're lucky. Communication isn't the town's strong suit. It's a completely different environment from where I live, but how many of us can't relate to that isolated small town feel and the way that if you fall on the "wrong" side of public opinion, it can make your life hell?It's just brilliant the way author Fredrik Backman takes us through the perspective of so many characters because we see the town through those varied eyes. Too many to write here, but in short, a crime occurs and it's one teen's word against another's.  The town decides it will side with one, and the book does an outstanding job of examining rape culture, as well as hate speech and prejudice against homosexuality and immigrants. One of the most poignant scenes in the book comes near the end when David, who has been the coach of the junior's team since the boys were 7, and has been a father figure for Kevin and Benji, but also participated in and allowed crude jokes about homosexuality to be shouted on the bus, on the ice, and in the locker room, witnesses Benji kissing another boy. Rather than being disgusted, he begins to cry, realizes how horribly he has failed, that Benji would have thought he had to hide such a thing about himself from him. Just so many great moments.  Trigger Warning:  rape

To begin with, this book started out really strong. The thump-thump-thump of the icehockey puck sounded throughout the introduction of the village of Beartown and the people we were going to meet and follow over the next 400 pages. I liked how Backman created an atmosphere and really made me understand how important icehockey was to everyone. The problem with this book, though, was that its narrator became too philosophizing and moralizing. This was okay to start with, but during my reading of ‚ÄúBeartown‚Äù I became increasingly annoyed with it. Furthermore, the novel drags on for too long, in my opinion, and I found it harder and harder to pick it up towards the end. Despite my love for Fredrik Backman and his quirky stories, this one felt like it was too much and too heavy. In the end I think it‚Äôs probably one of my least favourite books I‚Äôve read of his, unfortunately - even though 3 stars means that I still enjoyed it and would recommend it to other Backman fans.

¬†¬†¬†¬† Beartown is very much a character driven plot. There are a lot of characters in play, but it all comes together well. The plot introduces you to teen hockey players who are team stars treated like "gods" who can get away with just about anything. Their parents need lessons in being disciplinarians or how to be involved in their kids lives. ¬†¬†¬†¬† The first half is pretty much getting to know the characters, and the pace is slow, so patience is definetely needed by the reader. At the half point, a major act of violence occurs, and every character is affected. How the plot continues and ends from this violent act is unpredictable for the reader. Your patience will be rewarded by the second half as everything begins to spiral out of control in this small hockey town.

4.5 StarsI rarely read contemporary fiction, but this one pulled me right from the start. The narrative is very slow paced, yet I found myself enthralled by the characters and the town culture. While this is a book about a hockey town, it is really not a "sports books". In fact, it may very well appeal most to those outside of the fandom. I really connected with the perspective of the working mother, seeing so much of myself in that woman. I also loved that the book addressed such incredibly important topics in such a thoughtful manner. Highly recommend this one to readers looking for stories that address darker topics. This novel definitely lived up to the hype.

Beartown, a declining hamlet in the middle of a Swedish forest, has one big hope - ice hockey. Beartown's junior hockey team, the Bears, has made it to the national semi-finals, and - if they go on to win a championship - might attract a new sports arena to Beartown, along with tournaments, hotels, tourist traffic, and so on. This boon to Beartown's economy would be welcome to business owners, residents, and hockey sponsors. Thus, the high school boys who play for the Bears are pressured by both personal ambition and the dreams of everyone around them. The Bears' star player is the team captain, Kevin, a 17-year-old phenomenon who's been practicing day and night since he was a kid. Kevin's best friend is Benji, the team's 'enforcer' - who protects his squad from opposing players during games. Benji and the other Bears look up to Kevin and are intensely loyal to him. Kevin's mother and father - a wealthy, successful couple - are proud of their son's achievements and have high hopes for his future. In some ways, however, Kevin's parents are oddly distant. They travel frequently, rarely attend hockey practices, and seem to brush off signs of boyish misbehavior. Since hockey is Beartown's obsession, the adults who run the Hockey League are always in the public eye. These include the league's General Manager Peter - who made it to the Canadian pros before returning to Beartown; the junior team coach David - whose sole mantra is "Win"; the A-team (older boys) coach Sune - a hockey veteran who's about to be replaced; and the board of directors/sponsors - who pull the strings behind the scenes. Many of these men are anxious - and losing sleep - in anticipation of the important upcoming games. The first part of the book introduces the major characters in the story. In addition to the people mentioned above, this includes: the other teenage boys on the junior team and their families; the pub owner - an upstanding woman who's still mourning the death of her long-dead husband; Peter's 15-year-old daughter Maya - an aspiring guitarist/singer;Maya's best friend Anna - who has a troubled home life; Peter's wife Kira - a high-powered business attorney; David's pregnant girlfriend - who keeps him centered; and more. The initial chapters also establish the ambiance in Beartown - a village that eats, breathes, and sleeps hockey, hockey, hockey. Kids in Little League hockey hope to play for the Bears; Bears players dream of becoming pros; and everyone in town basks in the league's reflected glory. In addition, hopes for economic success related to hockey light up a lot of Beartown eyes.The future of Beartown looks pretty bright until things go badly wrong.As part of the revelry in Beartown - and with his parents away - Kevin throws a big bash at his house.....with plenty of booze. The teenage boys and girls at the party drink too much, and - at one point - Kevin takes Maya to his room and won't take no for an answer. When Maya reports the assault, Beartown becomes a divided town - with a pro-Kevin cabal and a (much smaller) pro-Maya faction. In many ways this is par for the course. Most readers are probably aware of news stories about 'entitled males' (athletes, politicians, celebrities, business moguls, etc.) who take advantage of females.....with little or no fear of negative consequences. Kevin seems poised to join this maleficent group since most Beartown citizens are determined to deny (or excuse) his bad behavior. After all, Kevin is a hockey star!!.Thus, there's a lot of ugly talk and bad conduct directed toward Maya and her family. The author handles these trends deftly, showing us the self-justifications and rationalizations of the people involved. Of course there's no real excuse for this kind of thing, and I was quite disturbed by the book's theme. (In fact, I wish Backman would have chosen some other topic to write about.) Still, several Beartown residents DO step up in an admirable fashion, much to their credit.'Beartown' is well-written, the characters are engaging, and I like the mini-epilogs, which give us a glimpse of the future of some Beartownians. I think many readers would enjoy this book and I'd recommend it to fans of hockey, literary fiction, and Frederik Backman. You can follow my reviews at https://reviewsbybarbsaffer.blogspot....
