Spoiler alert: He‚Äôs done it again! 
Fredrik Backman you‚Äôre one hell of a writer. I read three of your novels and thought I had you all figured out. But then you wrote Beartown and managed to surprise me. Big time!Beartown is a small town on the decline. Fewer jobs are available, the property values are decreasing, there isn't much to lift this town or keep it together, except for hockey, junior hockey. The hockey fever has overtaken Beartown, as the junior team is playing in the league semi-final. Imagine being a high school kid and having to deal with so much: the pressure of the competition that you‚Äôd naturally feel, the pressure of the club through its board members and sponsors, also, the parents' and town‚Äôs expectations. Hockey is an obsession. It‚Äôs also a way to get validation and a get-out-of-town card.We are in many ways influenced by our environment. This small town in the forest, with its endless cold and dark months, feels claustrophobic, more so for some of its inhabitants. Most people are simple, set in their ways, not very accepting of people who are different or have aspirations that are different to their own. The double standards that still apply to women are even more discernible in a small town. I appreciated Backman‚Äôs ability to portray the inner turmoil that goes inside so many women who have aspirations and needs beyond those of just being wives and mothers. Unsurprisingly, nobody‚Äôs life is simple. Everybody has hang-ups, inner struggles or real struggles, regrets and disappointments. For many, life didn‚Äôt quite turn up as they‚Äôd imagined. ‚ÄùBitterness can be corrosive. It can rewrite your memories as if it were scrubbing a crime scene clean, until in the end you only remember what suits you of its causes.‚Äù Beartown is quite the departure from the previous Backman novels, which were inhabited by many quirky characters. This novel is darker, grittier. The writing style is different as well. What‚Äôs not different is Backman‚Äôs ability to create realistic, complex characters, regardless of their age, gender or backgrounds.This novel has a huge cast of characters. The protagonists are the hockey players and their families, the coaches, the general manager and his wife and kids. Teachers, bar owners, businessmen are also part of the cast. Some of the characters are given more air-time than others, still, none of them is redundant. Incredibly enough, I never got confused about who‚Äôs who, which only demonstrates, again, Backman‚Äôs incredible skill.Great writers are also great psychologists. They speak life‚Äôs truths in a way that allows us to connect, relate, and understand. They also hold up a mirror to ourselves and society. Backman‚Äôs craftsmanship accomplished all that and more in Beartown.  I‚Äôve received this novel via Netgalley, in exchange for an honest review. I am so grateful to Atria Books for granting me access.

I don‚Äôt even have the words for this book. It captured so much of the human experience and was both heartbreaking and heartwarming at the same time. As someone who grew up in small sports towns this one hit close to home. It‚Äôs a book about hockey, but more specifically it‚Äôs a book about a hockey town and what people are willing to coverup and overlook for the sake of a great sports team and talented athletes. It‚Äôs about how often in towns like this, because you‚Äôre good at a sport your life and future somehow have more value than those who aren‚Äôt. This was giving Friday night lights (the tv show) vibes and if you‚Äôre reading this thinking it sounds exaggerated or that this doesn‚Äôt actually happen in small towns, it does.

‚ÄúBecause friendship is both complicated and not complicated at all.‚ÄùBEARTOWN is a novel that took me a while to get in to. I was just not all that interested, and then after a 100 pages or so I had time to settle and start to like the book. With a large ensemble cast, and some interesting perspectives on humanity, once I got into it, I enjoyed the experience.The plot-a small rural town, Beartown, whose local hockey team is the biggest thing going. The team is on the verge of greatness, and then there is a rape. Things progress rapidly from there. BEARTOWN is told from the point-of-view of a third person omniscient narrator, so the reader is in the heads of most of the large cast of characters at some point. This novel is the story of a place. Some of the inhabitants of that place I loved, some I loathed‚Ä¶but for most of them I simply had moments of liking and disliking them. Because they are humans, and if I am honest that sometimes liking/sometimes disliking is how I feel about most people. The characters in this book are very human, and thus they are not all one thing or another, but an amalgamation of good and bad. Fredrik Backman does that very well in this novel, creating people who are a mix of contradictory characteristics. As a result, they are interesting.While reading this novel there would be a thought that would come out of the blue that would make me take pause. The following lines are one such instance‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúA long marriage is complicated. So complicated, in fact, that most people in one sometimes ask themselves: ‚ÄòAm I still married because I am in love, or just because I can‚Äôt be bothered to let anyone else get to know me this well again?‚Äô‚Äù It is an uncomfortable thought, and in all honesty the truth is probably somewhere in the middle for most folks.Some quotes that I liked, for various reasons:‚Ä¢	‚ÄúThe town wakes early, like it does every day; small towns need a head start if they‚Äôre going to have any chance in the world.‚Äù‚Ä¢	‚ÄúNever trust people who don‚Äôt have something in their lives that they love beyond all reason.‚Äù‚Ä¢	‚ÄúHe‚Äôs been old for a long time, but is really feeling it today.‚Äù‚Ä¢	‚ÄúThat‚Äôs both a big and a small thing. Knowing that there are people who will never abandon you.‚Äù‚Ä¢	‚ÄúReligion is something between you and other people; it‚Äôs full of interpretations and theories and opinions. But faith‚Ä¶that‚Äôs between you and God.‚Äù‚Ä¢	‚ÄúLoneliness is an invisible ailment.‚Äù‚Ä¢	‚ÄúBut isolating yourself happens faster than you might think‚Ä¶‚Äù‚Ä¢	‚ÄúHumanity has many shortcomings, but none is stronger than pride.‚Äù‚Ä¢	‚ÄúEveryone has a thousand wishes before a tragedy, but just one afterward.‚Äù‚Ä¢	‚ÄúWords are not small things.‚Äù‚Ä¢	‚ÄúBig secrets turn us into small men.‚Äù‚Ä¢	‚ÄúThere are damn few things in life that are harder than admitting to yourself that you‚Äôre a hypocrite.‚Äù‚Ä¢	‚ÄúSometimes life doesn‚Äôt let you choose your battles. Just the company you keep.‚ÄùMr. Backman likes tidy endings. This text is no exception. I did not mind it. In the end this is really just a novel about people, living their lives, reacting to the things around them. And like all of us, sometimes they succeed in that endeavor better than at others.

If this review sounds like it was written by some octogenarian who sounds like he was forced to watch the latest Marvel movie and discovered that he liked it, THERE'S A REASON. ;)My caveat: I am not a huge hockey fan. In fact, when it comes to most books or tv shows or movies related to any kind of sporty topic, I'm already rounding down or trying to find any kind of excuse to run away from it.Why? I grew up with this s**te. I generally hated the hometown band-together-for-the-team mentality and privately called them all tribal yokels and worse. Let's have an institutionalized us-versus-them mentality, shall we? We can step up our witch hunts and hand out blinders to everyone equally.Sigh.So I read this book about a little hard-nosed hockey town because I was forced to. Truth. Someone held my head in position and kept poking me with a burning branch until I finished enough that I would have to do the rest on my own thanks to my OCD that comes with books. HAVE TO FINISH! So yeah, I did, and you know what? I enjoyed myself. The wide range of characters with all kinds of flaws butted heads against reality in all the worst ways. Good men and women did bad things and bad men and women did good things. There might have been some feels in here for me.But more than anything, this is the kind of book that gives fans and non-fans and everyone who might have the slightest bit ambivalence about the crap that goes on in these kinds of insular communities a good long pause. You can say that shit happens, that rapes happen, that star players can and should get off free and clear. Or, you can be on the shotgun's side. I might be on the shotgun's side.So, yeah, beautifully written, sprawling, a panoramic hoard of vivid characters, and a town torn apart. What's not to love? Issues of rape versus the "greater good" smothers these pages and *should* hit everyone in the gut. So yeah, this isn't just a hockey novel. I'll give it that.:)

Wow. I don't feel good after finishing this. I feel depressed, blue. The writing was excellent the emotional depth completely overwhelming. I don't read books with rape. I don't like to see it used as entertainment. There was nothing here but brutal honesty about all the views. Each person had a different reaction, different reasoning, it was painful to read at times. I finished this book and didn't feel good. I'm glad I read it now, but if I had known what it was about before I picked it up I wouldn't have read it. I read for release, escape, the dream, not a nasty dose of reality like this book went into. I am rating this on my feelings on the book not the writing.Humans can be so cruel. Humans can be such selfish jerks. Humans can reason anything no matter how horrible if it make sit easier on them. Humans justifying rape is WRONG. The mentality of this town is so wrong. Humans will fight dirty to stay in the crowd. Humans can also be kind, unwavering and wonderful but these standouts can be rare in tough times.This book, arguh, emotional roller coaster. I've known all these people at one time in my life. The realistic feel of them makes the punch in the gut more painful. It's all begins to decline with the rape of a 15 year old girl. You know the story, you've herd in on the news on TV shows, the blame game. Mr. Backman takes us to a deeper level and to the outer levels of this traumatic event. How Hockey rules over empathy, over friends, over family in this town and how it goes down, down.

Beartown by Fredrik Backman is the first in this series and for me it went from a 3üåü to a 5 üåü after the slow build up.The beginning almost made me add it to the DNF pile because of the hockey and how much in the town enjoyed it was in every paragraph and was a little much for meüòµ,(and I like watching the Stanley cup and I live in the UK) I then hit a certain point where the build up to THE important game became exciting, Then all of a sudden your hit with a puck between the eyes when the horrendous attack happens.It's a slow burner to begin with then it speeds along which makes it impossible to put down.If you're looking for something a little different about a community With a one track mind, coming of age with plenty of heart break and survival and many secrets and backstabbing then I would definitely recommend this.üìñ

Well. One of the ways I sometimes feel like I might be truly crazy but just don't know it, is when so many readers love a book, give it 5 stars and rave reviews, and I find it awful, deplorable, even possibly dangerous. I purely hated this book. I'll admit the story has a can't-look-away quality to it, so because I read it for my favorite reading group and because it was recommended to the group by a good friend, I got through it. I will just say that over and above the facts that the characters are cliches and the author continuously tells the reader what she should think about every incident, the bottom line is this: a 14-year-old girl is raped by a 16-year-old hockey star and he totally gets away with it. The author curiously did not tell the reader what to think about that.Mansplaining, predatory males, male sports heroes who get away with despicable actions; I know what I think about all that. In light of the recent disclosures about Harvey Weinstein, I cannot and will not recommend this book to anyone. Perhaps I read it wrong, but I don't think so.

I am so stumped about how to review this book but not because I didn't enjoy it. There are so many things I want to say but words fail me. This is the story of a town that wants to adhere to its set ways. The story of the townspeople, who have to accept the roles they are supposed to play, whether it correlates with the way they are or not is immaterial. The story of a game that is seeped into the town culture to such an extent that it is seen as an escape as well as a scourge. This book provides the best example of how review spoilers can damage a story experience. I went into this book assuming that it was a typical sports novel. And I was stunned to see the turn it took. Had I known beforehand about this part of the story, I would have lost out on that thrill of anticipation, the shock of discovery, the pain of uncovering the true faces underneath the external facades.Coming from a tropical country that barely has any winter and knows zilch about ice hockey, I found reading about a place where sub-zero winter is dominant and ice hockey is almost a religious obsession a surreal experience. But no where does the lack of personal know-how affect the book experience. Because the experiences of Beartown, with all its highs and lows, can be transposed to every place and culture regardless of country. The story begins slowly, like a wood fire that is struggling to come to life underneath the dry wood, but once it gets going, the flames are hypnotic, you can feel the heat blazing from every spark, you realise the purpose of every log, you see how the inferno doesn't belong to a particular part of the base but to the whole... Similarly, every single character has a role to play in this book. You might struggle with remembering the huge cast at first but they are so wonderfully described that you'll recognise them soon enough. If any aspiring writer needs a master class on character sketching, this would be a great book to refer to.I'm deliberately staying away from revealing anything about the story because I want you to experience the same thrill of discovery as I did. After all, the title tells you that this book is about Beartown. But the story will reveal that it is equally about its people. About Hockey. Choices. Decisions. Team spirit. Families. Friendships. Silence. Shame. Courage. Gender differences. Social roles. Expectations. Pressures. It's tough to draw a line about what's primary and what secondary in the themes. Everything is interconnected, and everything is essential. What you remember at the end of a book though is not the writing, the characters, the vocabulary... What you remember is how the book made you feel. If a book stays with you long after you have turned over the last page, you will remember it with a nostalgic fondness in spite of flaws. And that's Beartown for me. It has its blemishes, but the positives far outweigh the negatives. This is a book that will stay with me for a long time.Here are some of the nuggets from the plentiful food for thought available in this lovely book. ‚òò Never trust people who don‚Äôt have something in their lives that they love beyond all reason.‚òò How big is the world when you‚Äôre twelve years old? Both infinite and infinitesimal.‚òò There are two things that are particularly good at reminding us how old we are: children and sports.‚òò One of the plainest truths about both towns and individuals is that they usually don‚Äôt turn into what we tell them to be, but what they are told they are.‚òò If you tell a child it can do absolutely anything, or that it can‚Äôt do anything at all, you will in all likelihood be proven right.‚òò Any living thing that is kept behind bars for long enough eventually becomes more scared of the unknown than its own captivity.‚òò Everyone has a thousand wishes before a tragedy, but just one afterward.‚òò Humanity has many shortcomings, but none is stronger than pride.‚òò All adults have days when we feel completely drained. When we no longer know quite what we spend so much time fighting for, when reality and everyday worries overwhelm us and we wonder how much longer we‚Äôre going to be able to carry on. The wonderful thing is that we can all live through far more days like that without breaking than we think. The terrible thing is that we never know exactly how many.‚òò Culture is as much about what we encourage as what we permit.‚òò It‚Äôs always easier to lecture other people about morality when you‚Äôve never had to answer for anything yourself.ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ Sometimes life doesn‚Äôt let you choose your battles. I know next to nothing about ice hockey but for the past week, I played it vicariously with a fearless and dedicated team of adolescent boys in Beartown, a sleepy town at the edge of a forest. As in any sport, one plays to win. But that means sweat and blood ‚Äì an exacting demand of sacrifice from each player. It is hard to imagine the pressure experienced by each member of the Beartown junior team as they compete in the semi-final match of the most anticipated minor-league tournament, the biggest youth tournament in the country. A game such as this carried the hopes and dreams not just of the players but of their parents and in fact, the entire town.Beartown is a hockey town that has lost its shine. Folks who can afford it have moved away to bigger cities and commerce has declined. The people of Beartown pin their hopes on winning because  ‚ÄòBeing the best junior team around would remind the rest of the country of this place‚Äôs existence again.‚Äô The reality for Beartown is: ‚ÄòHockey is becoming more than hockey, it‚Äôs becoming tourism, a trade-mark, capital. Survival.‚Äô I wanted very much for Beartown to hold its head high again.Backman created a troop of incredible young characters ‚Äì Kevin, Benji, Bobo, Amat, Zach, Lyt, Maya, Ana ‚Äì and gave each a backstory that allows the reader to know them quite intimately. Amongst them are youths who live in poverty or have lost a parent, are bullied or ostracized. The one I felt most tenderly for is pint-size Amat, the cleaner‚Äôs son. He is considered too weak even though he is fastest on his skates. He is ‚ÄòTired of trying to prove he was more than the things they called him: a zero from the Hollow.‚Äô I began to root for him and the underdogs. Another hero is Ramona, a widow and owner of a pub. Spunky and straight-talking, she is the unofficial psychologist and to my mind, the conscience of this community.Beartown is about sportsmanship and what it means to be a coach or mentor. Two coaches are pitched against each other: Sune (age 70) versus David (age 32). They have different philosophies that inform their strategies of how to motivate a team. What they have in common is their dedication to hockey and their love for the boys, which I found inspiring.I have to admit that it took me quite a long while to get into this novel. When characters were introduced one by one in quick succession, I grew impatient and wondered if I could keep track of the boys. I also did not appreciate the teenage talk, much of which was unsavoury. Then on the night of the minor league hockey semi-finals, an act of violence shook the whole town and moved the plot into a swifter and more engaging gear. This was when I once again saw Backman‚Äôs perceptive understanding of parenthood, the umbilical cord that cannot be severed. One question that Backman raised is: Can parents protect their children? The parents of Beartown are put to severe testing. An omniscient narrator offers hints of what is to come, and this kept me curious and anxious to keep on reading. Even as the story ends, Beartown meets new challenges. One also catches glimpses of life for these characters ten years into the future. And now I cannot wait to read the two other novels in this series.It‚Äôs been four years since I have read a novel by Fredrik Backman. The marks of an accomplished raconteur are obvious once more. This is a well told story that makes us think about friendship, loyalty, justice, good, and evil. A very satisfying read.
The best book I‚Äôve ever read.The most complex and interesting characters I have ever read.I can‚Äôt begin to fathom how much I loved this book or how much it made me think.

"Culture, Values, Community" is the motto of the Beartown Ice Hockey Club. It's junior team is playing in the semifinal. All the hopes of Beartown are resting on the shoulders of the team. Kevin, Benji, Bobo, Amat and William are five of the twelve team members, ages 13 to 17 years old, who carry the aspirations of Beartown. David, the coach, and Peter, the general manager, are shouldering the responsibility of the hopes and dreams of the whole town. If the junior team wins the semifinal, and then the final, the prospect is jobs, hockey school and increased recognition. But one night of revelry will test the bonds of the club motto. This novel is splendid. It takes off slow with the introduction of several characters. It is written using an omniscient narrator which permits the reader to get closer to the different characters. Competitor or enthusiast, we experience the control, hope, anger, courage, love and pain of the players, staff, sponsors, board, townspeople, parents and siblings. The plot and subplots are so finely written the reader is drawn into the story effortlessly. The setting is a character in itself. The description is so vivid the five senses come alive. Each scene captures the essence of a hockey town. The story contains several stereotypes -- the view of women in career and family, the peer pressure of body image, and the view of a small town. Fredrik Backman has written an outstanding novel. I highly recommend it.

i am not sure how to write a review for this book, because my heart hurts so much. this is the best book of 2021 i have read (and i know it‚Äôs only november and i‚Äôll read more books), but no contest. this book is brilliant and heartwrenching and heartwarming all the same, and i think everyone needs to read it.this is a slow book, so you have to pull through for a bit. backman‚Äôs writing is gorgeous, i knew this from a man called ove, but beartown was a whole other level. it‚Äôs one of those books that you have to push through the first part a bit to be rewarded in the end. he builds a world within this small town through the eyes of more than ten characters, all of different ages and genders and dreams. it doesn‚Äôt pick up until the middle, and then i couldn‚Äôt put it down. this book is so darkly realistic and incredibly uplifting all at the same time.in beartown, their main economy comes from hockey. high school hockey, to be exact. it‚Äôs a tiny, inconsequential town to those who don‚Äôt live there. but they are damn good at hockey and they are given a chance to bring in a lot of buzz and attention when the junior hockey team qualifies for the semi finals. in this town, the teen boys who play hockey are not boys. they‚Äôre celebrities, the most important people in beartown. thus, backman explores toxic masculinity, sports culture, and the consequences of blind idolization.i found myself crying (one of those cathartic cries, not rage cries @ a little life) at so many of the relationships. backman is an expert at writing about people and the connections that make us human; I am not a fan of hockey 
 (please don‚Äôt revoke my Canadian citizenship!)
 however, I did grow up in a hockey town. Our town had only one grocery store, and no mall or movie theatre, but it had a fancy, remodeled ice rink that was nicer than any of the neighbouring towns, by far. The hockey players that attended our high school got good grades simply for playing on the local Junior B team, and they got excused from major papers or assignments if they had a game the night before. We accepted it- that was just the way it was. Everyone went to hockey games and only the popular girls dated the hockey players. When you have a town that prides itself on hockey, and builds its foundation on the game itself, you can understand a story like ‚ÄúBear Town‚Äù.‚ÄùBear Town‚Äù by Frederik Backman is a story about a small town that is built on hockey. The town that should have been deserted and abandoned years ago only stands because of its ice rinks and the talent they bring out. The teenagers who play are faced with pressures greater than they can deal with, all for ‚Äúthe love of the game‚Äù. However, when a young girl is raped and a small-town hockey superstar is accused, Bear Town is torn in two- the side who believe the young girl, and the side who believe that hockey is more important than the truth. This story has a lot of characters- the kids who play on the team of course, as well as the young girl who cries rape and her best friend. Then there‚Äôs the general manager of the team, the coach and all of the former players who still live in the same small town where they rose to hockey stardom. Each character gets a small piece of the plot, with a few getting larger pieces than others. Each one is well-developed and flawed, and a reader can easily identify with at least one, if not more, of the story‚Äôs characters. For a large portion of the beginning of the novel, there is a lot of hockey talk. They don‚Äôt use any of the jargon, so the story is easy to understand, but the general hockey politics and structure of teams is covered in detail. It‚Äôs a little rough to get through this part, but once ‚Äúthe incident‚Äù happens- the story takes off like a shot. ‚ÄúBear Town‚Äù quickly becomes addicting and suspense-fueled, and I read rapidly through its pages, desperate to know how it all turns out. (The ending is extremely realistic but also uplifting and powerful). Backman is known for his powerful novels and this is no exception. ‚ÄúBear Town‚Äù will particularly speak to hockey fans, but anyone who understands the politics of small towns or even the dynamic of small town sports teams will identify with this story.

Humanity has many shortcomings, but none is stronger than pride.

 Holy sobfest! WHAT. A. BOOK.Of the 200+ books I'll read this year, I'll be able to count on one hand those that fall outside of the romance genre - and I'm so happy that Beartown is among them!WOW, JUST WOW. Its depth and emotion swept me up and made a good attempt to drown me in my own tears, but I wouldn't change having read it for anything. This is one of those books that every reader on the planet should experience.It started out SLOW . . . Hockey, zzzzzz. Small town minutiae, zzzzz. Mostly unlikable characters, zzzzz. No chance of romance, zzzzz. Why was I reading this again? Oh yeah, because I had to put my name on a waiting list of 59 people at my library to get my hands on it. Plus, two of my most-trusted friends here on GR raved about it. There had to be something worthwhile in this book, right?Damn right.By about 15% my interest was holding . . . those unlikable characters and their everyday lives began to worm their way under my skin. And the hockey was just a structure on which the author carefully laid the groundwork for what he had to say. 

Leadership is as much about what you don't say as what you do say.

 And holy shit, you guys, this author had a ton to say. By giving us a cross-section of the inhabitants of this small Swedish town - young and old, male and female, rich and poor - who are polarized by a tragic event, Backman delved into humanity and its weaknesses and strengths. 

Hate can be a deeply stimulating emotion. The world becomes much easier to understand and much less terrifying if you divide everything and everyone into friends and enemies, we and they, good and evil. The easiest way to unite a group isn't through love, because love is hard. It makes demands. Hate is simple.

 It may sound like the author is being preachy, but I'd disagree. He takes the reader inside the minds of so many unique voices - including the victim and the perpetrator - and presents such a crystal clear picture of their motivations, triggers, and reasoning that I was left in awe. 

We become what we are told we are.

 To say the least, I'm glad that I stuck with it. Showcasing both the best and worst of humanity, Beartown is one of the best books I'll read in my lifetime. Obviously, I recommend!! :-)

4.5 stars rounded up because, yes, I cried. Beartown is not normally something I‚Äôd pick up. It‚Äôs a contemporary about ice hockey in a small town community, which I know nothing about, but this still somehow managed to break me apart and completely grip me heart and soul. I ended up caring so much for these characters and their lives that I felt every blow and every emotion with them - from rage, grief, despair and deep rooted love. Love for family, for hockey, and for a community isolated and desperate to keep up with the big cities. Backman‚Äôs writing is wonderful. So many times I went back and reread sentences because he managed to convey so much in a single sentence. Nothing is hidden either. We know the outcome of the story right from the opening sentence, but it‚Äôs the process of how we get there that packs the emotional punch. The plot itself is slow, (hence the no 5 stars) but it needs to be. For the first 150 pages we get an intense character study on the inhabitants of Beartown. We know what makes everyone tick, what are their darkest secrets and worst memories, and that makes the reader really deeply care for them and their stories. Everyone knows everyone‚Äôs business, they‚Äôve all played hockey together and shared in each other‚Äôs biggest life moments, and that‚Äôs what makes the heart of the story so shocking and believable. To believe one person over another, to see someone as a commodity and a lifeline, which gives them a ‚Äòfree pass‚Äô on life. It throws up so many important conversations and thoughts on human nature, it was incredible to read.Looking at the characters in more detail, we have the star hockey youth Kevin - the guy who has never been taught what it‚Äôs like to loose, always seeking perfection because that‚Äôs how life should be. He‚Äôs the guy who‚Äôs going to turn around the fortunes of Beartown‚Äôs hockey league, and bring in commerce and revenue to the town. Everyone has their hopes pinned on him. He can do no wrong, he has best friend Benji, a guy determined to ruin his own life by any means possible, watching his back. We also have Amat, the tender 15 year old who just wants to have a better life for him and his mother, the ice rink cleaner, by becoming the best. He idolises Kevin, and all his dreams come true when he‚Äôs asked to play in the youth semi finals game alongside him. And then there‚Äôs General Manager Peter and his family. A former hockey player himself, he‚Äôs determined the raise the club to new heights, and his passion for hockey brings his family into the world too. Something he‚Äôll live to regret. The love that each of these characters has for another is a running theme throughout the book, one that shows the power and strength love can give but also one that can be used to manipulate and abuse those who love us in return. An exceptional piece of work.

‚ÄúAnd when enough people are quiet for long enough, a handful of voices can give the impression that everyone is screaming.‚ÄùFredrik Backman is an author I turn to when I am looking for a boost. His books: A Man Called Ove, Anxious People, Your Grandmother Asked Me to Tell You She‚Äôs Sorry, and Brit-Marie are filled with quirky yet likable characters, humor, and humanism. His lively writing style and insight into the human condition help me to laugh at life. In Beartown, Backman shifts gears and focuses on the ugly side of human nature. At times it is a painful read.Beartown is a small town in northern Sweden facing economic decline. It is a hockey town, and the powers that be determine that hockey is the key to its revival. If Beartown‚Äôs high school hockey team wins the finals, they believe that the town will become the site of a hockey school, which could spark new development in the area.Backman is adept at creating the ambiance of a small town enthralled with hockey. With a sardonic eye, he introduces the townspeople, the team manager, the coaches, the players, the parents, and their history with hockey. The story builds to the first playoff where Beartown wins. Full to the brim with emotion, a beautiful book. My first by Fredrik Backman but certainly not my last. This isn't my usual go-to genre but this just caught my eye. I am so pleased I gave it a chance! Sometimes after a lot of thrillers, you need something in between or even alongside just to change the subject completely and wipe the slate clean a little. This book achieved it superbly. I'm thoroughly chuffed I decided to read this novel and I hope others do too. I have heard that this is a departure from Backman's usual topics but I would still love to give his other books a go, an author like this doesn't come around every day. They are already on my TBR list. I know that i've heard of a Man Called Ove before I discovered this book and I understand that it received very good reviews from critics - this will be my next read of his. I didn't expect to enjoy this as much as I did - for one, it's a book that revolves around Hockey and sport is not something that gets my attention at the best of times. Unless it is Tennis, of course. I would also like to note that I have the ARC version of this book entitled - The Scandal - the name it is known under in Canada and the United Kingdom. It is most commonly known as Beartown.Beartown is a snow-covered small-town in Sweden that emanstes with the kind of dark and cold that brings townsfolk together forming a tight knit rural community on the edge of civilisation. The isolation of the community means that they usually either come together - showing that anything is achievable when everyone supports one another or the polar opposite - where the people don't get closer but are pulled apart from one another instead. If they can all just pull together Beartown is on the edge of a revival, a bright new future is up ahead just for them. All of this hope for the future is then put in jeopardy by one brutal act. It divides the town into those who want the act to be kept quiet and never mentioned again and those who feel that they just can't stand by and let that happen. There are those who will risk their future in order to see justice done. It then falls to one young man to speak the truth that no one else wants to hear and find the courage to not just stay silent along with most of the rest. It's time for people to pick a side - you are either or one side or the other. Which side would you be on?You will be surprised how well a book about a Hockeytown actually makes you think about lifes big questions. Right vs wrong, morality, issues of individual loyalty. There are so many ideas in this book that lead you to think about everything in your own life. The characters are admirable and the storytelling masterful. Backman very cleverly lulls you into a false sense of security - you think you are reading something lighthearted or a pretty standard novel but quite soon you establish that his writing gift has made you think a lot more than you had realised! It takes a great author to pull this off.I would like to thank Fredrik Backman, Penguin (UK) - Michael Joseph & NetGalley for an ARC of this book in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

God. Damn.That‚Äôs how I felt, and maybe what I said out loud, as I finished Beartown. I wrote Backman off after Ove, gave him another shot and loved Anxious People, and when this one was recommended to me, I didn‚Äôt waste any time getting to it. Like Anxious People, this is a book about hockey, but it‚Äôs ultimately not about hockey. I didn‚Äôt bother reading much of the plot, so I thought it was mostly about hockey in a small town. I‚Äôm not a hockey fan at all. I‚Äôm much more into basketball and soccer these days, but you don‚Äôt have to love or know a damn thing about hockey to read Beartown. A lot more is going on here that I was not expecting. And it‚Äôs heavy, man. This book will smash you into pieces, attempt to glue you back together again, and then check you right into the boards over and over again. It‚Äôs a pretty long, sad, depressing ride, but it was all worth it in the end. Backman‚Äôs character development shines in this book, too. Everyone gets their air time, and even those most minor of characters gets their fifteen minutes of fame somewhere in the pages. The chapters bounce quickly between different storylines, characters, and/or perspectives, and that keeps you locked in the whole time. I found myself flying through the book, thinking about it when I wasn‚Äôt reading it, and taking every opportunity I could to sneak in a few more pages. I actually almost finished it on an airplane, and I was bummed that I had to get off the plane with about 15 pages left. I‚Äôll be thinking about Beartown for a long time. The town and its inhabitants are still bouncing around in my brain. It all feels so real and alive, like I was there for a week with all of the team, parents, and coaches. And I guess I‚Äôm gonna go back and visit them again soon. I feel like I need something a little lighter for now, something more comedic and fun, but I‚Äôll be back in Beartown again very soon. I‚Äôll read Us Against You, and then probably anything else by Backman. I love the way he tells a story, steps away to give you a few quotable lines, makes you think about life differently, goes back to the story, rips your heart out, puts it back in. I‚Äôm all in for all of that stuff.

"There are few words that are harder to explain than 'loyalty.' It's always regarded as a positive characteristic, because a lot of people would say that many of the best things people do for each other occur precisely because of loyalty. The only problem is that many of the very worst things we do to each other occur because of the same thing."What a book! Everyone has been urging me to read Backman, but his books never really caught my attention...until now. Although a podcast practically revealed most of the major plot elements, I decided to read it anyway because this time I wanted to be able to discuss the summer book of 2017. And that's exactly what it is! Backman introduces us to a cast of characters from a small backwoods town in Sweden. The only thing going for this town, which is practically on the brink of extinction, is the local hockey club. From birth young boys are trained in the sport, and told to give it their all. To say that Beartown is enthusiastic about hockey is an understatment; it's the only thing they know how to do. When a tragedy threatens to divide the town, it's also an opportunity for people to show their true colors.I really enjoyed even the difficult parts of this book! Unlikely people become unsung heroes, and the town if full of bristly but loveable characters, which I'm told is a hallmark of Backman's work. Highly recommend, although you really don't need to read too many reviews before picking up a copy. Most will divulge key points that it's better to discover on your own. I will definitely be reading more of his work, probably in reverse order, too!

It‚Äôs an intense story where friendships are tested, loyalties are tested ‚Ä¶parents‚Äô love for their kids are tested. Every incident is told and viewed from multiple angles. What‚Äôs right ?What‚Äôs wrong? It‚Äôs not that easy.I don‚Äôt want to talk about the plot much. Just know that there is a town in the middle of nowhere and there is a Junior‚Äôs hockey team. And Hockey is really‚Ä¶ really ‚Ä¶really important for everyone there.That‚Äô s it . well, not exactly‚Ä¶lot more in store.:)   Powerful story. Lots of diversity. I wish I could love it more but for me it was just a good enough read.

After languishing on my TBR pile for way, way too long I made a point to start catching up on all of Backman's back titles. I listened to the audio book of this one, and honestly, Marin Ireland is just superb and has an incredible way of narrating Backman's books that really connects with the story.I also did what I never do, which was watch the TV series of Beartown before reading the book. I can honestly say that other than making a few small changes, the series truly captured every meaningful part of this story. The series helped me see the mob mentality, the way that sports culture and its protective insular sheltering keep certain people from being held accountable for their actions. The book gave me insight into the characters and most of their thinking and motivation behind their actions. I definitely got more of a sense of the characters from the book than I did on the screen.Overall though, Backman's phrasing and way of writing totally connects with me and there is so much beauty and love among the broken people. Beartown is, it its core, a story of love. Friendship. Family. I never thought I would like a book about hockey, and that's part of the reason why I put off reading it for as long as I did. I have been to maybe two hockey games in my life and am not even sure about the rules. Yet this book has so many universal themes that I encourage reluctant readers to move past the hockey because this is about more than that. I'm moving on to the next book in the series to see how things continue and am interested to see that there's a third book slated for later this year.

I liked this, but didn't love it. I enjoyed the 'life lessons', but by half way through these 'lessons' felt way too repetitive. The format and number of characters, also, made it a bit confusing at times. Overall, though, I really did enjoy the actual story... just wish the delivery had been better. 4 stars.
3.5 stars

There are damn few things in life that are harder than admitting to yourself that you're a hypocriteBeartown is a book about a town obsessed with ice hockey. The town doesn't really have anything else than ice hockey to talk about. Beartown has had a star hockey player, and is about to have one more in the near future. Thus in the initial chapters of the book, this will literally feel like a book based on sports without any much story apart from it.That's only till the semifinal match. Once the semis are won by the junior hockey team of Beartown, the story takes a turn and gets really interesting.Sexual abuse is not an easy topic to write a story about. But Backman handles it very well. Obviously the accusser is none other than the star player, thus the town is blind and eventually sees him as a victim. Well why won't they be blind, after all he's the star player of the town. He is the one who is about to turn around the fortune of the poor town.I feel bad for the victim, as she is treated as the accusser by the entire town. After being harassed sexually, she is harassed physically too by her school-mates. However she is not a coward. She takes on each challenge courageously, and is sometimes the one handling the sadness of her parents.Till the end, the town doesn't believes her. But once the exact description of the event is announced to the entire town by an alibi just before votings are done to kick-out the girl's father from the mangement of the hockey team, then the town silently supports her family. But the accusser's family is rich, and rich people find some way to save their ass. Talking about what I like about the book:- Mr. Backman, your writing is just amazing.- The character build up was just amazing. Not just Kevin, Maya, Benji, Amat or their family, but other characters like Jeanette, Ramona, Anna, Tails, Lyt, etc too had a justified ending.- Even though the ending wasn't on a happy note for the victim, the story was a complete one with a justified ending. The rich do get out of everything with money.- The accusser wasn't punished by the law, but the victim found a way to punish him so that he never regrets what he has done. Eager to read part 2 of the series.

In a town, in a room, on a computer.....Finally, two years later, I got my closure.When I put Beartown down the first time in 2017, my heart just couldn't take it anymore. Now, years later I finally had the courage to finish it.This book was hard for me.The author has a way with words, and the way he portrait the good but also the bad in human nature - broke my heart. I never want to read books that picture how horrible we humans can be towards each other. Seeing it in the news is all I can bare - I don't usually want to read about it as well. But I wanted to read Us Against You and I felt like I had to finish Beartown first.I've loved this author's writing for years now, especially after OVE and¬†My Grandmother Asked Me to Tell You She‚Äôs Sorry¬†I was hooked, but nothing could have prepared me for the onslaught of feelings this book brought forth.This story is one that will make you believe in mankind and also hate it. It will make you think, feel and tear up. It truly put me through the wringer. There was a reason why I didn't finish the book the first time around. But the beautiful writing, the underlying message and the ever present glimpse of hope was worth it in the end.I still stand to my rating from 2017, even though the book was beautifully written, the topic was just too raw for me. I didn't really enjoy it as much as I hoped, even if I couldn't put it down the second time around. The story was just too dark and heart-breaking for me.But there is a reason why readers love this book. And I would certainly recommend it to anyone who loves to read beautiful and meaningful fiction, and who has a thicker skin than I do. Because, please be aware that for a big part this book is about today's rape culture and its repercussion.___________________________________Find more reviews and book recommendations on my blog.Find me on Bookstagram.

Beartown is gradually beginning to vanish. Its not just the dense woods thats surround the town that make it so. Still there is one thing that keeps Beartown alive and that is hockey. The junior hockey team made it all the way to the championship semi-finals and they actually have a chance. Everyone, from the coaches to the locals, are putting all their faith on the team. When struck by a quite lamentable event, the town pick sides and begins to grow apart. Its about hockey and so much more.Fredrik Backman is not a one trick pony! For those familiar with his work, you will not find the likes of Ove, Granny or Britt-Marie on these pages. The wit and humour that usually characterize his prose are absent here. What you will find, however, is the same skill (of Backman) to construct characters that stay with you long after you turn the last page. Beartown is primarily about hockey but it would be a big mistake to assume that its just about the sport. One does not have to like hockey to enjoy this book (personally I like soccer but the overall sentiment is the same). Being of a more serious and solemn tone, this novel is powerful and poignant. Dealing with loyalty, courage and a deep sense of both, wanting and to belong this novel explores the human spirit and its limits. Experiencing a heartfelt elation to a deep anger, this book was an emotional ride. The gamut of emotions that Backman exposes the reader to is certainly wide, this is his true trademark. I was rooting for (most) of these characters on and off the ice, particularly Sune and Amat. What else can I say? I love this author and can not wait for his next book. Highly recommended.

This is a book about a hockey town. But, it could be about any college town that revolves around a sport and has different rules for its stars. Club FirstAt any cost?Not the heart warming story you have come to expect from Fredrick Backman..but each chapter seemed to start with a ‚Äúspot on‚Äù description of life or love, as the town tries to make sense of the thing that has happened that is tearing it apart..It took awhile for the story to get going..at least half of the book before the pace picked up for me...but I definitely felt the ‚Äúchill‚Äù of the weather and of the residents who lived in Beartown, a town divided....
I'm so so glad i picked up this book, its beautifully written, utterly captivating and heart-wrenching.

‚ÄúEveryone has a thousand wishes before a tragedy, but just one afterward."Well holy shit, I was not expecting to love this book as much as I did. This is my first book from Fredrick Bachman, and it certainly won't be my last. This is an incredibly powerful story about a small town in Sweden called "Beartown" and this town thinks hockey is the most important thing in the world. This is a story about family and community and love, but also heartache and tragedy, and I'm just blown away by how deep this book got. There are trigger warnings for: rape which I wasn't really expecting from a book like this. This book is extremely feminist and has so many amazing feminist messages and quotes throughout this book. It also talks a lot about how the world always blames the victim in a terrible situation. Those messages in this book were so powerful for me, I loved it. ‚ÄúWhat an uncomfortable, terrible source of shame it is for the world that the victim is so often the one left with the most empathy for others.‚Äù It was just so important and amazing to see the feminism in this book, especially with Kiera and her job as a lawyer, and how she felt like she could never be "one of the guys" at her job because she is a Mother, and yet people expect her to be exceptional at both. I also love how it said in this town girls can't like hockey because "if they like the game they're a lesbian and if they like the players they're a slut." I'm a huge fan of hockey and I'm a girl so I completely agree that girls should be allowed to love hockey and not be judged for it, or be called a slut or a lesbian for it. I loved all the quotes about motherhood, and anxiety and the psychology behind it, it was all very thought provoking. ‚ÄúShe is told all the things she shouldn‚Äôt have done: She shouldn‚Äôt have waited so long before going to the police. She shouldn‚Äôt have gotten rid of the clothes she was wearing. Shouldn‚Äôt have showered. Shouldn‚Äôt have drunk alcohol. Shouldn‚Äôt have put herself in that situation. Shouldn‚Äôt have gone into the room, up the stairs, given him the impression. If only she hadn‚Äôt existed, then none of this would have happened, why didn‚Äôt she think of that?‚ÄùThis book also has this overall moral question of: how far would you go to protect your child? which is always a very interesting thing to read about. When parents of a rapist are put into question about what they know and who they raised... It's all very intense and heart breaking. ‚ÄúAll adults have days when we feel completely drained. When we no longer know quite what we spend so much time fighting for, when reality and everyday worries overwhelm us and we wonder how much longer we‚Äôre going to be able to carry on. The wonderful thing is that we can all live through far more days like that without breaking than we think. The terrible thing is that we never know exactly how many.‚Äù I adore Kiera and Peter's relationship, her being a lawyer and a Mother and him being the coach of the hockey team. I enjoyed the way they talked about marriage and bickered back and forth, but you could tell they really loved each other. Their scenes definitely made me cry a few times whenever they mentioned their daughter that died as a baby of heart disease. ‚ÄúHate can be a deeply stimulating emotion. The world becomes easier to understand and much less terrifying if you divide everything and everyone into friends and enemies, we and they, good and evil. The easiest way to unite a group isn't through love, because love is hard, It makes demands. Hate is simple. So the first thing that happens in a conflict is that we choose a side, because that's easier than trying to hold two thoughts in our heads at the same time. The second thing that happens is that we seek out facts that confirm what we want to believe - comforting facts, ones that permit life to go on as normal. The third is that we dehumanize our enemy.‚ÄùThis book is gorgeously written, and very thought provoking and starts a very important conversation in regard to feminism and rape culture. I really enjoyed this book and I think it's something everyone should read. (Also I highly recommend listening to the audiobook - it's fantastic!)

This is my fourth book by Fredrik Backman, and I am happy to report it lived up to my high expectations. Though, as is typical with his books, I was initially skeptical I would like it. The book, on its surface, appears to be about a hockey-obsessed little town, and frankly few things interest me less than hockey. I should have known that nothing is quite as it first seems in a Backman novel. Beartown is about hockey, yes, but it's really about community, friendship, family, betrayal, love, disappointment, and so much more. His novels are all vastly multi-dimensional and typically more than a little melancholy, but they also feel very real. They are essentially about normal people and their troubles which can feel so huge and seem so insurmountable, even if, from the outside, they don't appear that big a deal. Backman has a way of exploring what lies beneath the surface of people from all walks of life. Nothing in his books is ever black and white. They are not the easiest reads, because they force you to think and maybe even challenge opinions you once held as given. The cast of characters in Beartown is large, but vivid and beautifully developed. The setting is at times bleak, but chillingly atmospheric. The story moves slowly, then startles with a jolting event, and the tempo changes almost with the quality of a song. Everything in Backman's books seems intentional and well thought out, and at the same time completely inevitable. Big events happen, shocking and troubling, and still they didn't feel forced or overly dramatic. This book, in particular, feels very timely in light of the many emerging stories of sexual assault, though I suppose it always, sadly, was a timely issue. It considers the shame forced on victims of assault, and the horrible reality that they are so often doubted when they find the courage to speak.Backman's are the types of stories that linger with you, or at least with me, long after I have read them. There aren't that many books that leave a lasting impression when you read well over 100 books a year, so this is saying something.If I haven't made it clear enough by now, and you re still reading, I really, truly, very much recommend Fredrik Backman's books, Beartown and the others, too.Find more reviews and bookish fun at http://www.princessandpen.com

A stand alone book by Fredrik Backman published 2016This was yet another 5 star mesmerising book from the pen of Fredrik Backman.Beartown, like so many other small towns all over the world, is hanging on by its finger nails for survival. As businesses leave for greener pasture the population diminishes. There is next to nothing that locals can take pride in except, that is, the local Junior Ice Hockey team. By some miraculous occurrence the junior team has a couple of exceptional players and with them as the flag bearers the team has made it to the national finals. Suddenly the populous have straighter backs and there‚Äôs a buzz around the town that‚Äôs been missing for years. To win the national finals would give the town a lot more than just pride. Sponsors would want to invest in the team, everybody loves a winner. Businesses would be coming to Beartown rather than leaving it. People can see money everywhere so the pressure on the boys to succeed is enormous. Beartown has come alive, people have their tails up and God is in his heaven shinning his benevolence down on them.That was until the 15 year old daughter of the teams‚Äô general manager accuses one of the superstars of raping her. All hell breaks loose. How dare this spoiled little vixen burst their bubble?This revelation will turn the honest, hard working locals of Beartown into a vicious, vindictive pack. 75% of the locals just want the problem to go away, she‚Äôs young and she‚Äôll get over it, and anyway there‚Äôs a game to be won. The other 25%, if not vengeance, what they want, at the very least, is justice. The emotional trauma that the young girl at the centre of all this hatred goes through will have you wanting to step into the pages and rough up a few of the fine upstanding locals.This is a fantastic, emotional rollercoaster of a ride and I can‚Äôt recommend it highly enough

I don't enjoy sports...don't like to watch sports on TV or in person. I certainly don't want to read about sports. But oh boy, was this book about hockey good! I've never read Backman before but I'm on a mission to read all of his other books. 5 well deserved stars!

It took me thirty pages of this book to know it was going to be a new favourite and one of the best books I read in 2020.I was anxious before reading this book because I knew it had a lot to do with ice hockey and I know absolutely nothing about that. But don‚Äôt worry. After the first few pages you understand why ice hockey is so important to the town and you‚Äôll probably end up caring about the sport as much as I did when reading.Backman is the master of writing such realistic characters. He balances so many of them, but each one is fully fleshed out and so believable I wouldn‚Äôt do a double take if I met them on the street. We get to see what each person is passionate about, what drives them and therefore can‚Äôt help understanding them.The small town setting was done incredibly well. Everyone knows everyone, and everyone gets caught up in what the town finds important at the time. And it is set in the middle of winter in an ice hockey town. The setting is so seamlessly woven into the story that I couldn‚Äôt help but shiver while reading.In terms of the sports, it really did talk about the positives and the negatives of sports culture. A team is truly a found family, and you get that feeling from reading this one. But it also shows how just like in families, there can be problems and secrets and fractured moments too. It also talked about how in the sports industry you dedicate your life to the sport and it becomes you all ‚Äì sometimes eclipsing other things you should care about in life too. It becomes your escape, your future, your career‚Ä¶ so much that you don‚Äôt know what to do without it. That can be a beautiful thing, but it can be dangerous too.It also talks about the toxicity in sports culture too. And there is a lot of that. What happens to those disregard, injured, pushed too hard too soon as young players, seeing people as products, players granted too much free reign in life so they don‚Äôt learn discipline and respect, overlooking problematic behaviour, feminism in sports, LGBT+ rights in sports, race in sports‚Ä¶ it almost feels impossible to think a book can have a time to touch on all of those themes and do it well, but the book truly does.The relationships in this book were so important. The motherhood feels and discussions with Kira were some I appreciated so much. I loved seeing Ana and Maya, and the exploration of how friendships change and morph as you grow older. Amat and Zaccharias‚Äô characters also reflected that, but in a different way. Kevin and Benji too, although that friendship relationship got even more complex for several reasons. And then last but not least, Amat and Bobo as well. Bobo‚Äôs development over the course of the novel was my favourite thing. In fact, let me take a moment to mention my favourite characters: Benji, Bobo and Amat in that order. Oh, and I adored Leo so much too.And there can be no ignoring the main focus of this novel. I know some people find the main theme to be a spoiler, even though I think it shouldn‚Äôt be. I have it in my content warnings in this original version of the review (goodreads click link below to go to blog review) if you want to know ahead of time. What I love about how this novel is written is that it shows the escalation of the issue. How it starts with comments and jokes and becomes more. How the ignorance of the truth, the simplifying, the dehumanisation, the choosing of sides, how the victim is treated‚Ä¶ all of that adds up. The disparaging difference between how both sides were treated underlines the issues with how this topic gets handled and approached today. I liked the small details such as a particular point of view vanishing once it was no longer deserved, and how the novel no longer focused on them. When reading this, I felt sadness, anger, frustration, shame and everything else. It was an emotional onslaught all the way through and I couldn‚Äôt take a breath until I finished the book. But there was hope in the novel too, strangely, which I didn‚Äôt expect. And appreciated.I am always one to love imagery or repetition in novels ‚Äì I think it can be such a powerful literary device. In this novel there is the repetition of silence. But there are some characters who understand the silence and others who don‚Äôt ‚Äì and whether they do or don‚Äôt is very telling of their character.All in all, this is the kind of book that shows you everything beautiful ‚Äì flawed but beautiful ‚Äì and rips it all away to reveal the truth. Read it now.This review and others can originally be found on Olivia's Catastrophe: https://oliviascatastrophe.com/2021/0...

5.0 StarsExtraordinary! Outstanding! Magnificent! One of the best books I've read in a very long time.When I finished Beartown, I paused to reflect, took in a deep inhalation that rushed over my lips and tongue, flowing all the way into the depths at the very bottom of my lungs, filling every cell of my body with the living, breathing, emotional river that rushes out of these pages. I blink away the moisture that puddles in my eyes, sniff back the tears that escape into nasal passages and slide down the back of my throat. I‚Äôm quieted in contemplation, enveloped in the humming vibration of feelings. It feels really good!While the story revolves around the Beartown Ice Hockey Club, the only thing left to cheer for in the small town nestled in the forest, suffering steady economic decline, no knowledge of hockey is necessary to understand and FEEL this book. This book is alive, a full range of human emotions on display and converted into the full force of electric, mesmerizing kinetic energy emanating from each and every page.Winning the championship game would put Beartown on the map; a new hockey academy and rebounding economic prosperity. After the semifinal win, Beartown in jubilant! But the post-game activities of the junior team, inspired by alcohol and male bravado fostered by the coaching staff, spills out of the hockey culture bubble, escaping into the real world of politics, class and social upheaval. Everyone in Beartown is influenced; even those with no interest in the game. Everyone is tangentially connected to hockey simply by their presence in Beartown. It‚Äôs his word against hers. Neighbors and friends take sides; parents prepare for battle. Relationships are tested and challenged. Best friendships are disintegrated and reassembled in completely different forms, some for better, some for much worse. Mothers and fathers discover new, more passionate ways to love their children, to defend them.As news spreads across Beartown, best friends bond more tightly and grow stronger; others splinter like shattered glass. Closely held secrets and long held beliefs and assumptions are exposed and confronted, often times validated with a selective accumulation of facts. Culture, Values and Community, the motto of the Beartown Ice Hockey Club, is vague enough to have meaning for everyone and anyone but specific enough to inspire long time members to question the very existence of the team.‚Äú‚Ä¶the club had an unpleasant culture of silence,‚Äù Kira once told him. ‚ÄúThe sort of thing you find among soldiers and criminals.‚ÄùBackman‚Äôs writing style and delivery is astounding, adeptly and skillfully exploring friendship and loyalty when they smash head on with morality, right and wrong, good and evil. Love in Beartown can be tough and unyielding and in the end, the unyielding love and extraordinary strength of a fifteen year old girl saves her parents along with many of the adults in Beartown from misery and despair, loneliness and bitterness, hatred and jealousy.  At book‚Äôs end, my only disappointment was the very last page meant I was forced to say good-bye to all the people of Beartown. I‚Äôll miss you the most Maya Anderssen. You are a remarkbale human being. Benji Ovich, you are stronger than you can ever imagine. Amat, you are an angel! ‚ÄúCherry trees always smell of cherry trees." Stop what you are doing right now and read Beartown!

Small towns are not like big cities. If you have ever lived in one, you know that while you can hide in a big city and be anonymous, that is not going to be very easy in a small town. On the flip side, you are a part of something in a small town and you share something with every other inhabitant, for good or bad that town is you and you are that town. Some people want to escape and others want to never leave, but there are limited ways out and never leaving can mean withering on the vine.The small town that is Beartown, Sweden is a hockey town. They have built their lives around hockey. Anything that threatens the hockey club threatens the town itself, again for good or for bad, for it is the center around which everything else orbits. So, introduce a moral dilemma, you must do what is right or you must do what is right for the club, which is to say the town. If you go against the club, you go against the money, the power, the prestige and the economic base, and the world as you know it might just collapse on your head. I was not enthralled by this book for the first third. It was too much about teenagers and teenage problems. It was too much about sports which are of little or no interest to me, and hockey which I confess to not even truly understand. But it was flowing easily along and I could drift with it pretty effortlessly. Then an event takes place that sets everything on its ears, and I reversed my view of the book almost immediately. It became about something much more meaningful, much more universal, and something that can affect anyone regardless of age.My hat is off to Backman for creating both realistic characters, realistic situations, and realistic reactions. I wanted to scream at some of these people, but then I want to scream at a lot of people in real life. I wanted to soothe and cuddle others and, again, we know those people who just seem to need a pat on the back or a word of encouragement and don‚Äôt ever get it.I have A Man Called Ove on my physical TBR shelf. It just moved up the ladder.

Every time I try to write my review for this incredible book, I write four plus pages; that's unacceptable. Backman writes about us, people, parents, kids, in a struggling town anywhere in the world. The location doesn't matter really. Everyone is trying to live everyday as best as they can, provide for their families maybe a little better than they had it during their childhood. You'll recognize yourself and your neighbors. The town's identity is its sport, in this case hockey, but it could be any sport. It encompasses everyone's life. Some kids are better than others, all are taught that the TEAM comes before anything or anyone. The team includes kids from all over town, some privileged, some poor, mixed ethnicities, all encompassing.However, an incident occurs that will test everyone's loyalties. People will take sides. The characters are so complex, so deep, so incredible. There are at least ten quotes I could place here. How could Fredrik Backman be so knowledgeable about people, especially teenagers. The primary refrain throughout is, "we can't protect our children." That is very true, we think we can, but we can't. All we can do is teach them right from wrong. They grow up and we can't be with them all the time, they'll have to make their own decisions. So profound for our world right now. Please read this book, it will matter, to all of us.Oh my goodness!!! I have no words to explain the wonder of this book. This book is very different from Backman's previous books. Amazing. An additional 5 stars to Backman's translator; you are the best on the planet. Congratulations. Bravo.Thank you Netgalley, Atria Books, and Simon and Schuster.

I loved this book about a small town whose main driving factor is hockey."It's only a game. Everyone who plays it gets told that from time to time. A lot of people try to tell themselves that it's true But it's complete nonsense. No one in this town would have been the same if that game hadn't existed."Hockey is so important to the town of Beartown, that when one of its elite players does something so egregious, the town is torn apart. We know from the description that something bad occurs. I kept reading with a feeling of dread, waiting for the "event" and the fall out. When it occurred and the reaction it elicited from the whole town was so emotionally devastating.The author captures the players, the parents, the coaches and some of the townspeople who are impacted by this game of hockey. Backman knows how to create unique characters-flawed, quirky, believable people!He brings the world of hockey to life- the fanatical parents; the politics surrounding hockey; the driving force in these young players; the win at all cost attitude.Loyalty means a lot to team players- are you to remain loyal at all costs? Is being part of a team more important than being honest and moral? The ending was strong- it totally satisfied me. I was mesmerized by this book. Bravo to the author!My thanks to Netgalley and Simon and Schuster and the author Fredrik Backman for the privilege of reading this book in exchange for an honest review.

I find it very difficult to rate this book as it was like a wrestling match for me. I loved it and I didn't like it at all. A few times during the first 100 pages I wanted to stop and find something better to read. I couldn't get past the 1 star then. How much hockey can someone who doesn't like sports much, take? But the build-up of the story had me hooked so I needed to read on. And on... and on.... It was so drawn out that my rating plummeted back down again. But I read on till the end and I thought this book was as fantastic as it was horrible. So there you go, I've chosen for 5 stars but don't ask me why exactly.

"Community is the fact that we work toward the same goal, that we accept our respective roles in order to reach it. Values is the fact that we trust each other. That we love each other. David thought about that for a long while before asking: What about culture then? Sune looked more serious, choosing his words carefully. In the end he said: For me, culture is a much about what we encourage as what we actually permit. David asked what he meant by that, and Sune replied: That most people don't do what we tell them to. They do what we let them get away with." (210) "Hate can be a deeply stimulating emotion. The world becomes much easier to understand and much less terrifying if you divide everything and everyone into friends and enemies, we and they, good and evil. The easiest way to unite a group isn't through love, because love is hard. It makes demands. Hate is simple. So the first thing that happens in a conflict is that we choose a side, because that's easier than trying to hold two thoughts in our heads at the same time. The second thing that happens is that we seek out facts that confirm what we want to believe- comforting facts, ones that permit life to go on as normal. The third is that we dehumanise our enemy. There are many ways of doing that, but none is easier than taking her name away from her" (273)Simply put, Beartown is a phenomenal work of art. Its focus is timely, its cast of characters brilliant, and the book's overall story is hauntingly memorable. This was my first book by Fredrik Backman, and now I'm eagerly curious to see if his other works match up to this literary gem. When the book starts, we catch glimpses of hope from the tiny community of Beartown and its inhabitants as they stake their future on the success of their local youth hockey team. Hockey is everything to this town, as it symbolizes the one glimmer of hope and escape from a community facing harsh economic stagnation and even harsher bitter cold. As the team pushes forward and the community rallies around them, a horrifying turn of fate presents itself that threatens to divide and enrage Beartown, challenging the prospects of hope it so desperately is fighting for.As stated, Beartown has an outstanding cast. Every character feels fleshed out and important to the story and to Beartown itself. That is the central pillar to Beartown making it stand tall and proud among contemporary literary works. I enjoyed discovering what made each one of the characters tick. There's Peter and Kira, the pound parents who fight to give their children love, opportunity and protection. There's Bobo, a loveable giant who's appearance doesn't match his innocent nature. There's Amat, a refugee from a war-torn country he never knew fighting for a place on the hockey team and in Beartown itself. There's Ramona, the local fiery barkeep and a dozen others with interesting backstories. My personal favourite was Benji though, an insightful young man on the hockey team who one character subtly refers to as the "bravest bastard I know." While I realize Beartown is a fictionalized town, in the back of my mind I've concluded I believe it really exists among the wilds of Northern Sweden. And coming to that realisation reminds me of the power of storytelling and the believability of it can have over an audience.

1st reread September 2020
The emotions. The critique. The understanding. The love. The hate. While I was too angry and hurt because of the unfairness and injustice of it all the first time around, I could see more clearly this time and could pick up a lot of the finer details I've missed a few months ago. And that made me appreciate this book and the execution of the story even more. The topic is such a hard one to write about but Backman does it in such an incredibly honest way - without ever becoming preachy or having the feeling he imposes a certain view on the reader. And still he shows so very clearly how this is a bitter reality and how people rather turn their heads and blame the victim instead of acknowledging the problem and their own mistakes - and that may be the hardest punch delivered by this book. ---------
Original review
I've tried countless times to put my thoughts and feelings about Beartown into words. But I can't. And I don't think I ever will. This book is too complex, too real, too emotional, too human, too raw and takes up a way too big part of my heart. It made me feel everything in an intensity I never thought a book could make me feel. Fredrik Backman captures the essence of what it means to be human in this story in a way I could never explain accurately. This story is a masterpiece and no one - no one - can convince me otherwise.

The opening sentence in Beartown reads: "Late one evening toward the end of March, a teenager picked up a double-barreled shotgun, walked into the forest, put the gun to someone else's forehead, and pulled the trigger."Then Backman takes us back to early March and tells us everything leading up to this event. Along the way, he tells us so much more. The story revolves around a hockey team in a hockey town. I personally love hockey but I don't think you need to be a hockey fan to enjoy this book. There a lot of characters introduced in the beginning but once you get all the characters straight it becomes a book about so many things. Friendship, parenthood, disappointment, loyalty, acceptance, just to name a few. This novel took me through many different emotions. The writing is full of memorable quotes like:"Being a parent makes you feel like a blanket that's always too small. No matter how hard you try to cover everyone, there's always someone who's freezing." "Another morning comes. It always does. Time always moves at the same rate, only feelings have different speeds. Every day can mark a whole lifetime or a single heartbeat, depending on who you spend it with."This was my first book by Backman but it will definitely not be my last.

There is something special about a book when you feel so deeply connected to the characters that their pain is yours. This is not a typical Backman novel. It will not leave you smiling from ear to ear. You won't get the warm and fuzzies either.What you will get is a story about a small town and their love for a sport played on the ice. Character development is just as beautiful as always. The message is just as loud and clear.Backman made me thoroughly enjoy a book that circles a town‚Äôs love of Hockey. Do I love hockey? I may now.
