After reading Beartown I just had to search online to find out how old Fredrik Backman is ‚Äì he was born in 1981 so he‚Äôs only in his mid-30s. How can it be that a person in his mid-30s has so much wisdom and life experience? Honestly I reckon he could pass for a 2,000 year old Greek philosopher. Pearls of wisdom are sprinkled throughout the entire book. A couple of examples:David, on the other hand, sits alone and silent at the front, staring at the text on his own phone. It‚Äôs from Kevin‚Äôs dad. He‚Äôs just found out what his son is accused of. One of the first things you learn as a leader, whether you choose the position or have it forced upon you, is that leadership is as much about what you don‚Äôt say as what you do say.The 'scandal' has erupted and divided the town...Hate can be a deeply stimulating emotion. The world becomes much easier to understand and much less terrifying if you divide everything and everyone into friends and enemies, we and they, good and evil. The easiest way to unite a group isn‚Äôt through love, because love is hard. It makes demands. Hate is simple.So the first thing that happens in a conflict is that we choose a side, because that‚Äôs easier than trying to hold two thoughts in our heads at the same time. The second thing that happens is that we seek out facts that confirm what we want to believe ‚Äì comforting facts, ones that permit life to go on as usual. The third is that we dehumanize our enemy. There are many ways of doing that, but none is easier than taking her name away from her.Kira and Peter, Maya‚Äôs parents, suffered the tragic loss of their son several years prior and one day they‚Äôre feeling happy‚Ä¶‚Ä¶Everyone has a thousand wishes before a tragedy, but just one afterwards. When a child is born, its parents dream of it being as unique as possible, until it gets ill, when suddenly all they want is for everything to be normal. Foe several years after Isak died, Kira and Peter felt a terrible, lacerating guilt every time they laughed. Shame can still catch them when they feel happy, making them wonder if it‚Äôs a betrayal of their child that they disintegrate entirely when he left them. One of all the terrible effects of grief is that we interpret its absence as egotism. It‚Äôs impossible to explain what you have to do in order to carry on after a funeral, how to put pieces of a family back together again, how to live with the jagged edges. So what do you end up asking for? You ask for a good day. One single good day. A few hours of amnesia.There are so many themes that are skilfully developed and explored in the book ‚Äì living in a small town and all the dynamics that goes with that, team sports, loyalty, the pack mentality, social class and they haves and the have nots, the wealthy family that thinks they can buy whatever they like, being a parent and raising kids, especially adolescents ‚Äì to name a few. And of course there‚Äôs the ‚Äòscandal‚Äô, 15 year old Maya‚Äôs courageous accusation against Kevin, the best player in the hockey team who is the son of the wealthy businessman and the way it divides the community.Don‚Äôt be too concerned if you‚Äôre not into hockey or sport generally, this is a great read in my opinion and I give it 4.5 stars. I would have given it 5 for sure but I just took a while to get into it and initially reacted a little negatively to the way the narrative shifted quickly, a paragraph about one character, two pages about another, three paragraphs about a third person, back to the first character with another page etc. But this is a very minor criticism. I strongly recommend this book.

TW: Body image, child mortality (flashback), guns, homophobia, rape, rape culture, suicide (mentions), suicidal thoughts, victim blaming, violenceBeartown is a slap in the face.Well, if I am being totally honest, I was way more impressed with the writing than the actual plot, but what would be the plot without the words shaping it? So, there is a correlation between the two and now that I‚Äôve wasted a few lines to say nothing in the end, I should start talking about the book.Let me start by saying: Beartown wasn‚Äôt about what I expected it to be about. If you‚Äôve read the book, you know what I mean, but if you haven‚Äôt, I would recommend not having any expectations. That being said, it was a breath-taking turn of events, the consequences still resonating in my head as this is a subject I am very sensitive about. The characterisation is strong and well developed, I found myself switching sides as I read the book and as each personality was explored further. The character range offers a wider vision of a society we are all part of, Beartown is only a sample of communities present around the world. We all know a local bar owner who knows the habits of a town‚Äôs inhabitants, we all know a kid with a secret, we all know a protective father, etc. Because of the book‚Äôs structure, I was inevitably carried into the eventful spiral following the tragedy. I absolutely loved the quickness in change of point of view and narrative ‚Äì the unforeseen consequences of a fast-paced environment mirroring the speediness of a hockey match, its strategies and its outcome. Just like the characters, the atmosphere suddenly takes a darker turn, which emphasises the seriousness of the book. I was far from knowing how heavy and serious Beartown was going to be.I have to insist on how beautiful the prose is. I also need to reiterate that Beartown was translated from Swedish and that the mere fact that the prose in English is stunning, makes me imagine how amazing the original work must be.A beautiful and emotional read, where right and wrong are interestingly intricated to a compelling plot. I found myself taking sides but also questioning the thoughts and ideas of every character ‚Äì controversially, each individual exposes their reasoning and their interest, and the simple fact of acknowledging and reckoning of the tragedy seems to be something unsurmountable. The different impacts and effects among the community were really well presented and it added more depth to the intrigue. Fredrik Backman is an amazing and skilful writer, and I will be reading more of his works.

I have read every single one of Fredrik Backman's books. And I have loved every single one of his books. So when I tell you that this, right here, is his masterpiece, you need to listen to me. If you do not read any of his other books, read this one. If he never writes another book, it will not matter. What matters is that he wrote this book, and everyone should read it. Everyone. This is completely different from his darkly comic, quirky stories. Oh, there's quirks here, but it's the quirkiness of real people, with all our flaws and our rituals, the things that make us laugh and cry, our likes and dislikes. Backman's strength, as always, lies in his characters, who are always so heartbreakingly real and never more so than here. I don't want to say anything else about the plot. I don't want to give anything away. On the surface it's a book about hockey, but it doesn't matter if you don't know a thing about the sport. It's also a story about families, and friends, about politics and economics. About the interconnectedness of everything, especially in a small town. It's a story about truth and lies, bravery and cowardice . . . it's just one hell of a story, perfectly written.It's a masterpiece.

Once again, I am rendered speechless by a Fredrik Backman book! The man definitely has a way of telling a story that is so utterly compelling that, every time I read one of his books, I find it nearly impossible to tear myself away (which is why I‚Äôm glad I started this on a weekend so I could spend all day reading if I needed to). Before I go further, I need to make a confession: I‚Äôve never been into sports and under normal circumstances, I probably would not have gravitated toward a book about hockey. But as nearly everyone who has read and reviewed this book mentioned, this is more than just a novel about hockey (or, more accurately, about a small town in the forest that is obsessed with hockey). In fact, this book blew me away with the wide range of themes it explored, which ran the gamut from parent/child relationships, to identity, belonging, class conflict, society bias, love, friendship, loyalty, the difference between right and wrong, etc. Beyond all that though, this is also a richly rendered character study about ordinary people living their lives and struggling with real life issues such as loneliness, abandonment, death, abuse, bullying, financial hardship, circumstances outside our control, etc. These are characters that we can absolutely relate to because they are flawed and realistic ‚Äî characters that make us feel the entire spectrum of human emotion and then some. Backman is a masterful storyteller with a unique writing style that I absolutely love ‚Äî a combination of serious and slightly humorous, yet also gut-wrenching and emotional. I‚Äôve been told that it‚Äôs nearly impossible to come away from a Backman novel without feeling something (whether positive, negative, or indifferent) for the characters and I have to say that I absolutely agree! That was definitely the case with every single character in this story. In fact, by the end of the book, I was so emotionally invested in these characters that I didn‚Äôt want to leave them ‚Äî which is why I intend to pick up the sequel, 
Us Against You
, right after this one so I can stay with the characters longer (and yes, I am eagerly looking forward to the final book in this series, which is scheduled to be published here in the U.S. in September).

This is a story of a small town with a big heart for hockey. Hockey. My least favourite sport even though both my son and daughter played it for many years. I don't miss those early mornings or stinky hockey bags. Most of all I don't miss the subculture that exists. The mom's screaming squad, the aggression and violence, their own set of rules. The parents fighting over calls. Over a game. A game with a stick and a puck. I'm not even sure I wanted to read this if not for the glowing reviews from my GR friends.'Hockey is life' as my husband's tshirt says and this is true for Bear Town. Even though the premise of this story is very much about the sport, it's also about the values instilled in the game and team. It's about the passion, the relationships, the successes, the loneliness, the failures. It's about mistakes and the consequences. The various perspectives, the emotions and backend stories make this so real. Maybe because I lived pieces of it and learned to tolerate it; but, it's more likely because you are a master storyteller and this story scores 5*****

Do sports build character or reveal it? In Fredrik Beckman's new book, the game of hockey does both. Beartown is a small city, dying away in the cold, dark forests of Sweden, that lives and breathes for hockey. As the book begins, Beartown's hopes for fame and glory (and perhaps a civic resurgence as well) are pinned on the ice hockey club's junior team winning the last two games in the biggest youth tournament in the country. But one unspeakable act will disrupt their plans and divide the city. Which should come first? Loyalty to the club, and by extension, the entire city...or justice? The book actually begins with a foreshadowing of one teen's way of finding justice. Keep that in mind as you read the rest of the story. The first 40% of the book is all about hockey. Almost everyone in Beartown is obsessed with it--the children, their parents, their coaches, the middle-aged former players, the wealthy sponsors. But notice, hockey is only for boys. Unlike the neighboring city of Hed, Beartown does not have a girls' hockey team. Girls aren't allowed. Girls aren't supposed to love hockey, after all. If they do, they must be lesbians. And if they like the players, they are groupies and sluts. Girls, therefore, don't count in Beartown--they are merely a distraction.To be sure, several of the hockey players have been inspired to work harder and harder to develop their talents and make the team, and in them, one could say that character has been built by their efforts. In others, who were given great talent and excel without much effort, who were admired and pampered all their lives, one could say character is revealed by their actions. And in between are those who maybe didn't try hard enough or just don't have what it takes. Not everyone is good enough to play hockey at the higher levels. The training process shakes out the chaff. One such player is mercilessly bullied by the older boys--"he knows firsthand what the strong do to the weak in this town." One cannot help but wonder, Who took the 'fun' out of the game of hockey?The characters in this story are AMAZING! Strong, strong women (thank you, Fredrik Backman!) Men who are manly enough to allow themselves to be weak and emotional at times. There are great bonds of friendship. The author is fond of saying, "Never again do you have the sort of friends you have when you're fifteen." But those bonds of friendship are sorely tested as they experience life. Loyalty is also a big theme. Which comes first: loyalty to your team or to your friend? Is loyalty more important than doing what is right?This book is wonderful at times and disturbing at others. Twice I had to put it down and walk away--so you know how emotionally involved I was at that moment. I highly recommend this book to fans of Backman's other books: you will find he has a stepped up to a new level in his writing with this one. You won't find the charming, warm and fuzzy story here. This one makes you stop and think about what we are teaching our children, what life lessons are important to learn. I also highly recommend this book to newcomers to Backman's work--this is an excellent place to start.Many thanks to Rachel Brenner and AtriaBooks/Simon & Schuster for offering me a special widget to read an ARC of this book through NG. I am so grateful for the opportunity; Fredrik Backman is definitely one of my favorite authors. Personal note: I confess to not being much of a hockey fan even though I grew up in the suburbs of one NHL city and moved to the suburbs of a second as an adult--but I'm always delighted when one of those two teams wins the Stanley Cup of course! My one big experience with the thrill of hockey came during the 1980 Winter Olympics when America's hockey team beat the Russians to win the gold medal. We were glued to our tv sets for that! Do you believe in miracles? Yes, we do!A second note: When we moved to a small city in Illinois in the early 80s, we found a similar sports culture surrounding their winning football team--similar to Beartown's hockey culture, that is. Those boys could just about get away with anything--even the police looked the other way. And middle-aged men sat in bars reminiscing about their glory days on the field--the highlight of their lives.

It is official!¬† I can honestly say that Fredrik Backman is my favorite author.¬† I have now read everything he has written, and all have been top-notch.¬† "Beartown" rates as high as "A man called Ove" in my opinion, so that is high praise indeed coming from me.I usually add a few quotes to my reviews, but in this case if I added all the quotes I highlighted in my Kindle, this review would be almost as long as the book itself. Though, that being said, I did have to add a few of my most favorite quotes at the end of the review I posted on my blog.Where to start?¬† When you absolutely LOVE a book, it is hard to know how to write a review without sounding 'gushy'.¬† I hate gushy.Deep in a forest in Sweden lies a small town called "Beartown".¬† Beartown is a hockey town, and this book is about hockey.¬† But it's not really.¬† It is about society, it is about life, parenthood, loyalty, bravery, and so very much more. It is about a scandal, and how the people of Beartown are forced to take sides...Beartown is a town that is in economic decline. Pretty much all it has left is its hockey club. The hope is that if the town's team wins the final, money and prosperity might return to the town as a result.It is hard to pinpoint a protagonist in this novel.¬† All the characters shine brightly, and you will come to care for them all."It doesn't take a lot to be able to let go of your child. It takes everything."The Andersson family: Peter, his wife, Kira, their fifteen year old daughter Maya, and their twelve year-old son, Leo. Peter, a former professional hockey player, is the General Manager of the Beartown Hockey Club. Kira is a talented lawyer, Maya loves her guitar, and Leo his games. Oh, and then there is Ana, Maya's best friend, who practically lives at the Andersson's.The Erdahl family: Seventeen year-old Kevin is the town's star hockey player. He was born with the talent to excel at his sport. He is the only child of affluent parents who are not demonstrative in their affections. His father is one of the primary financial backers of the team."Kevin is too good. Kevin is the jewel, Benji the insurance policy."Benjamin (Benji), is Kevin's best friend. He has been since they were both tiny.¬† A fighter on the ice, Benji always has Kevin's back.¬† Kevin wouldn't be half the player he is without Benji's support, both on and off the ice.Fatima, works as a cleaner at the hockey rink. An immigrant, and the mother of fifteen year-old Amat, a small boy in stature, but a big man in moral fibre.¬† He loves hockey and is one of the fastest skaters in Beartown.¬† The only thing he loves more than skating, is Maya Andersson."The most painful fall for anyone is tumbling down through a hierarchy."Sune, the A-team coach of the Beartown Hockey Club. He has been around as long as anyone can remember.¬† He is patriarch of the hockey club and mentor to both Peter and David.David, the hockey coach. The players love him and have done so since they were seven years old. He is who they strive to win for.Ramona, the chain-smoking owner of the town's only tavern. Ramona is a childless widow."People say she's gone mad, because that's what people who know nothing about loneliness call it."This book did exactly what literary fiction should do.¬† It makes you think. About others in your life - about yourself. It makes you chuckle, it makes you weep. This is a book about parents and children, friendships, loyalty and betrayal, loss and loneliness, bravery and cowardice, vengeance and justice, the value of social acceptance."Another morning comes. It always does. Time always moves at the same rate, only feelings have different speeds. Each day can mark a whole lifetime or a single heartbeat, depending on who you spend it with."In my opinion, if you spend your time reading Beartown, it is time well spent.¬† Highly recommended!¬†Many thanks to Simon & Schuster Canada who sent me a physical copy of the book, and to Atria Books who approved my request for a digital reading copy on NetGalley.

People who live in small towns live a different kind of life from urban kids. It doesn't matter if it's Sweden or the U.S., it's the smallness that makes the difference. You will never have a better friend than the one you have at 15 and it's so true. In a small town, people know everything about you. They know your family, you spend the night in each other's bedrooms, you have been in school together since you were 5. You are bound in ways that are unexplainable and when those friends betray you, the pain is almost unendurable. The book is about hockey and so much more. In the small town of Beartown the only thing that matters is hockey. Time was not been kind to Beartown and industry is moving away and jobs are few and far between. What they do have is a wonderful team and the possibility of a hockey academy being built there if the junior team wins the championship. The pressure is on with these young kids aged 15-18. The town's future is riding on their young shoulders. The kids have been raised on hockey since they were 4 or 5 . Their mantra is "This sport demands only one thing from you. Your all." In backyards and on frozen lakes the sound of a hockey stick hitting a puck over and over again. The sport is so encompassing and get told it's only a game. "But it's complete nonsense. No one in this town would have been the same if that game hadn't existed." After a regional win, a tragedy occurs and nothing is ever the same again. How the town responds and the decisions made changes life for good. It's absolutely heart wrenching. It's painful to read but it shows everyone's point of view so well.  Backman is absolutely one of the best authors writing now. He doesn't have many books out but each one tells an unique story. Britt-Marie Was Heretells the story of a middle aged woman starting life over, My Grandmother Asked Me to Tell You She's Sorry is a young girl who is being protected by a fantasy life created by her grandmother and And Every Morning the Way Home Gets Longer and Longer is about a grandfather with Alzheimer's preparing his beloved grandson for what will come. All different and all heart warming. If you have not read him then do yourself a favor and read this book. It will speak to you on so many levels.Thank you Net Galley and Simon & Schuster for the opportunity of reading this wonderful book and writing a review.

Beartown is a hockey town.The book is so much more than that.My second book by Backman and it certainly did not disappoint. Based on a small forest town that solely relies on hockey. Every person in the town is impacted by this team, the sport, and the mascot it represents. You have class warfare from the Heights to the Hollows. The local bar-- (called Bearskin hehe) and the old school male point of view. The town is bustling for the big game of the year, the one that can change this town on the map-- everyone has skin in this game, and then something happens to test the strength of the game. Can they survive it?Backman has a way with words that grips your heart. The way he writes a succinct statement can change your perspective in an instant. For me, this immediately pulled me in. There were SO many characters to keep track of and their perspectives varied within chapters-- making it a rhythm that took me some to adjust to. For me, the book took too long to get to the meat of the plot. Over halfway through-- building, building, building and then whoosh-- I couldn't put it down. Backman builds the tension and leaves you hanging so that you are coerced into reading until you find out what happens. I had so many favorite characters that I found myself rooting for- some in small ways, others in much larger, heartbreaking ways. This is a great book that teaches so many important lessons about how a sport can turn against a town, and so much more.

I tried to read Beartown by Fredrik Backman a year ago. Hockey, hockey, hockey. It was all about winning and playing. I found it incredibly boring. Since then I have seen there are 2 other books in the series. I decided to pick this book back up and finish it. It is very sad, a bit depressing and life altering. After a life altering event in Beartown, the reader learns, women are still oppressed On to the next book in the series.

So I feel like at least one review of this book should say "Trigger warning". It's not clear when you read about this book what the subject matter is. If I'd know I wouldn't have picked it up, it's incredibly distressing to read wether it's a trigger or not. From what I read about it, I thought it was about a shooting in the woods and how the town heals from that through hockey, love and friendship. Your basic Backman book.What it's actually about is the rape of a 15 year old girl and the town taking sides between the victim and rapist. It was beyond horrible to read.It's also one of the worst books I've ever read. It's incredibly long winded, goes on and on and on about how "important" hockey is in Beartown to the point where it's gushing on every other page.I got fed up of reading vague sentences like "The dad is still sitting in the kitchen" or "A teacher is standing in a class room" or " As the boy practices on his own" I felt like I was reading some crappy fanfiction.I thought at least the ending would resolve everything and the rapist would be locked away or as I hoped killed.Spoilers.He gets away with it. The ending is vague and rubbish and Kevin has his own wife and child, left totally free to live his life and the whole book felt like a huge waste of time designed just to depress the reader. I don't understand how it's getting such warm reviews. I'm a big fan of Fredrik Backman and I unknowingly picked this up thinking I was going to read something fuzzy and heart warming like his other books. That's what I wanted to read. Instead I got this and I just kept hoping it would get better and be resolved but it didn't. It just breaks your heart, makes you lose faith in humanity and leaves you thinking WHAT SERIOUSLY?

This book was amazing! Riveting does not even cover it. I will admit I am a huge hockey fan. I have been watching hockey since before I can even remember with my dad. It took me a couple years to get back into hockey after he passed but I did go back to following the sport fanatically in the end. Anyways, this book follows a small community where hockey is first and foremost and the boys who make this team get the prime treatment. Including when one victimizes a young girl. The disturbing reaction of the community was so infuriating but it did not turn me away from the book. Instead I found myself rooting for somebody to come forward and punch some sense into these people! The brave in this book are not the ones the reader would expect. It was just a profound read. My quick and simple overall: are you kidding me, this is now one of my favorite books!

4.5 stars: ‚ÄúBeartown‚Äù captures the essence of small town politics and the laser focus and idolization of a beloved sport in said small town. Author Fredrick Backman MUST have lived in a small town and grown up around such venerated sport heroes. Backman picked hockey to tell his story, but it could have been football, perhaps basketball. In small towns across America, members of successful sport teams live above the law and outside the rules. Beartown is a hockey town. It‚Äôs a town in a remote area (the forest) in Sweden. Hockey is the heart and the lungs of the town. Without it, the townsfolk would have no purpose. The story opens with the junior team riding wins and focusing on the national championship. The culture of hockey dominates the story. The reader is treated to the inside conventions and customs of a team. The craze of the townsfolk and the obsession of winning are felt while reading. The hockey players are above the law, in school and on the streets. They know they can do whatever they want without ramifications. In fact, the feeling is drilled into them that they are gods and are deserving of anything they want. Backman writes those scenes with perfection. It‚Äôs realistic fiction, sadly.One of the star players is involved in a felonious act. He doesn‚Äôt see it as a felony because he has been taught that rules don‚Äôt apply to him. Some townspeople side with the hockey player, despite evidence to the contrary. Moral ambiguity is the catch phrase. Only the reader and the two involved know the story. Hypocrisy runs rampant. Backman does write redeeming characters. Not all are amoral. But hockey, as a culture, is difficult to cross. And some who cross it are dealt with swiftly and inhumanely. Backman shows the true ugliness of the sport.That said, Backman does a fabulous job showing how hockey (or any sport) instills discipline. It is a safe haven for those boys who need direction. It‚Äôs not all bad; there are redeeming characteristics of the sport.What Backman does best is show humanity at it‚Äôs worse and best. There are bits of humor sprinkled here and there, but it‚Äôs a big departure from his previous works like ‚ÄúA Man Called Ove‚Äù. I highly recommend this one, as Backman hits another one out of the park!

I'm very happy I decided to go into this one blind. This isn't a book I'd usually read, and most of my motivation was solely from Anxious People . The writing is still as amazing as ever from Backman, and I enjoyed it exploring themes of community, friendship, and loyalty. The ending was genuinely tense and had me a little bit more shaken than I was expecting. The only reason I can't give this five stars is because I thought there were a few unnecessary characters in an already fairly large set of a cast. It was a lot of moving parts, especially at the beginning when you'd transition into a different narrative in as soon as a single paragraph.Last night I tried to get into Us Against You, but made it fifty pages before I stopped. It wasn't because it was necessarily bad, I'm just surprised that this book needed a sequel let alone an upcoming trilogy.

This book. THIS BOOK. I don't even know how to talk about it I loved it so much. It's the kind of book where I really wish I were more prudent about my five star ratings. It's taken its place alongside my all-time favorites ever. I loved it. It made me feel SO MUCH. Every character was complex and multi-faceted, not just good, not just bad, and so developed (shockingly, since we move around between a lot of characters). Its themes are rich and explored with nuance and compassion: loyalty, family, friendship, love, good vs. evil, truth, compassion, justice, hope, resilience. I cannot recommend it highly enough and want to put it into the hands of all the people in my life.Note: this book deals heavily and honestly with rape. It's heavy and hard to read. Make sure you're in the right headspace.

I‚Äôm glad I chose this son of a gun book by Backman as my first book of 2018, if I made it through this, I can do anything, honestly.Someone needs to tap Backman on the shoulder and tell him he doesn‚Äôt need to be heart wrenching in every word. We need to breathe in order to read on.

Gosh, this book made me angry! (but in a good way)Beartown is a small, parochial community in the forested north of Sweden. Jobs have been drying up over recent years and many in the community are struggling. The only thing that brings joy to many of the citizens is their collective obsession with hockey (ice hockey) and the town's beloved club, whose teams compete in the junior and A-leagues. This season, the Beartown junior team have qualified for the semi-final, and the excitement is electric.The first half of the novel, while thick with foreshadowing, is a slow-build to the pivotal event - a team party following the much-anticipated game, attended by many of the town's teenagers, during which a 15-year-old girl is raped by one of the youth team's star players.The rest of the book follows the reverberations from this incident, for the victim, her family, the perpetrator and his family, the other members of the team and the wider community of Beartown. It's a disquieting tale of misogynistic attitudes, warped priorities, conflicting loyalties and the finding of courage, to stand up for what's right and to survive.Earlier this year, I read Chanel Miller's brilliant Know My Name an account of the author's experiences as the then-unnamed victim/survivor of the notorious "Stanford rape" by elite swimmer-student Brock Turner. Although Beartown was published less than two years later, I suspect that Fredrik Backman must have been at least partly inspired by that true story, especially given that the two men who came to Miller's aid on the night she was raped (and apprehended Turner) were Swedish post-grads. Certainly, many of the issues and attitudes which fuelled fierce debate around Turner's arrest, trial and sentencing are raised in Beartown.As always, Backman's plotting and characters are superb. The backstory around the town and the generational change occurring at the Hockey club are poignant and insightful. He creates an appropriately tinderbox-like setting for the dramatic events that follow. With characteristically well-crafted prose, he explores his characters' motivations and fears extraordinarily well. While several characters are downright antagonistic and their behaviour easy to condemn, Backman makes them both believable and (to some extent) understandable. The characters on the side of moral "right", particularly Maya, Benji and Amat, certainly face a lot of hurdles over the course of the novel, but are not portrayed as saints, but as fallible individuals who struggle with their choices.My reading of Beartown was partly by way of listening to the Audioworks audiobook edition, narrated by Marin Ireland, and I took the first half fairly slowly. However, once the action heated up around the midway point, I read the remainder in only a couple of sittings.A really engrossing and thought-provoking read. I'm looking forward to reading the sequel, Us Against You, early in the new year.

I actually hadn‚Äôt planned on reading this book. I liked Backman‚Äôs A Man Called Ove about a cranky old man learning to be...well, less cranky. It was sweet and heartwarming. But then he wrote three more variations on the same theme. And they were fine, if not quite as sweet and heartwarming as Ove. But, to be honest, I was kind of tired of reading the same story over and over again and so I didn‚Äôt think I was going to read this one. I‚Äôm not totally sure what caused me to give this book another look, but I‚Äôm so glad I did because it is definitely not just another rehash of the same plot points. In fact, it could not be more different than Ove. It‚Äôs about sports culture in a remote Swedish town where hockey is everything (if this was an American novel, it would have undoubtedly been about football). The Beartown Bears are one of the premier junior hockey teams in the country and seem to be on track for the championships. There are rumors that the star player, Kevin, might have a future in the NHL. And bringing home the trophy would have huge economic implications for the down-trodden town in the middle of nowhere. It‚Äôs an intense amount of pressure for a group of sixteen- and seventeen-year-old boys. But like star football players in a lot of American high schools, the boys essentially run the town. They‚Äôre given a wider berth for misbehavior than they might otherwise be given. And, perhaps because of that, one night between the semi-finals and the finals, things boil over into a violent act that literally threatens to tear the town apart. This read to me almost like a cross between We Were the Mulvaneys and The Art of Fielding. I think it might require a little bit more knowledge of hockey than the former did of baseball--or, at least some level of interest, because there are long passages simply describing practice routines and gameplay. But, really, the book is about the spiraling implications of this one violent act: how it affects players, coaches, parents, even the townspeople. How it strains friendships and marriages and career prospects of kids too young to drive. No one in Beartown is unaffected, and Backman is willing to spend time with just about everyone in the town as he wends his way through the story. Which is both good and not-so-good. He started the book off with one hell of a first page, but then the pacing slowed down a little too much. I might have given this five stars if it hadn‚Äôt dragged on quite so long. At times, I felt like there were too many small characters and too many threads being built up--it took nearly 200 pages for anything to really happen, and I can imagine that would become frustrating for many readers. This book tested my patience, but Backman tells his story with an almost unbelievable amount of honesty and empathy, even anger, and he ultimately drives the story into an incredibly powerful, heart-wrenching end.

My first book by Mr. Backman and if this is an indication of his masterful storytelling it will not be my last. I may be late to jump on his bandwagon but I will ride it all the way. Simply and beautifully done Mr. Backman. I recognized this small town, where hockey is king. This sport brings this community together. Not only the young players with big dreams and the men who coach them to achieve their best, but also the "has beens" and "want to be's" and all those who live their mundane boring lives with the goal of seeing that Friday night game alongside their neighbors. This is their team, they all claim ownership! I have seen it, in small communities where the way out of a factory job is being the best on the team...be it football, or baseball, or soccer. Dreams are big, and easily shattered. The characters we find in Beartown are the cream of the crop, the bad seeds, the good for nothings, the honest hard working folks. They are all here and wonderfully revealed and developed. They all have a part to play. Some of them play fair, others not so much. Out of this comes a wonderful story of youth, learning what is important, what is right and when a line is crossed where do you stand? My favorite characters were the young ones. They were almost like clay, molded by the adults, but with each one reaching a point where they claimed their own identities. This is not a story of the somewhat brutal sport of hockey....a mans game. It is the story of life, of relationships, of taking a stand based on what you believe. There is unity in these characters, a common goal. Yet Backman slowly reveals the individuals and when they reach the point when they set their own goals. This is a story that young, old, rich, poor, successful or not, should be able to relate to. It is a simply wonderful telling of what life is really like, disguised in the game of hockey.

This is my week for being an outlier. The much beloved Beartown is going back to the library. I've tried to read it several times as it is my bookclub's choice this month. But I can't get past page 115. It grates on me.

"There are thousands of ways to die in Beartown. Especially on the inside."Never have I ever read a book that made me care about characters and cry for them as much as Beartown.
SUMMARY
It is best to go into this book blind. All you need to know is that Beartown is a small-yet-eccentric hockey community, where the town is more forest that civilisation. But unless the Junior Hockey Team can make it into the finals and win, Beartown will disappear. What happens when you put so much pressure on young boys? What happens when a tragic assault of a young girl threatens to destroy the very town everyone is trying to save?
REVIEW
I read this book after seeing so many people on BookTube rave about it. I was a little skeptical, Beartown was out of my usual reading comfort-zone of fantasy and romance. However, I was utterly blow-away by this masterpiece. I am so glad that I read it. This is the first book I have ever physically annotated with highlighters. Never have I read a book with more beautiful prose, prose that screamed to be highlighted and remembered. I wish I could insert every beautiful and heartbreaking line in this review, but that would take away the magic you experience first-hand reading this story. The second I finished this book and threw my slew of used tissues in the bin, I flipped through my highlights. I reminisced and cried all over again at the phenomenal story that Backman crafted through irresistible prose. Yes, this is a large cast, a very large cast. I was overwhelmed in the beginning, afraid I would confuse whose parent was whose, and which hockey player was which. But Backman makes every character distinct, every family dynamic unique, and you fall for them without realsing. I cried like a child fresh out of the womb during this book. Whenever I hear that a story about rape is written by a man, I get wary. It may be sexist, but I am always worried that it will be portrayed in the wrong light. I was wrong in the case of Backman. Beartown has one of the most real and heartbreaking outlooks on rape culture - especially in a small community. I was crying, not just for the girl, but her friends and family as well (I say "the girl" because I don't want to spoil the book). I wish I could go into detail about how this story affected me, how the girl's experience broke something within me, how I just wanted to curl up and cry on my couch for hours, but I can't - because it will break me all over again. This is novel is a tale about a town that is broken and trying to keep itself together by frantically duct-taping the cracks. It is raw and real, and you feel and care for every single character.So please, just trust me. Read this book. It will change your life.

‚ÄúWhy does anyone care about hockey? Because it tells stories.‚Äù In ‚ÄúBeartown‚Äù Fredrik Backman uses hockey as the framework for his novel, but it applies equally well to any sport in any community that has an out-size impact on players, their parents, former players, and ordinary residents. In Beartown, the junior boys hockey team is the heart and hope of the community. Residents believe that if the team can win the national finals (and they have a very good shot at doing so), it will bring a new hockey academy, conference center, malls, and jobs to the dying town. But everything changes when one of the players commits a violent and brutal act, one which deeply divides the town. ‚ÄúBeartown‚Äù was a little slow getting started because Backman has so many characters to introduce. But that slow build-up really pays off in the richness of the characters, characters that could be straight from your life, and most importantly, characters you really care about. The book focuses on some extremely powerful emotional issues, but never gets bogged down in moralizing or cheap sentiment. ‚ÄúBeartown‚Äù has a darker tone and story line than any of Backman‚Äôs previous books, but courage, love, and the bonds of family and friends shine through. His empathetic, sensitive, and insightful understanding of the human heart, with all it‚Äôs fears and desires, truly makes his work stand out, and he‚Äôs one of my favorite authors to recommend.Thank you to Atria Books and NetGalley for an advance copy of this book.

I‚Äôm surprised by how much I loved this book because the backdrop is all things hockey. That it‚Äôs by Fredrik Backman is pretty much the only reason I decided to give it a listen (I loved A MAN CALLED OVE), because, again the backdrop is hockey. I don‚Äôt dislike hockey. I actually like hockey, and since my husband used to play it when he was much younger, he likes watching the Stanley Cup Finals and I usually watch with him, with him patiently answering my ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the puck?‚Äù every ten seconds without a complaint (that little black disc ‚Äì even smaller on TV ‚Äì is hard to keep track of). I just never pictured myself picking up (or picking out) a novel with hockey players on its cover.The story is set in a Swedish town but the narrative reads like the setting could be any place in Minnesota where the population is less than five thousand and the only thing to do in winter (which lasts a long, long time) is play or watch ice hockey. Hockey is more than just that, though. It‚Äôs not the only thing you can do; it‚Äôs the only thing you WANT to do. It‚Äôs the only thing. It‚Äôs THE thing. And into this mini cosmos, Mr. Backman introduces an ensemble of characters ‚Äì some in their teens, some in their 40‚Äôs, some somewhere in between ‚Äì whose lives and choices play out in and beyond and behind this ice. It‚Äôs truly a book about people, not hockey, even though you can feel the numbing cold, taste the blood on your lip from a slamming body check, even see the puck. And the people in this tableau are so richly drawn and perfectly imperfect. The ending is everything an ending should be. Surprising and deeply satisfying. One word of caution: I listened to the book on audio (and with an audio book, you hear EVERY word). The language can be hard on the ear; it was on mine. If the prolific use of the F-bomb makes you cringe, you might want to read instead of listen or choose another book. If you can see (or hear) past that, it's an absolutely stellar book.

Beartown was no exception - it was horribly believable, terribly realistic and wonderfully written. this is known to be one of Backman's darkest novels, and i can definitely see why, because it was so incredibly heartwrenching - i honestly couldn't take it sometimes. i had to take breaks when reading this, because it made me so

Being from the UK I know absolutely nothing about ice hockey! But I do remember being on holiday in Canada quite a few years ago and hearing car after car driving down the road, horns tooting, people leaning out the windows waving flags and cheering.....we were told the local ice hockey team had won !So with my very limited knowledge I did wonder if this book would interest me. Luckily, even though the game was a constant through the book it was not in any great technical detail, so I coped ok! It was well written and the passion for the game came through. This book could be about any small town, the quirky characters, the good and bad relationships and how a small town can come together and equally pull apart. But the difference with Beartown is, it‚Äôs a small town dominated by it‚Äôs ice hockey team and all the passion and bad blood that goes with it and how the whole town copes with a ‚Äòlife changing‚Äô event. I thoroughly enjoy it but I didn‚Äôt always relate to the behaviour of the characters, I thought the flow of the story was often repetitive, whether it was the love you feel for your children or the preparation and training for a game...... win, win win etc ! I do feel that it could have been a shorter book. I know I am in the minority but this book did not give me a big buzz, as I thought it would.

This book was probably the most difficult one to read of all of Backman's books for me. It deals with rape, so if that's not something you want in your literature, I would suggest avoiding this one because it deals very heavily with the subject. That being said, it handles the topic really well, as frustratingly accurate as it can be at times. My only criticism of the book is that it felt a bit long; it's mostly the reader watching events unfold along with the lives of these characters, but I really enjoyed nearly all of the characters in this book so I was ok with the length in the end. Backman is definitely one of my go-to authors and I'll read anything he writes. It's got a lot of heart, a good message, and manages to make you laugh and cry, sometimes in the span of a single page.

"Late one evening toward the end of March, a teenager picked up a double-barreled shotgun, walked into the forest, put the gun to someone else‚Äôs forehead, and pulled the trigger. This is the story of how we got there."

Initial Thoughts
After just finishing a second rate horror novel I was in the mood for a surefire five star book to get me back on my reading track. I was recommended Bear Town by Fredrick Backman by a good friend who knows exactly what type of books I like. Plus it heavily features Ice Hockey, which is a sport I love. I grew up around it, with a brother who played to quite a high level. So this looked like the book for me.Its currently got a 4.27 rating on here, a number of my Goodreads buddies had awarded it five stars and raved about it. Having sat on my TBR for over a year, the stars were aligned with this one. The coffee was brewed, the salted peanuts at the ready. I was all set for a great time. What could possibly go wrong?
The Story 
As illustrated by the opening quote, the novel begins with a gunshot in the middle of a forest. The story that follows tells us how we got there. Taking place in the fictional location of Bear Town, a place that eats, sleeps and breathes Ice Hockey, we get the story of a financially deprived community that is pinning all its hopes on the sport they love. The junior teams march to the regional final presents Bear Town's one and only chance to bring honour, pride and much needed investment to its inhabitants. The question is...what are they prepared to sacrifice to get there?When a traumatic event occurs and accusations are aimed at the teams superstar player and team captain, we're going to find out who is prepared to put their morals to one side in the pursuit of success. It's something that could turn team mates into enemies and rip an entire community apart. For me this had the set up for a great story.
The Writing 
But then I hit a massive stumbling block and it really pains me to say it. I really wanted to love this book but I had some major issues with Backman's writing style. It is very different in that he uses an omnipresent narrator, that jumps about quickly from character, while injecting the authors own philosophy on events taking place. At first I was enjoying it, as it was fresh and unique, but it quickly started to grate on me. Particularly the choppy sentence structure and the way it jumped about at a rapid pace.Despite the short sentences and page breaks, the overall pace was slow and the story dragged its feet toward a pretty anticlimactic finish that was predictable. A complete contrast to the sport the novel is based on. There's very little twist and turns and it does get a little repetitive. Dare I say quite pedestrian and boring in parts? Yes I do! You could shave a hundred pages off and the book certainly wouldn't have suffered.Backman's style is also a classic case of tell not show, where he constantly prompts the reader in certain directions and came across as trying to interpret events for me. I'm a reader who normally likes to be presented with events and have the chance to make my own mind up. Another problem is the authors lack of description. Bear Town is an intriguing setting in a harsh and primaeval location that I was immediately interested in. But he barely describes it choosing to give us the basic blot along with the narrator's take on what's going down.
The Characters 
Because there's a lot of characters, and Backman constantly jumps between each one, we don't seem to get a lot of development for any of them. I don't want to go as far as saying they were cardboard, but I will say that none were very fleshed out and as a result I never got invested and start to care for them.The main character of Peter Andersson, the hockey club general manager, was particularly annoying. A player that apparently made it all the way through Swedish ice hockey, which is an often brutal and unforgiven sport, he was an absolute wimp. There's some really bad things happen to his teenage daughter and his response was completely shocking in the lack of one. Maybe I took it too personally, as a father of a young daughter myself, but it really did wind me up.Another thing that turned me off was the majority of female characters seemed to look down on their male partners and friends with statements like 
"You're an idiot, but I love you."
 I would have found this slightly humerus but it started to become a repetitive theme. Not quite sure where Backman was going with this one but it wasn't for me. Pretty much like all of the characters in the book. I will say that Benji, the tough as nails, gay player did endear himself to me. If I had to pick a favourite it would be him but there were aspects that were forced and a touch unrealistic. Still, if I had to route for someone in this story it would definitely be for him and he could come and play for my team any day.
Final Thoughts 
Damn! That's two negative reviews in a row from me now and I don't like to do that. I'm gutted I didn't love Bear Town as on the surface it looked like my type of book. Although it was a big disappointment, I'm not going to feel bad about it as there's plenty of good reviews for it and I think it's just not my type of book.Being honest it came across as a bit of a young adult novel and had a soap opera quality to it. There was a lot of teenage angst in there. Certainly not my type of thing.However, don't take my opinion as gospel (what do I know lol) and certainly read some of the positive reviews to give yourself a more balanced take. This book did tackle some very important issues, but it's not enough to save it from a 2.5 star rating.Sorry Mr Backman. But if you're reading...thanks and cheers!

4.25/5 stars‚ÄúEveryone has a thousand wishes before a tragedy, but just one afterward.‚Äù‚ÄãThis is the hardest book I've ever had to read in my life. I've only had other 2 books that gave me such a hard time and those were The Flowers for Argenon by Daniel Keyes and Challenger Deep by Neil Shusterman. Still those two books can't compete with how brutal Beartown was on me.Beartown is not a happy book. It's not an easy book, nor is it pleasant. Not even close. It's a hard, heavy book that made me feel angry and helpless. Did I enjoy it? No. But I did love it.Would I read it again? I don't think I'd be able to handle it again. Do I recommend Beartown? - YESYESYESYESYES ‚ÄúBitterness can be corrosive. It can rewrite your memories as if it were scrubbing a crime scene clean, until in the end you only remember what suits you of its causes.‚ÄùBeartown is a hokey town. I myself don't like hockey, and to be honest with you I think I even hate it now. If you are a hockey fan this book will speak to you on another level. If you are not a hockey fan, there are things in Beartown that are more important than hockey. Because I don't care about hockey the first 150 pages of the book were a drag, but I'm glad I stuck around anyway, because this book pulverized me. I was expecting something along the lines of A man called Ove - sad, quirky and with lots of tears. Beartown was nothing like that - it was brutal, pretty depressing and instead of tears I just got buckets of rage. Want to feel angry? Want to feel blind rage coursing through your veins? Read Beartown. ‚ÄúThe very worst events in life have that effect on a family: we always remember, more sharply than anything else, the last happy moments before everything fell apart.‚Äù‚ÄãBackman weaves the story of a small town community, but somehow it's the most personal and intimate thing you will ever read. The characters are introduced and the array of emotions you go through as those characters make their choice vary from affection to "I want to kill them all".‚ÄãThe writing is precise and choppy - somehow perfect for the cold bareness of the Beartown, but it brings more dimensions to the story than any flowery and overly wordy writing ever could. Backman might as well be a genius of human psyche, because man knows what he's doing, and he's doing it really, really well. My WEBSITEMy INSTAGRAMMy WORDPRESS BLOG

When the early reviews came out for this book - they were all 5 stars. I thought - wow, that's awesome for a book about hockey! I just don't think the majority of females love to read about sports, but females are loving this book!?! Now I see why...this book is not about hockey. There are actually only a few games even played in the book. This book has a very large cast of characters. I listened to the audio version and it was really, really good!! To actually follow the life of each person and remember all the little details is sometimes hard on audio. But, Fredrik Backman has a unique ability to describe his characters. To make you see them, feel them, feel their pain, their happiness, anger, longing - all of the wonderful emotions that happen while you read this. There are more than 10 really fantastic characters that you will LOVE. And very much like his debut A Man Called Ove, this book is about - relationships, actions, friends, confidences, societal norms, jobs. It's also about being part of a team, and being a member of a town who essentially feel as if they are also.......part of the team. Of course, this is happy times when they are the winning team!!! Hockey is LIFE, in their small town. And as we all know.....it's very hard to put LIFE on the shoulders of teens!!Definitely pick this one up, immediately! And be prepared to immerse yourself in Beartown!!!!

3.5 stars, though that may change with time, I suppose, sink or rise. It took me out of my comfort zone, at least. Best sellers and I make strange bedfellows.Some of what worked against it was me, not it. I'm not big on sweeping tales--either vertical in time (one of those generational sagas) or horizontal in scope (huge canvas, dozens of characters). I do not do well with 3rd-person omniscient point of view, either. A bit too clinical for me. I'm much more convinced by the heart and soul of 1st or 3rd limited. And authorial interruptions! The asides about ten years from now, or does-something-he'll-regret-in-a-few-chapters-as-you'll-see, or I-know-something-you-don't-because-I'm-God!No. I don't like to see the author waving. I like him invisible. I like to pay no attention to that man behind the curtain.And a bit too pat an ending? Oh, yeah. Hollywood endings--even in Sweden--have always grated on me. I would be a horrible test audience for a film that has an unpleasant ending. The sole "keep it as is" vote, I fear.That all said, I have to respect the design and scope here. It had some surprises for me. It lumbered off the blocks in the beginning, yes; it was entirely too long, yes, again; but it picked up nicely at crunch time. I enjoyed stretches. And I liked certain characters. Precious few. And this despite feeling manipulated a bit by a sentimental and didactic author. Big of me, I know.So overall, enjoyable despite the odds. And despite how claustrophobic (among other phobias) this small town in Sweden (that could've been in Pennsylvania) felt.*That's saying something. Hats off to Mr. Hockey. I hated to sort of like your book, which, in the end, barely escaped the trap of becoming unbearable._____*Note, however, that Backman never locates it geographically. Anywhere hockey is played and human nature is displayed, was his wish. So be it.

new favorite. backman forces both the reader and the characters to confront the ugliest as well as the most beautiful sides of beartown and its inhabitants, weaving his way through the lives of dozens of characters and stitching the fabric of the town into your heart as he goes. without realizing when or how he did it, i became deeply bound to these characters. how this book manages to be a character study on over a dozen characters, i‚Äôll never understand. it‚Äôs genius.i lost track of the number of times backman broke my heart and healed it over again. i think every other paragraph of the last 200 pages of the book brought fresh tears to my eyes, as my emotional investment in the community grew with every page. the relationships between characters were raw and honest; each one crafted with such care. there is no perfect character in this book‚Äîeach one makes choices you‚Äôll disagree with, and yet, backman ensures you understand each of them intimately. these characters live in my heart in a way i cannot describe. backman paints the small town feel and atmosphere so vividly. the town and cast feel unique, yet there‚Äôs a feeling that this could happen anywhere; every small town has its ‚Äúhockey.‚Äùi always say that i read as an exercise in empathy. sure, sometimes i read for escape or learning or entertainment, but my favorite books are always the greatest exercises in empathy. beartown has easily earned its spot on my favorites shelf for this reason.easily my favorite book i've read this year.________reread review: just as devastating/heartwarming/soul-crushing/beautiful/touching the second time.________rereread review: how much more some of this hurts after having completed the winners.

Beartown was SO much more than I thought it would be. (CW: sexual assault) Fredrik Backman, why do you cause me so much pain? Why do you make me feel so much love? I'm a mess.How can this novel be described? I'm not sure it can. It is one of the rawest, realest books I've read and it is on a very raw and real topic. This book is chock-full of nuance. It shows you every single perspective, as well as how toxic culture is systemic. And that it can get that way on accident, occurring from a town filled with people who think they're doing the right thing. And maybe they are, maybe they're not. It's complicated. It's so, so incredibly complicated.But boy is it good. It's so, so incredibly good.I truly cannot be more touched by someone's writing than Backman's, this I do believe. And despite that for the first 40 pages the constant jumping of perspectives and introducing new characters right after the other made my head kind of spin, I was totally on board. And I got used to the POV shifts. As well as fully went from "now wait, who's this? How can I ever remember all of these people?" To feeling like I knew them all like the back of my hand. So! Off to immediately jump into the sequel. And pray every day will be the day that the third installment of this series is translated into English. (Or that I miraculously learn Swedish just to be able to read it.)

"Never trust people who don't have something in their lives that they love beyond all reason."I've read every single book by this author, and this is now my second favorite after And every morning the road home gets longer and longer. Although I enjoyed his first three books, I'm very glad to see that he is moving away from what was becoming almost formula writing. In Beartown the author shows us the best and worst of humankind, by creating many characters who all make both terrible AND wonderful decisions. The story is not a new one, but this book does not focus on the event, but on how our situation, history and prejudices affect our reaction to an event. I loved that the focus is not so much on the people it happened to, but on everyone else having to decide what they will think/do about it. A point proven by the fact that I have sooo many favorite characters in this book, but the ones I felt least connected to was the involved parties. The reason I read everything this author publishes is his amazing way of saying something about everyday life that we all already know, but saying it in such a way that it resonates very deeply with me. On being a poor kid: He doesn't want possessions. He just wants to lie in bed one single night without having to count.  (money)On a parenting: If she does everything right at work, things usually go as planned, but if doesn't matter if she does absolutely everything in the universe correctly as a mother; the very worst can still happen.I highly recommend this thought-provoking, unique and touching (I had tears rolling down my face for the last 20%) story.

This is only the second book I‚Äôve read by Backman, the first one was ‚ÄúBritt-Marie Was Here‚Äù. They are much the same in many respects (just swap out football in ‚ÄúBritt-Marie Was Here‚Äù for ice hockey in ‚ÄúBeartown‚Äù and you‚Äôre there) yet also very different in other ways: whereas ‚ÄúBritt-Marie Was Here‚Äù is witty, funny, and quirky, ‚ÄúBeartown‚Äù is preachy, woke, and predictable. Evidently the author felt it necessary to write ‚Äúseriously‚Äù because he dealt with serious social problems: rape and homophobia. However, notwithstanding the scourge these practices truly represent, the narrative is just a little too sentimental and obvious for my taste. Everything that happens is pretty much what you would expect and I often had the feeling that the story was written for emotional effect, but perhaps that is unfair to the author. I was also not overly impressed by the translation into English (serves me right for not attempting the book in Swedish, a language I have a basic working knowledge of). E.g. the rendering of the Swedish word ‚Äúsnus‚Äù as ‚Äúchewing tobacco‚Äù is misleading. Snus is a form of wet tobacco that is placed between the upper lip and the gums (it is not ‚Äúchewed‚Äù), from where the nicotine is absorbed directly into the bloodstream. A very effective and clean form of nicotine consumption, apart from the spitting! Snus is illegal in the EU, except in Sweden, where it is very common.

*Disclaimer: An ARC of Beartown by Fredrik Backman was provided to me by Simon & Schuster Canada in exchange for an honest review. This does not effect my opinion in any way.Actual rating: 4.5 stars rated up!--‚ÄúWhen you lose in hockey it feels like having your heart scalded. When you win, you own the clouds. Beartown is a heavenly town this evening.‚ÄùWow. Just wow. I have never read anything by Fredrik Backman before, but let me tell you, I definitely plan on picking up his other novels as soon as possible. Beartown is one of the best books I have read all year. It was unexpectedly dark, yet it dealt with these tough topics perfectly. I‚Äôm still thinking about this book more than a week after finishing it.--What I LikedThe character driven story. I absolutely love character driven stories, even more so than plot driven stories. I loved that Beartown jumped back and forth between the perspectives of multiple characters throughout the entire novel. I love hearing a story from many points of view and while it can sometimes be confusing and hard to keep track of all the characters, Fredrik Backman masterfully made this story easy to follow. The characters were all phenomenally written and while there were a few characters I absolutely DESPISED, there were many that I kept wanting to read more about. Amat, Benji, Sune, Ramona, Maia & Ana were by far my favourite characters throughout the story and I couldn‚Äôt wait to learn more about each of them.The writing. Fredrik Backman has most likely just become a favourite author of mine. I have literally only read Beartown, but I‚Äôm already thinking about ordering his other books ASAP. The writing is just phenomenal. As mentioned, I loved that Beartown was a very character driven story told from many perspectives and Fredrik Backman wrote it perfectly. It flowed so well considering the fact that it jumped from character to character constantly. There was just something about his writing style that makes me want to read everything he has ever written.The hard hitting topics. Let me just preface this paragraph with a spoiler warning. This paragraph also calls for a trigger warning around the topic of rape. What started as a story about small-town hockey, turned into a much darker story about rape and white male privilege. I wasn‚Äôt expecting this story to go in the direction that it did as it turned out to be really hard-hitting and quite unexpectedly dark. A young teenaged girl is raped and while that was hard enough to read on its own, it was even harder to read about how some of the other characters dealt with the situation. I have never felt more disgusted in my life than when I read what some of the other male and female characters opinions were on the situation. What was most disgusting about all of it is that it isn‚Äôt far fetched. It isn‚Äôt unrealistic. This is all too common. Rich white boy with a promising future rapes someone and people come to his defence because they don‚Äôt want to see his career as a professional hockey player tarnished. It‚Äôs disgusting and completely unacceptable. Fredrik Backman writes about this terrible crime in a way that is sadly so realistic, but he also writes it in such a way that as a reader, we know that he is completely aware and understands that this is reality. That if this really happened, people would actually defend this scumbag. I was honestly completely blown away by the way Fredrik Backman wrote this story and how he was able to make me feel countless emotions while reading it.--What I Didn‚Äôt LikeA tad slow moving. The only little tiny minor thing that I didn‚Äôt like was the pace of the novel. Yes, it flowed well and I couldn‚Äôt put it down, but it did kind of take a while to get going. The first quarter or so was a little slow, but once the story picked up, it was all I could think about. As mentioned, this was a little tiny minor complaint. Otherwise, this story was flawless.--‚ÄúThere are thousands of ways to die in Beartown. Especially on the inside.‚ÄùI just can‚Äôt stop thinking about this book and the characters within. It was good and so well written. I need more. I can‚Äôt wait to dive further into the work of Fredrik Backman!--Initial post reading thoughts:Damn. That was a tough one. I was definitely not expecting the subject matter to be so dark and hard-hitting. There were moments that made me happy, but mostly there were moments that made me feel so angry. It is completely disgusting that events such as the one that takes place in this novel are so common. I need some time to properly assess my thoughts and feelings, but just know that this was one of the best books I have read so far this year.

I could not put this book down, and when I found out there is a sequel set to be released in early June I was ecstatic. I was certainly tardy to the party in reading this and wish I hadn‚Äôt waited so long. So, if you were like me and haven‚Äôt read it yet ‚Äì well, you know what I will say next: what are you waiting for?!In Beartown hockey is everything. The town is counting on the junior hockey team to win a championship ‚Äì not just for the glory ‚Äì but for the economic success that would come with it; that is a lot of pressure for seventeen year old boys. The town (parents, former players, board members and sponsors) all say to act in the best interest of the team, but their viewpoints are more selfish than they will ever realize? How far would you go to win? One of the players will commit an act of violence and a young girl will be forever changed. Who will the town rally behind and why? How does one act when the truth could ruin everything?You will love and you will hate, really hate, some of these characters. If you are like me, you will wish you were written into this story as a character so you would have the opportunity to shut one of them up. My goodness did I despise this character. If you read this, or decide to read, you can only guess who I am talking about. Let‚Äôs discuss! The characters you love, you really love. It is pretty simple, you either love them or hate them: the character development ‚Äì hero or villain ‚Äì was strong.There were many characters introduced in the beginning, but I was so engaged in the story that it was easy to keep track. I was a huge fan of the pace and flow, and jived well with author Fredrik Backman‚Äôs writing style and the message he set to deliver through his characters. If you are a fan of contemporary fiction, I highly recommend this read.I have also read Backman‚Äôs A Man Called Ove and need to read more of his novels. I cannot wait for the sequel to Beartown, Us Against You, out June 5th!

I would give the turn on revenge a 5*, but this was a difficult, heart-wrenching read. Lots of good instruction on what not to do as regards alcohol, justice, sports obsession, and gossip. Also, good lessons on being who you truly are, and the pain that comes from hiding that in order to fit in or to become popular.Teen years are fraught with dangers, and parents try to do their best. Sometimes their own issues get in the way. I found it really interesting how some of the (main) characters are not given names. Only "Kevin's dad" or "the mom."I also notched down one star because of the vulgar language which was overdone, and too prevalent. I can tolerate some profanity and some sexism, but not sure this extent was necessary.Still, Backman is a fantastic writer and I will likely read the sequel (once I recover).

I gobbled this up in two days. It's a terrific, important read that really tugs at the heartstrings and simultaneously makes your blood boil.This marks my third novel by Fredrik Backman. I thoroughly enjoyed A Man Called Ove but found the storyline and main character a little too familiar and a lot too precious. My Grandmother Asked You To Tell You She's Sorry was awkward and borderline unreadable to the point I almost gave up.I had heard fantastic things about Beartown thanks to the good folks here at Goodreads: I managed to skim over the reviews to remain relatively ignorant about the plot. I knew it was about a hockey town. (I like hockey.) Miracle and Mystery, Alaska this was not, however.This is a story that can really test you: there's difficult subject matter in here. Characters are complicated and significantly flawed. Life is tough. Heroes have not earned their place in the spotlight.In the age of soccer moms and little league dad brawls and sports hero worship and ultra competitiveness, I could see--and completely understand--a lot of people not enjoying this story for the simple fact that it hits way too close to home. I was on the other side, however: 1) totally impressed at how deep and dark Backman went (I haven't pegged his style yet; the three novels I've read to date are so, so different), and 2) nodding my head up and down in earnest at his portrayal of teenagers carrying the weight of a town on their shoulders: a town that is unknowingly--or knowingly, but looking the other way--harming their young for "a greater good." It's a cautionary tale about "group think" (examined at the sports team level, the school level, the community level, and town). It's about the outliers that come forward in the midst of group think, despite the consequences. I don't think I've read a book as successful at illustrating the dangers of youth sports and its ugly underbelly.I'm at a 4.5 or so. I can't get to 5, because towards the end, there were still a few "Ove" moments: a bit too neatly wrapped up for my liking. But given how engrossed I was in the book as a whole, I'd still pronounce it one of my favorite reads of the year.

Beartown is a small town in the middle of a forest. A town that is dying a slow death. The jobs and young people are leaving. By the lake in Beartown there is an ice rink and therein lies hope for the future of Beartown. There the junior ice hockey team is about to skate in the national semi-finals. The hopes and dreams of an entire town rest on the shoulders of a handful of teenagers. The semi-final match is followed by an act of violence that leaves a fifteen year old girl traumatized and will tear the town apart.This is a coming of age story for a teenage girl who must make a choice between whether to speak out or keep silent. It is the story of team mentality. And it is the story of courage and doing the right thing for the right reason no matter the cost. A hockey championship could lure a hockey academy to Beartown and turn around the economy. But at what price?This is a darker novel than "A Man Called Ove" but there are several heroes in this story. Characters who exhibit strength and courage. It isn't easy being a teenager and it is made even more difficult if an entire town is pinning it's hopes on you to win a hockey championship. This story runs the gamut of emotions. The characters are flawed and distinct. A masterful storyteller.

This was definitely an intense and impactful read. Backman clearly understands the human mind, thoughts and emotions so well. This is about far more than just a sport or a town. It‚Äôs a deep look at humankind and a statement on society. The writing style took a little getting used to for me but I liked that there were multiple storylines that are followed individually as well as when they intersect with others. I loved how it jumped between perspectives and storylines, it really helped to get the full picture and see the ripple effect of different decisions. It was interesting to learn about so many different characters and see a lot of growth in most of them. It was hard and sad to read, but brought up a lot of important topics and discussion points.

Even though he leaves behind his usual theme of quirky older people who seem hardened and unloveable but are discovered to have a soft underbellies(Ove and Britt Marie) , you still won't be surprised that Fredrik Bachman's latest book about a young group of hockey players, still manages to sneak in many life lessons. Hockey is the game that keeps the town alive, and has long bound the small town of Beartown together. Count on Bachman to deliver a story that is full of ponderable questions about love, loyalty, and how far you will go to win... in hockey and in life.A very good and thought provoking book. 5 stars

DNF. I hate it when I don't like a book everyone else loves, but I had to throw in the towel at 50% point. My rating would have been ** My reasons:The characterization and description of the scenery was done to death. We are reminded about the woes, dramas and mannerisms of the not so likeable characters (what they like or don't like, how they feel or don't feel) in every single chapter. I hate it when the author thinks the reader is an idiot who wouldn't get it the first time and has to be force-fed every single information multiple times.In a word, the book is well-written, but for me, that is not enough.
