I should start this out by saying that I'm not a sports fan and that description is putting it mildly. Sports bore me. Usually when I start reading anything about them or watching them, my eyes glaze over and I tune out. This has been the greatest disappointment to my father who has been dragging me to Giants games my whole life. To this day, he has to bribe me with ice cream to get me to go. In other words, this usually wouldn't be my cup of tea. I'm so glad that I gave this book a chance though because it is so much more than a book about hockey. I haven't read Backman's other books besides, "A Man Called Ove," and I will get to them because I own them all and I think he's terrific. But from what I've heard, this book is different from all of them. There isn't a grumpy protagonist at the heart of everything. There's a small town where hockey controls everything and holds the power. The hockey players are treated like kings, particularly the star player Kevin. So when an allegation of rape is made, it throws the whole town out of wack and creates a ripple effect on other issues brewing under the surface.  I don't know if the phrase, "allegation of rape," is correct. To me, it was crystal clear that a rape happened. But for spoiler purposes, I didn't want to give things away. I'll try to think if there's a better way to say that. This book has many themes. Rape, sexuality, friendship, and even more but I can't think of everything right now. I couldn't help but think of the book Missoula: Rape and the Justice System in a College Town and if you've read that, you'll know why. What Backman's done that is similar to Ove is craft characters that will stay in my heart for a very long time. I will be thinking of Benji, Maya, Anna, Bobo, Amat, Sune, David, Kira and Peter for years to come. While many ends are tied up, there are lots of unfinished stories. Normally I would not be ok with this as I ended it desperate for more details about these people I had grown to love so much. However, when I went to hear Backman speak in June, he said he was almost done with a sequel to Beartown. I can hardly wait!I don't usually add personal stories to reviews but I'm going to do so with this one so you can skip over this last part if you'd like. It is a tad lengthy. I deliberately put it at the end so that people could read the book review first and continue on to this only if they felt like it. Part of the story DOES involve Fredrik Backman so it is somewhat related. I don't know about you guys, but so much of what I go through in life trickles down and becomes intertwined with what I'm reading. Or when I think about a book later or reread it later, I'll instantly remember what was happening to me back then. Separate from how beautiful this book is, with characters I'll never forget, I'll forever associate this book with Liz. I've been part of an online book group for the last fifteen years or so give or take a few years. I'm not exactly sure on the specific date I joined. We started out on the ivillage website and then when that shut down, we eventually migrated here to Goodreads and to a small Facebook group. The members live all across the US and we even have someone in Canada and one person in England. These women are my dear friends and I feel as close to them as many of my, "in person," friendships. They have helped me through some hard times.Only one other person besides myself lived in California and that was Liz. Though she only lived two hours away or so, we had never managed to meet up. The lives of introverts right? But when Liz posted on Facebook that Fredrik Backman was coming to the Santa Rosa Library to speak and sign books, we were finally motivated enough to meet. I had loved, "A Man Called Ove," with all my heart and it seemed like a great opportunity.It was such a fun night. We had dinner and strolled around downtown Santa Rosa and then went to the library. Backman was a delight. He was very funny in a dry way which is my favorite kind of funny. My author crush was tripled now. We stood in line after and he signed our books. Liz had a copy of Beartown. I had Beartown and Ove. We got pictures taken with him. I have one that I took at the exact moment she was telling him that it took him coming to California for us to meet after many years of online friendship. He was pretty amazed and his face lit up. He may have also thought we were kind of weird for waiting for so long. When I got in my car to go home, I made tentative plans with Liz to get together much sooner this time now that we had broken the ice. We discussed meeting in the middle to go to the outlets or to have lunch. We both said that we wished we had gotten together much sooner. I was so happy that she was just as kind, warm and funny as she seemed to be online.We did not get to meet again because just a week and one day later, I found out that Liz was gone. I tried not to be mad at myself for not meeting her sooner. Eventually I was just glad that I got a chance at all. Either way, I miss her. I saw that she had finished Beartown right before and that made me happy. She had been very eager to start it and I saw she had rated it five stars. I'm glad she got to finish it.

Hockey is just a silly little game. We devote year after year after year to it without every really hoping to get anything in return. We burn and bleed and cry, fully aware that the most the sport can give us, in the very best scenario, is incomprehensibly meager and worthless: just a few isolated moments of transcendence. That's all. But what the hell else is life made of?
I don't love hockey. I don't hate it. I am apathetic. I mumbled a weakhearted "yay, good for them" when our Washington Capitals finally claimed the Stanley Cup in 2018 after a 20-something-year draught of championships for the Metropolitan area. Yeah, all of the DC teams kind of...(suck). Luckily, no excess of tears, frustration, or disappointments for me because I really don't care about that stuff! But I am not apathetic and I definitely do care about this small group of Beartown inhabitants who have captured my own heart and soul with their extreme obsession over hockey.Why? Because Fredrik Backman is unrivaled in his capacity to express the human condition in words. This made A Man Called Ove one of my favorite books, and Beartown is no different. Do not mistake this as a story about just hockey; it is equally a compelling and skilled exploration of the convoluted gray areas encircling good versus evil, silence versus speaking up, and coming of age versus sheltering youth. All of that takes place in Beartown, a dying town in the middle of a snowy forest. There's one supermarket, jobs are dwindling, and roads are deteriorating. The townspeople know that the only hope of ever reclaiming Beartown's former glory and some much needed infusion of capital is for the junior hockey team to be claimed victor of the championship finals. But as Backman meticulously crafts achingly real backstories and glimmering future dreams for numerous community members with their intersectional identities‚Äîof teenagers, parents, hockey players, coaches, friends, colleagues, adults, kids‚Äîand the perspectives they offer, you come to realize that hockey has oh so many more consequences than you could ever imagine in a town. In what appears at first glance a quiet, near-forgotten town, Beartown is in truth a profound and memorable read that grabs onto your emotions and attention from the very beginning. I was alternately biting my nails or hyperventilating at the end of each chapter, dying to know what happened in some combination of fear, dread, anticipation, and excitement. Despite being much more heavily centered on teenagers in comparison to Backman's A Man Called Ove, this one is a much darker, less innocent departure. You are cut raw by emotions and torn by hard questions. Backman succeeds in boldly confronting humanity's capacity to justify or ignore evil, cruelty, and selfishness. But, as one can expect of this author, he is equally adept at championing goodness, compassion, and courage, proffering an uplifting and hopeful note through all the tears and despair. 
If you are honest, people may deceive you. Be honest anyway. If you are kind, people may accuse you of selfishness. Be kind anyway. All the good you do today will be forgotten by others tomorrow. Do good anyway.‚Äù
And somehow, for those of you who never loved hockey or sports in general, you will walk away not so much loving the sport but loving and respecting and understanding and hating the people who do. Mark my words, if I flip accidentally to hockey on a TV screen, I will assuredly and immediately turn it to a different channel, but Beartown and all its myriad emotions and memories will flash in my mind for a split-second before I turn away to a channel that satisfies my very normal, non-hockey-centered life.

Update Jan 14, 2021: I follow Backman on InstaGram where he told us that the tv series based on this book debuts on HBO/HBO Max in the U.S. on Feb 22, 2021. I will definitely be tuning in!4++ starsBeartown is a story of loyalty, friendship, love, acceptance of self and others, courage, class, politics, culture and the good/bad/ugly of human beings, all set against the backdrop of an economically depressed, one-factory town in the dense woods of northern Sweden that has one thing going for it - hockey! We see how a town and its people can pin their hopes and self-worth on "their team" and how a sports team can both unite and divide. Backman is such a good writer with insight to the human condition that is way beyond his years. In Beartown, he creates memorable characters, including the town itself. I felt like I really knew the town and the townspeople, as if I lived there or nearby. (It wasn't hard to imagine since I live in Minnesota where there are many similarities - obsession with hockey, cold and ice, lots of Scandinavians and many towns that could be Beartown.) I previously read and loved A Man Called Ove and And Every Morning the Way Home Gets Longer and Longer, two very different books, but both touched my heart in a quiet, subtle way. Beartown has a lot more action in a shorter package than Ove and I was swept up in the drama of what would happen to the people, the team and the town. In the last third of the book, the writing becomes almost staccato, quickly shifting from person to person and setting to setting that had me breathless - in a good way! I wanted to know where this would all end up, but I had to slow down in the last hour of the audiobook because I didn't want to leave these people behind.I would have given Beartown 5 stars except that I wasn't as satisfied when all was said and done as I was with Ove. Here it seemed that the resolution of the central crisis of the book was too pat and the people behaved a little out of character to give us a more heartwarming ending. It feels a little like Backman had a movie deal in mind ala Friday Night Lights, but I can't picture a movie of Beartown being anything near as excellent as the movie of A Man Called Ove. (But with that said, if they do make a movie of Beartown, you can be sure I'll go see it :)))I can recommend this as another really good read in the Backman cannon with the above reservations and I heartily endorse the audiobook - excellent narration.

Beartown by Fredrik Backman is one of those books that completely engulf the reader. Right from the start, I could tell I was in good hands, that I was being led on a journey by a writer who knew what he was doing‚Äîa master storyteller, spinning a yarn‚Äîand all I had to do is sit back and enjoy the ride. I had no idea where the story was going to take me, as I usually don't read the blurbs. I remember thinking, okay‚Äîthis is a book about hockey players and a town that pretty much exists because of hockey, but it's well-written and has a lot of subplots going on, so I'll go with the flow. One act changed all that, and I didn't see it coming. After that pivotal moment, all the groundwork the author had laid came into play. It was all there, ready to dovetail and fall into place like a chain of dominos. Everyone who'd been introduced now flashed a different side of his or her character, be it a piece of personal history that slanted their take on events, or nuanced emotions to the gut-wrenching situation they now found themselves in. It would be almost impossible as a reader to not feel as torn as the players in this drama. There's so much at stake, and so many will be destroyed by the outcome, one way or the other.I take my hat off to this author. It's rare to come across a novel where every character is fleshed out in a way that they become instantly visible in the mind's eye, even though he doesn't go overboard with descriptions. He is a master at giving just the right details to sum up each person. Then he layers their personalities with flashbacks and secret moments of doubt and anguish. I give this book 4.5 stars, not because it is faulty in any way, but because it wasn't an easy journey for me as a reader. Fredrik Backman has the courage to write a tough book that embraces all life can dish out, without judging and without pulling punches. I really respect him for this and I will happily read more books by him. I feel a little conflicted about the rating, but I reserve 5 stars for those books that leave me with a warm glow in my heart. This book is an instant classic and deserves to be so, but it‚Äôs not an easy read, in that it takes the reader places that are far from comfortable.

5‚≠ëI simply have no words for how excellent this book was. Wow wow wow!!! This is my second book by Fredrik Backman and I have got to say, I highly enjoy his writing style. Both books that I have read by him so far, have had a bit of a slow start but his writing still intrigues me enough to want to continue. Honestly, this book had everything that a book needs to have to deserve a 5 star rating from me; - strong family relationships - strong female friendships <3 - great character development - important topics of discussion - impactful writing

Let‚Äôs play HOCKEY! That‚Äôs the cry that signals the start of hockey games in the US, as I recall. As a high school and college student, I witnessed a few battles on the ice. Now, I guess I‚Äôve mostly outgrown it, mostly due to prevalence of fighting, I suppose. But when I picked up Fredrick Backman‚Äôs Beartown, and saw the word ‚Äúhockey‚Äù in the third sentence of the first chapter, a reference to the upcoming youth hockey semifinal game, I fully expected lots and lots of hockey action. Surprise! The actual game isn‚Äôt fought until, gee, about one-fourth of the way into the story! Yet, hockey permeates this book. Beartown, most of its residents feel, would be nothing without hockey. From the time they learn to walk, most boys learn to skate. (Some girls learn too, but there are no teams for girls.) Not long after that, they are picking up sticks and learning to handle and shoot a puck. Families of players are all in, most of them, that is. They drive their kids to practice, attend their games, and make sacrifices so that their kids, their players, can become the best. Every kid wants to be one of the Bears, the Bears from Beartown.Learning to skate, develop skills, build strength, power, and stamina, and blend with other players to form a cohesive unit takes time. I felt like the plot and character development of this book was much like that. At times, I found it hard to be patient, partly because the prologue foretells a terrible event, and then leaves the reader to ponder and wonder who, what, where, when, and why. There are so many characters ‚Äì the Anderssons ‚Äì Peter, who is the GM of the hockey club, his wife Kira, a lawyer, their 15-year-old daughter Maya, and their 12-year-old son. There are hockey coaches, Sune and David, teenage hockey players like Kevin from a wealthy family and Benji, his best friend, who is not wealthy. Then there is Amat, an immigrant kid who lives in ‚Äúthe Hollow‚Äù and skates like the wind. There is Maya‚Äôs best friend Ana, who spends most of her time at the Anderssons‚Äô home. Initially, there were too many names that made it hard to connect with any one individual. The story jumped from one person or family to another, showing slices of life in the small town. Was it effective? I suppose, because it eventually began to take shape, but it took me a long time to feel at ease with this story.When it does all begin to coalesce, things happen fast. There is hockey action! One criticism I have is that Backman‚Äôs third person omniscient narrator often tells rather than shows us what‚Äôs going on. He speaks, sometimes in clich√©s, sometimes much more eloquently, but also many times it seemed edifying, and there were moments when I wished he would refrain from instructing and just let a comment or an action sit there for the reader to consider. However, the hockey scenes made me feel like I was there in the crowd.The party afterward is where things go wrong. Up to this point, the setting could be Warroad, Minnesota, or Thunder Bay, Ontario, or any other small town in Sweden or a village in any other cold climate. Then it happens. It could happen anywhere. A party where teens and alcohol and hormones mix. A town that has been united by hockey is suddenly torn apart. What is unity? What is community? What is loyalty? What is courage, and what does it cost? Along with the shock comes blame. He said; she said. Blame the parents, the coaches; even blame hockey. It happens in high schools and colleges everywhere. People in the US and around the world know about the case of Brock Turner, the Stanford student athlete who got an extremely light sentence for felony sexual assault. This novel brought up feelings of anger and sadness for that victim and for women and men all over the world who have faced these situations. Don‚Äôt blame hockey. Don‚Äôt blame sports. Ramona says, ‚ÄúBlame the f*ing MEN!‚Äù Even that is oversimplification.Backman understands the culture that allows girls and women to become dehumanized. He portrays the female characters as both strong and vulnerable. His male characters are also both vulnerable and strong. His depictions show great perception and sensitivity. The thing is, in Beartown, no one really talks much. I‚Äôm not sure Beartown is all that different from small towns anywhere in that regard, or even large cities. The verses ‚Äì indeed, pieces of his writing are poetic ‚Äì capture the hearts and souls of the men and women as they struggle to raise their children and to protect them and of kids who scramble to fit in, to find their place, to learn, to love, to accept, to win, and to heal. He seems to get it, to really KNOW the intense fear of the dark that won‚Äôt go away‚Ä¶and finally - Bang! We know what the prologue teased us with nearly 400 pages earlier. And it's not quite what I expected. It's so much more.Beartown is an uncommonly good book. And no, you don‚Äôt have to be a hockey fan to love it.4.5 stars
I can‚Äôt believe I almost DNFed this book because I don‚Äôt enjoy or understand hockey. But it‚Äôs about a lot more than that.rtc

Opens: Late one evening, toward the end of March, a teenager picked up a double-barrelled shotgun, walked into the forest, put the gun to someone else's forehead, and pulled the trigger. This is the story of how we got there.My Thoughts: Although the events before, during and after an ice hockey match are the bones that the story is pinned on ‚Äì the focus is NOT ice hockey. For which I was truly thankful because I know nothing about the game ‚Äì other than it looks very dangerous! No, the book‚Äôs focus is on the individual characters that are directly involved, and also on the emotions of the township as a whole ‚Äì this quote sums it up:‚Äú‚Ä¶Hate can be a deeply stimulating emotion. The world becomes easier to understand and much less terrifying if you divide everything and everyone into friends and enemies, we and they, good and evil. The easiest way to unite a group isn't through love, because love is hard, it makes demands. Hate is simple. So the first thing that happens in a conflict is that we choose a side, because that's easier than trying to hold two thoughts in our heads at the same time. The second thing that happens is that we seek out facts that confirm what we want to believe - comforting facts, ones that permit life to go on as normal. The third is that we dehumanize our enemy‚Ä¶‚ÄùThere is a diverse cast of characters and their different viewpoints are each recorded meticulously. Being a small isolated town in a remote area of Sweden the community of Beartown is tightly knit ‚Äì they all know each other, and pull together to survive. The upcoming ice hockey match is currently the sole focus of the town, with the expected win to potentially turn the town fortunes around.So, summed up, the hopes of the whole town all ride on the shoulder of one young star player. So when after a pre-match party he is accused of rape the focus of Beartown turns onto his alleged victim; she now becomes the only thing standing between Beartown finally declining and it‚Äôs rebirth as a society. You can imagine that sympathy is not a common thought towards her. The resulting furore becomes a catalyst for a very traumatic time for the community. With accusations and counter accusations flying; lies, innuendo and rumours being taken as fact ‚Äì the citizens of Beartown almost immediately start to show their true colours and the lines are drawn. But what is more important ‚Äì an ice hockey match or a human being? Friends become enemies, and enemies team up in a common cause. The many different actions taken are slowly woven together as each action causes a reaction that ripple-effects across the town and adds to the progress of the story. I became utterly engrossed as the story gradually unfolded.Beartown was an emotional rollercoaster for me as my reactions to the events and conversations triggered my mood to swing from happy to angry to upset and back to happy again ‚Äì sometimes in the same chapter! Often, the actions of the characters surprised me in how they reacted, especially when it was different to how I thought they should react. Beartown tackles some heavy issues - peer pressure, homophobia, rape culture and hero worship of sportsmen and women. All very current themes faced daily by different societies around the world.An edge of the seat story ‚Äì and, as I have said, an emotional rollercoaster that left me panting in exhaustion at the end.With thanks to Atria Books and the author via Netgalley for my copy to read and review.

There's a problem with the Goodreads rating system, and I'm not talking about the "only 5 stars, why can't we have 10" complaints. I'm talking about how it wobbles between how good you think a book is, and how much you liked it. These are two completely separate things: quality and enjoyment are not the same thing or even necessarily related. Some enormously enjoyable reads aren't particularly deep, aren't especially well-written, don't say anything new or important - indeed, there might even be serious problems with a book which still provides reading enjoyment. 4* for "really liked it"? Or 2* for "it was ok"? (And what if it doesn't come up to "ok"? I tend to strongly dislike poorly-written books, but some of them get good reviews from others.) And then there are books which address important subjects in hugely perceptive ways, or shine a new light on an important topic, or show astonishing writing skill, or which have characters so real that you miss them when you finish the book, but which are depressing, or cover subject matter which is intrinsically not pleasurable. 5* for "it was amazing"? Or 1* for "did not like it"?Beartown is one of those books. I cannot honestly say that I "really liked" a book about the rape of a young woman and the aftermath of that event. But it is a great book. Backman handles heavy subject matter in a sensitive way, within a clever format. This book demonstrates such a clear understanding of the perspectives of a wide range of characters, showing the humanity and frailty in all. This is wonderful story-telling with a strong impact.I picked this up because I had very much enjoyed other books by this author: A Man Called Ove and My Grandmother Sends Her Regards and Apologises. Like those, this offers many beautiful phrases - I highlighted too many sections to quote here - and has strong characterisation, but this book is driven more by events, and it is certainly much darker.Is it a book about sports? Yes and no. Backman uses ice-hockey as framework and analogy and certainly in the early part of the book, I wondered if I was getting as much out of it as I would if I had the least interest in ice-hockey. But it's about life, family, power, denial, strength, love. If this is a book about sports, then Backman should be applauded for getting me, with my near-absolute lack of interest in sports, to read and be awed by a book about sports.Note: I've read one or two reviews from readers who didn't find it credible that so much of the community stood behind Kevin, the boy who rapes Maya. To those, I'd respond: just look at what happens when celebrities - athletes, actors, directors - are accused of harassment, assault or worse. So many people stand by them and/or refuse to believe allegations despite ample evidence, sometimes even proof or admission of guilt. 2017 has been a year when a lot of powerful people have fallen, but in many of those cases, their abuse of power was known about and tolerated for many years - and in other cases, they are still directing, acting, playing, presidenting...

"'one day, zach, you'll have more money and influence than all those bastards. and then you'll do great things. because you know how much it hurts to have no power. so you won't hurt them, even though you could. and that will make the world a better place.'"

I am utterly incapable of a speaking single syllable right now. Quite possibly my new favorite book of all time.So, before I break down, I will write a very short but hopefully proper review. The most observable strength of this book is definitely the writing. Fredrik Backman will absolutely astound you with the way he crafts a sentence into a masterpiece. You can tell by reading any chapter in this book that the words spill straight from his heart onto the page. And the result is pure beauty.Once you get over the writing, other things start to hit you. Such as the flawed and endearing characters. The characters in this book are so three-dimensional, so complex, so human that I was entirely too close to screaming out in delight, because that is a very rare thing to find in books nowadays. The story, at its core, is about a small town deep in the woods in Sweden called Beartown. Life in Beartown revolves around the sport of ice hockey, and the people in this town have stacked all their hopes of becoming a bigger town onto the shoulders of the boys in their junior ice hockey team. The team is about to compete in the finals, and the entire town is buzzing with excitement. Little does anyone know about the horrors to come that will cause a young girl's entire universe to come crashing down. And it couldn't have been told in a better way. There was no sugar-coating. There was no shying away from difficult subjects, such as rape. It was all so raw. And that is part of why I loved it so much. It was so obvious that this book was written by a person understands humans in a way few others do, acknowledges their beauties but also their shortcomings, their joys but also their sorrows, their good but also their bad.I have so much respect for Fredrik Backman.trigger warnings: rape, sexual assault, victim blaming, strong language, drinking, violence‚ûº 5 stars

Beartown was an excellent read. Backman's characters feel real and though this is the only book I've read by him so far; I'm putting him on a very exclusive shelf with Marlon James as a male who creates authentic and substantive female characters. I found two unicorns in 2020!! I'm going to keep this review short. Beartown is about a dying town, sports obsessed with hockey and all of the human behaviors that make it run. The book is a character study showcasing a pretty broad range of human emotions and motivations and viewpoints. And it is very thoughtful. All of the personalities are strong, some of the characters are extremely substantive. The readers understand who they are and why they behave the way they do. This is the kind of book that sticks with you and has far more meaning beyond the plot and the conclusion.The book is very white. A remote Scandinavian town with events taking place in the dead of winter with the snow piled high among the monochromatic population. Not every book is meant to be diverse. The book appears to be true to what it purports. I had a couple of issues: Maya was just a little too much. Too wise, too clear-headed, too worldly, too mature, too bold, too certain, too well-adjusted for a 15 year old. Also all of the characters were just a little too good. Maybe I'm very cynical but these characters were capable of deep introspection and I just don't think that is indicative of the average person...or am I judging by American standards? Because there was only one character that did not do some soul searching and that was the uber wealthy father of Kevin. Simplistic: extremely wealthy/big business=bad; everybody else=good deep down. I feel so jaded, but I'm just too old and seen too much to be utterly charmed by this book. But in all honesty, I enjoyed it immensely and the choice of a female narrator for a novel ostensibly about hockey seems bold; but Marin Ireland knocked it out of the park (sorry for the cross sports metaphor)!! There is definitely more Backman in my future. At a minimum the sequel Us Against You. But I see myself going beyond the minimum in this case. He's a terrific storyteller!!4+ StarsListened to the audiobook. Marin Ireland is brilliant!!

What can I say? Fredrik Backman, you've done it again. I am speechless and shocked and in awe etc etc. I had the time of my life reading Beartown: a chilly, honest examination of a small, poor town whose future rests on the shoulders of the local teenage hockey team. Unlike Backman's previous works, which focus on one (sometimes two, but usually) one character, Beartown features a large cast. I was very thrown off by this at first, as I'd become used to Backman's style; he really changes it up here. It took fifty or so pages for me to get a handle on all the characters, but once I did I really enjoyed the ride. All these people are endlessly fascinating to read about--they harbor grudges and secrets and hopes; Backman writes about the powerful, underdogs, and everyone in between with precision and raw skill. Topics such as homosexuality, the alluring power of groupthink, small town politics, rape culture, and parenthood are handled with surprising ease and dignity. Backman is a master of misdirection: he leads his readers in one direction, only to reveal it's all a fake out and, instead, takes them to a much more fulfilling place. Sorry, fanboying here. I just really love this author, okay? Beartown is a fabulous novel. It's a relentless tour de force. I couldn't find anything to complain about if I tried. I don't even like hockey, but the author made it not only interesting ‚Äî he actually had me on the edge of my seat during the game scenes. That's a feat in itself! Highly recommended to any and all readers. This is slightly different from his previous work, and I welcome the change. An author has to grow to survive. I cannot wait to see what Backman publishes next! (I'd also like to show my appreciation for Neil Smith, who translated this fine novel from the original Swedish to English. Great job!)

One of the things that will make a whole community "group think" is sports. Group think ~ A process of reasoning or decision-making by a group.  That definition does not say that the reasoning or decision-making will be positive. You see just as much negative group think as positive. The community of Beartown weathered both positive and negative. Beartown is a small community like most. It had a wealthy section and a poor section. The overall community was dying and the major players of the community wanted growth and recognition. The thing that brought these two sections of people together was the ice rink - Beartown Hockey - the teenage boys who played their hearts out. We follow a number of hockey players and their families - from both sides of town. The teenagers currently playing and also the men who had played the sport - both those still involved with the rink and those no longer involved. Backman took us deep within family and what that means and where that lays in the heart of each man. He did not mince any words or situations when it came to family life or it's trauma. He highlighted the things that drive any particular man and makes it appear that family is not his main concern. And he also brought family to the forefront as the most important thing in a mans life. Depending on the situation - and there are many situations in this story, both positive and negative - the families in this novel either grew or regressed. The community mentality either ebbed or flowed. As the story concludes a solution is found. Maybe not ideal, but one that most could live with. Each man and family had to make their own decision. Hockey was still the main sport and motivation, however group think was not as prominent as it once had been.

TW for rape/SANow I won‚Äôt be retracting any of my previous ‚ÄúFredrik Backman can do no wrong‚Äù statements, but ‚ÄòBeartown‚Äô is definitely my first book of his that I‚Äôve had a hard time enjoying. A big reason I didn‚Äôt love this one was because I identified a bit TOO much with the story, and therefor picked it to pieces until it was no longer enjoyable. I, like Maya, was sexually assaulted at 15 and also faced the repercussions of rape culture, so to say it hit close to home would be an understatement (yes, I knew what the story was about before reading, I just wasn‚Äôt prepared for our circumstances to be so similar and usually am not triggered easily so I thought I would be fine).I‚Äôm glad this book exists for others to understand stories like mine and approach them with more empathy, but as for the victims of the crime depicted in the book? Not so much. Personally, I would not recommend this to anyone who has went through SA, especially if you are experiencing PTSD. One of my biggest pet peeves in media surrounding rape is how hopeless victims are portrayed, and that was unfortunately very present in ‚ÄòBeartown‚Äô. After Maya is assaulted, it‚Äôs brought up continuously how she‚Äôll never really recover, will always be afraid of the dark, etc., and while I think Backman wrote those lines (with nothing but good intentions) to try to ingrain in the reader how terrible rape is; the prospect of one day recovering from that trauma shouldn‚Äôt diminish the horror of it. Yes, sexual assault is among the worst things someone can go through, but it doesn‚Äôt have to be a lifelong wound. I‚Äôm so grateful to be living in a time where issues like this can be openly discussed, and at the same time, I don‚Äôt think the amount of dispair that surrounds survivors is productive to the conversation!! It sounds corny, but whoever said ‚Äúthere is a light at the end of the tunnel‚Äù was kinda right, and I‚Äôve started making my way towards it :‚Äô)VAGUE/MINOR SPOILERS IN THE NEXT PARAGRAPHSAnother thing that I disliked about this book was that climactic ending. Fredrik Backman‚Äôs finales typically tie together perfectly and have a sort of full-circle moment, and while it usually works for me, this one just didn‚Äôt. Something about the whole eye-for-an-eye / trauma-for-trauma situation just wasn‚Äôt satisfying to me, not saying it wasn‚Äôt warranted (!!!) but‚Ä¶ yeah I don‚Äôt know, there really isn‚Äôt a gratifying way to wrap up a story that deals with topics as heavy as rape.However, I did appreciate how Kevin was written as a fully fledged human being, and not just as a cookie-cutter villain like most sexual offenders in media are portrayed. I don‚Äôt think a lot of people really internalize the fact that rapists are everyday people; your neighbors, your coworkers, even your friends or family members. Is this a scary thought? Absolutely, but if we remove perpetrators of their nuance and reduce them to black-and-white we strip them of their humanity, which makes us stray even farther from solving the issue at hand. Props to the author for not taking that route!SPOILERS OVERAll issues aside, this is Fredrik Backman we‚Äôre talking about; I could have infinite issues with his story and it would still be readable and engaging, simply because he wrote it. I‚Äôm not sure if I‚Äôll continue on with the series any time soon, but if I do, it will be for Benji and Amat (my sons, actually). Definitely not my favorite of his works or one I would recommend to everyone, but I still think ‚ÄòBeartown‚Äù is an important story and am happy that it‚Äôs out there.

I loved this book. Many would say that Beartown by Fredrik Backman is about hockey but please don't be deterred if you are not a hockey fan. In the sub tropical city I live in ice hockey is almost unheard of. I don't know the first thing about the sport but that doesn't matter in the least. Sure the book is about a town that lives and breathes hockey. It is the blood that pumps through the town's veins. It's everywhere and it's vital to life in Beartown, but hockey is not all there is to this story. It's about the people in the community, how they deal with each other, the things they do and don't do based upon their past experiences. It's about people doing what you let them get away with.Beartown is a forestry town in sharp decline. Some say you can't live in this town, only survive it. The Bears Junior team has been training hard for years and are on the cusp of winning a major championship. The town's fortunes are hanging on this outcome and winning is the only acceptable option.  " There are no almosts in hockey." WIN!! is what these boys are told. In their club there are posters and pennants that read  Culture. Values. Community.. Without giving away any plot points it's fair to say one event shakes the town to the core and the words on those posters are thrown into question. People's values are tested. The culture of the club is put into question and the community is divided. Morals and motivations are put under the spotlight. Right versus wrong. Loyalty, courage, truth and lies, secrets, trust and betrayals. They're some of the big issues this book forces you to think upon. Fedrik Backman puts readers in the shoes of the characters in this town, some loveable, some not so much, all with human flaws, fears and frailties. These characters, this book is the stuff of life and it's so relatable regardless of whether you're from a hockey town or not. " There are no almosts in hockey." and the same can be said of Fredrik Backman's writing. He gives his all and we, the reading public, are the ones that benefit. Excuse me now while I go and start on the sequel.

If "The Mighty Ducks" and "Speak" had a baby, and it was delivered by a male Swedish Jodi Piccoult, this book is what you'd get.I live in The State of Hockey, grew up playing pond hockey, and love all things hockey in general; this book did not do it for me. Beartown is a small town that has seen better days. The citizens of the town have placed their hopes and dreams for reigniting the town‚Äôs economy on the outcome of the games of the town‚Äôs talented hockey team. After one incident of violence, however, the townsfolk find that they must examine and act upon their own convictions of morality and justice. This is a coming of age story that is heart wrenching. It‚Äôs a story about character, decisions and consequences, courage, resilience, and, ultimately, healing.Fredrik Backman perfectly captures the atmosphere of small town life in this thought provoking and unforgettable novel.

As the story develops there are subtle hints, so you get an idea the direction this tale may turn. Stil I found it almost shocking. This is a novel, this is literary fiction. I would have given it 5 stars, but I was disappointed in the ending (my opinion), I don't want to say anything more about it because I dont want to give even a tiny bit of a spoiler. 4.3 stars

My favorite quote from this book:  "The love a parent feels for a child is strange. There is a starting point to our love for everyone else, but not this person. This one we have always loved, we loved them even before they existed. No matter how well prepared they are, all moms and dads experience a moment of total shock, when the tidal wave of feelings first washes through them, [...] its incomprehensible because there's nothing to compare it to. It's like trying to describe sand between your toes or snowflakes on your tongue[...]" Ch.44

This was a very excellent book, with a few flaws that prevent me from giving it 5 stars, but with ending chapters that will warm your heart and make you think there may be hope for the human race after all. Slow at the beginning, and a good number of characters to get to know. But those characters are magnificent. Ramona and Amat stand out for me. So many were such fine people, though; and the characters, for me, absolutely make this the book that it is.
